title: Pirelli Classic Marathon Rally
subTitle: Stirling Moss and me, crossing Europe in a 1965 GTB.
promoTeaserSmall: In 1989, I was Stirling Moss's navigator in a 1965 MGB. Here's the Automobile Magazine story.
promoTeaser: In 1989, I was Stirling Moss's navigator in a 1965 MGB. Here's the Automobile Magazine story.
metaDescription: Vintage story on vintage racing: My 1990 story on driving in the Pirelli Classic Marathon Rally with Stirling Moss, previously published in Automobile Magazine. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
This article first appeared in the January 1990 issue of Automobile Magazine. To see how Stirling, now Sir Stirling Moss, looks and sounds right now, see my video interview shot earlier this spring.


Cortina d’Ampezzo—I admit I was a little nervous, so I called my friend Pat Moss, the great rally champion, for a bit of advice.
“I’m doing that weeklong vintage rally across Europe in June with your brother,” I told her.

“Oh, Christ!” she laughed. “Stirling’s sense of humor is a little slow. You’ll have to go notch-notch with him. And he’s a terrifying driver,” teased the sister of one of the greatest racing drivers in history.

Actually, I wasn’t worried about the driving. At fifty-nine years old, the great Moss was still great. But I’d heard that he was a real bear—a persnickety, cranky, demanding perfectionist—with a boundless appreciation for the opposite sex.
It was all true.

Pirelli, in its unparalleled enthusiasm for motorsports, was for the second year sponsoring this epic 2,000-mile marathon across Europe in pre-1965 rally cars. Just over 100 teams from seven countries had entered their Jaguars and MGs and Austin-Healeys. There were several Ford Lotus-Cortinas, Sunbeam Rapiers and Tigers and Alpines, a couple of Volvo PV544s, some Rileys, two Jowett Jupiters, three Lancia Aurelia B20s, and a stunning Lancia Aprilia. There were also a Healey Silverstone, a Swallow Doretti, a Ferrari 275GTB, and a 1934 Talbot 105.

To guarantee a rousing battle, Pirelli had signed up five of the most famous names in rallying—Timo Makinen, Roger Clark, Ove Andersson, Paddy Hopkirk, and Stirling Moss—to participate. Among them, the now-graying famous five had won forty-three World and European Championship Rallies and sixteen Grands Prix (guess who). To undercore his genius on the open road, Stirling had also won the Targa Florio and the Mille Miglia and was one of only two drivers in history to have won a gold Alpine Cup for finishing three successive Alpine Rallies with no road penalties. My driver.

Our biggest drawback would be the car, a sweet little 1965 MGB roadster with an 1,800-cc engine, prepared by British MG specialist and vintage racing driver Ron Gammons. How could we possibly compete against the mighty 4.2-liter E-type Jaguars and the blistering Mini Coopers?

“I tell you, I bloody well want to win this thing,” Stirling shouted back to me. I was hanging on for dear life as we sped across London on his moped, along the Thames to the Tower Bridge, where our car was waiting at a press conference.
People pointed to us from the sidewalk, and you could see their moths say, “Stirling Moss.” Cabbies yelled to him at red lights: “Hey, Stirling! I remember the Cooper!”

I had stayed up pretty late looking through our two-volume route book. In the next seven days we would have to check in on time at seventy-seven controls stretching across seven countries, from London to Cortina d’Ampezzo in the Italian Alps, with a loop through Yugoslavia. We would be driving many of the most famous roads and mountain passes of the brutal Liege-Rome-Liege and the Alpine Rallies of the 1950s and early 1960s. There would be seven special timed speed sections including a lap of the Nurburgring, a visit to Hockenheim, and three hill-climbs. From all appearances, there were few opportunities for Stirling’s driving skill to win position and seventy-seven chances for me to get us lost, check in late, and blow it.

Sunday

We started seventh in the sea of people and cars that crowded the Tower Bridge at 7:30 a.m., waving adieu to Stirling’s wife, Susie, and eight-year-old son, Elliot. Barely out of London and Stirling was waving to a carful of young cuties. I looked at him sternly, and he laughed.
“You can pick up a nice wife that way,” he explained.

Our first destination was an abandoned Hoverport on the coast where we would run a gymkhana before boarding the channel ferry for Dunkirk. One little twist at the end that would handicap us for the rest of the rally was the proviso that the co-driver had to leap from the car and hit a red button on the timing table to arrest the time clock. I am no lithe, limber, leaping sprite. Especially not in a five-point safety harness. We placed eleventh, beaten by Paddy Hopkirk in his Mini Cooper, Timo Makinen in his Victor Gauntlett-owned Austin-Healey 3000, two other Austin-Healeys and another Mini, a Lotus-Cortina, a Jaguar E-type, a Triumph Vitesse, and two other MGBs. What we could not abide was that one of those MGBs was our team owner, Ron Gammons, who was clearly out of his skull with joy for having beaten the great Moss. Small consolation that we pipped Roger Clark’s Cortina by a second.

There wasn’t a big sulk across France and Belgium, but Stirling was not going to let this happen again. We might not win overall, but he wasn’t going to be beaten by an identical car. He made me look up the next test, tomorrow morning’s run through a Belgian park, and decipher the course.

pages.name: page2

pageElements.text:
Monday

We lined up behind Mike McCarthy, editor in chief of Britain’s Classic and Sportscar and co-driver/photographer Julian Mackie. Their ’55 Austin-Healey 100-Four was acting up, and they promised to keep out of our way if we caught them on the course.

Stirling and our MGB were flawless, flicking through the haybale chicanes and pivoting around an impossible hairpin that circled a huge oak. We caught our friends from Classic and Sportscar, and they dove for the ditch so we could race past. I had the belts off and the door open the minute I caught sight of the time clock and slapped the red button as fast as I could manage. We smoked everyone around us and found out later that only the number 75 Austin-Healey 3000 of John Chatham was faster. We also noted that we tied for second with the number 107 Ford Lotus-Cortina of Piggy Thompson and Eddie Ganderton, who had knocked down the fastest penalty-free run at the Hoverport. We’d beaten Paddy by a second and Ron Gammons by fourteen seconds. Timo’s Austin-Healey blew a fuel pump fuse and died on the course for five minutes.

Stirling beamed as we sped along deserted two-lanes, descending from the Ardennes to Haccourt, following signs to Liege. We crossed into West Germany and, as we climbed into the Eifel Mountains, saw our first sign for the Nurburgring.
We planned to ace the Nurburgring. Who better than ringmeister Stirling Moss? As it turned out, a whole bunch of people once we’d bungled the reversing test.

The Nurburgring test began with a backward run through a slalom course, a sly attempt by the organizers to keep the rally’s average speed down to the sanctioning body’s strict 35-mph average. Our problems began when Stirling headed for the wrong side of the first cone, a twenty-second penalty. I yelled for him to go the other way, and it took forever to sort it all out. If it weren’t for Stirling’s knowledge of the track (he described each turn in advance as he flew around), we would have finished much worse than thirteenth fastest. The number 75 Austin-Healey was in front again, sharing fast lap with Paddy Hopkirk’s Mini Cooper. And this time, not only Ron Gammons but his son Malcolm in the third MGB of our Bees’ Knees team beat our time.

The next test—at Hockenheim—wasn’t until the following morning. Our enjoyment of the winding route along the Moselle, and of the forest roads we traveled between the two legendary circuits, was woefully dampened.

“We’ll gradually have to lower our sights just to keep morale up in the car,” moaned Stirling. “First, it was an overall win. Then first in class. Now it’s team prize and an Alpine Cup.” We had laughed at that, and somehow the day brightened.

Tuesday

We were tenth fastest at Hockenheim, but Roger Clark’s Lotus-Cortina conked out for a spell midway around the circuit, so we moved up a notch (with John and Alison Woolley’s Triumph Vitesse) to sixth overall. Timo’s Austin-Healey was healed, setting fast time by two seconds, but his previous electrical problems had dumped him in less-than-threatening sixty-sixth place overall.

Very soon the rally would become brutal, and we’d have a chance to fight our way back. But for now, as we drove across rural Germany, the hills were small, and the sky was so blue it looked fake. Stirling prayed for rain as we got our first real glimpse of the Alps from Fussen. We had 100 miles of serious snow-capped peaks before we reached our stop for the night in Merano, Italy. The last was the Passo del Rombo, at 8,232 feet, with an Italian customs booth at the top. It was the first (but not the last) time Stirling’s driving style really grabbed my attention. He had been flying along, which doesn’t bother me, and to save the brakes in the mountains, he had been using the throttle and steering wheel rather flamboyantly in concert with the understeer. That didn’t bother me. The Passo Del Rombo bothered me.
First, he didn’t believe me when I told him customs was a mere half-kilometer ahead of us, around one of those blind turns.
“Any second now!” I yelled.
“Stirling!” I yelled.
He hadn’t begun to lift when we crested the hill and saw the guards in their little booth, handing passports back to some other rallyists.

“Shit!” yelled Stirling, throwing us into a slide to scrub off speed.  The guards took one look at the rally car sliding toward their shelter and hit the floor. We were still sliding when their peaked caps came up, then eyes, then arms waving us frantically past.

“Go, go, go!” I hollered, and we were heading down the other side. Which scared me worse. There were the dark, narrow, slimy tunnels. There was a tiny road slashing back and forth down the mountain, so narrow that at one point a truck had to reverse for a half-mile to let a bus past. There were the carabinieri, chasing us in a Land Rover, which didn’t stop Stirling from passing Paddy’s Mini Cooper on a piece of road barely big enough for both cars. Navigator Alec Poole was at the wheel.
“It’s good to do that, even if Paddy wasn’t driving,” said Stirling. “It’s a mental thing.”
I said nothing.
“And anyway, I enjoyed it, so sod that.” He began singing something Italian in an exaggerated basso profundo, speeding up from 70 kph to 90.

“You’re not a nervous passenger, are you?” he said without looking. “Because if you are, I feel sorry for you.” He thought that was pretty funny. Even funnier were the carabinieri, who finally caught us at the bottom of the hill and passed us with very big smiles and waves. Stirling passed them back.

I was actually becoming used to Stirling’s aversion to following other cars. It wasn’t the passing that took adjustment as much as the shouting and waving that accompanied every single pass. If the party to be overtaken moved over promptly, he was rewarded with a hand wave from Stirling. Any resistance and Stirling would lay on the horn, wave his fist menacingly, and shout insults as he went by. He shocked the Germans and the Austrians, but we were in Italy now, and they loved it, especially his rude Italian. He loved it, too.

pages.name: page3

pageElements.text:
Wednesday

The rally reseeded Wednesday morning in Merano, with the fast cars at the front of the pack—even Timo, who the organizers decided to start twentieth “in the interest of safety,” despite his fifty-eighth-place position. The order now went: John Chatham’s Austin-Healey, Piggy Thompson’s Cortina, the E-type of Henry Pearman, Paddy’s Mini, and our archrival for first in class 6b, Tony Dron in another MGB. We were seventeen seconds back, still tied with the Woolleys' Vitesse.

Paddy strolled over as we waited for the day to begin. “Stirling, you know old John Chatham over there fancies himself quite the driver,” he said. We all looked at the ruddy-faced Chatham, enjoying his fame as the rally leader.

“Why don’t you go over and ask for his autograph? That’ll get him bothered, and he’ll run off the road straight away.” Paddy’s co-driver was holding out a pen and a vintage racing magazine with Chatham’s Austin-Healey on the cover, and somehow, I was the one coerced into doing the dirty deed. Chatham was quite obliging, and the jinx was on in Paddy’s devilish Irish eyes.

Four of rallying’s greatest mountain passes were planned for this day: the Stelvio, the Gavia, the Vivione, and the Croce Dominii. The Stelvio would be a closed-road hill-climb, uphill only, which would favor the stronger cars.

As hyped as I was to be racing up the famous Stelvio, it was pretty uneventful. Left. Right. Left. Right. More exciting than the drive was seeing forth-place Paddy along the way, leaning against his dead Mini. But the true excitement happened on the way down. Not to us, but to Roger and Margaret Ealand in a lovely red 1965 E-type Jaguar.

Mr. and Mrs. Ealand had had quite a ball running up the Stelvio, and at the top, Mister confided to Missus that this was for him. Yes, he would be pursuing this type of adventure from here on. Ten kilometers later, marked in the route book as “first of many tunnels. CARE—some very narrow,” they crashed heavily, mangling their pretty Jag. Rally officials nearby helped them move the car from the tunnel and to the side of the road, which also happened to be the side of the cliff. A flatbed truck came by, and as the truck driver and Mr. Ealand attempted to pull the Jaguar aboard, Mr. Ealand’s rope snapped, and he pitched off the side of the cliff. Mrs. Ealand fainted dead away. Thankfully, Mr. Ealand's fifty-foot plunge left him merely bruised and shaken.

While the drama of the E-type was unfolding behind us, we headed for the Gavia. After a mad scramble for fuel (during which Stirling had to shout in Italian at two gas stations' worth of attendants to get served during off hours), we found our road—a tiny, barely paved piece of nothing wriggling up through the forest and bounded by a thin little wooden slat guardrail. Except where it was missing.

We came around one bend and were stopped cold by an eathmover completely blocking the way. Stirling leapt from the car and, wasting no niceties, shouted in Italian, the gist of which was “important race,” “no time,” and probably a few motivational words learned from his race mechanics back in the old days. I was mortified. They shouted back. He shouted louder. They caved in. We were through.

We hit the Passo di Gavia summit—a spectacular expanse of high snow fields with a 360-degree view of jagged mountain ranges—at a dead run. The road down was disintegrating, and we banged and rattled at speed over the rough terrain. With seventeen minutes and six kilometers left to our checkpoint, Stirling plotted how to arrive with just enough time to clock in with the front-runners straggling behind us. Piggy Thompson’s Lotus-Cortina was the only car in front of us as we headed for a series of tunnels.

They were a nasty lot, especially at the speed we were traveling. He chose a tunnel in which to pass the Cortina, horn-blasting trucks, cars, and road graders out of our path, veering to the wrong side of a roadworks sign through what felt like thick mud. Later, we discovered we’d churned through wet cement.

Our first “selective” test was a regular run over roads open to the public, with the exception that we had to clock in to the exact second on our due minute, with a penalty point for every second late. I looked at the rally computer as we were flagged off, and there were no mileage readings. Striling looked at his gauges,  and there was no odometer. We looked at each other and swore in our native tongues. Nothing could be worse, we thought. It could.

We had to drive fifty-five kilometers through small villages, negotiate the Passo di Vivione, and descend to Borno. It was another slash back and forth through the mountains, and on the way up to Vivione, we passed leader Chatham’s Austin-Healey stuffed into the mountainside. He waved, and I felt a twinge. Paddy’s autograph jinx.
I didn’t have time to worry. We had our own problems. Stirling tapped the temperature gauge with his finger. The needle was spun completely around. He patted the steering wheel.

“Good old girl,” he said, coaxing her up the mountain. We expected the ride down to cool the engine, but the needle stayed pegged. A well by the side of the road caught Stirling’s eye, and he pulled off. There were two wine jugs, and I filled them as Stirling wrenched the radiator cap free. We poured the water in and then checked under the car. There was no leak. There was no water coming from the exhaust. We were stymied, and when the needle hit the peg again, we knew our problem was terminal.

Again we found a roadside well, and the radiator took all the water we could pour in. Mystified, downcast, we continued on in silence. We made it to our checkpoint on time and decided to wait for Ron Gammons, a few cars behind us, to have a look. The clerk of the course, famed navigator in his own right Fred Gallagher, looked under the hood with us.
“No fanbelt,” he said.

What a couple of bozos. Ron arrived and hooked up a new belt. Fred’s wife poured her drinking water into our radiator, and we were on our way, temperature needle settled at ninety, and Alpine Cup still intact.

We crossed the Passo di Croce Dominii, and it was one narrow donkey village after another back to Merano. With the demise of poor Chatham and Paddy (who continued, but in ninety-first place), we were now in third behind Henry Pearman’s E-type and the Lotus-Cortina of Piggy Thompson. Dron was three seconds back. Timo had moved up an astounding forty-four positions to twenty-second place.

pages.name: page4

pageElements.text:
Thursday

The rain that we had been praying for materialized as we climbed to the Passo di Monte Giovo. The road twisted up through dark pines, their new growth fluorescent against the gray sky. It was sprinkling as we descended into the fog-shrouded valley below.
“This is quite like the descent to Adenau at the Nurburgring,” observed Stirling.
Our speed picked up.
“Saving the brakes,” he said.

It would be a hard day of mountaineering—we faced the Passo di Pennes after the Monte Giovo, then the passi Lavaze, Rolle, Cereda, Duran, and Cibiana. The rain-slicked narrow roads really cheered Stirling, and the old stories came hot and heavy, in between downshifts, singing, and yelling in Italian at numerous road construction crews. One roadblock five kilometers from our checkpoint seemed particularly impassable. A big earthmover was in the middle of a major operation when Stirling began yelling at the foreman.

“Twenty minutes,” said the foreman in Italian, as Stirling hopped up and in the front of him. Back and forth the shouting went, when Stirling suddenly spun on his heel and hurried back to our car. He sailed past the long line of waiting traffic, inserted himself at the front of the line, yelled more out the window, and the machine miraculously dropped its load and backed out of the way.
“Heh-heh-heh,” laughed Stirling as he pushed the MGB around the sheer rock face that bordered the one-lane path.  “Oh, I love it!” We checked in on time.
Our only test for the day was another timed-to-the-second selective section, encompassing the last three passes. Two girls were hitchhiking from the summit of Cereda.
“Can you navigate?” Stirling yelled to them as we flew by. I socked him.
We followed the E-Type up the last major climb of the day—Cibiana.
“I don’t really want to pass him,” said Stirling, “but I have to get on my brakes to avoid hitting him in the corners.”
“Well, drop back then and save the brakes,” I said.
“Then again, if we push him, he might shunt,” said Stirling. “Hee-hee-hee.” He backed off and looked at me. “I’m a terrible sport.”
Not much farther on, we came upon the E-Type, parked at the side with a flat tire.
“Can we help?” asked Stirling, slowing. They waved us on.
As we waited for our exact second to roll up, the Jaguar came screaming into the checkpoint. On time.
“Oh, bugger!” said Stirling, “Bugger, bugger, bugger!”

Our gas station looked grim for the run into Cortina, so Stirling decided to coast down the mountain. The hairpins were a little tricky, but we rolled down at a fair clip, only slightly off the pace of the Triumph in front of us.
“It’s rather restful, isn’t it?” asked Stirling. “How far do you reckon we can coast?”

Not all the way to our checkpoint in Cortina, unfortunately. First we ran out of mountain, then fuel. Then we realized that our fuel filler was in the trunk, especially safe from vandals now that the trunk latch was broken. I ran like hell back down the road and waved Ron Gammons over as he came flying by. With a mighty whack of a very large hammer and screwdriver, he punched through the worthless lock, wrenched open our trunk lid, gave us a can of fuel, and sped off. Once again, we checked in on time.

pages.name: page5

pageElements.text:
Friday

There were no hill-climbs or special tests today, but one of those special selective sections, this one in Yugoslavia. We had come to realize that we couldn’t gain any position on these sections, only throw our Alpine Cup away, and we had come perilously close to doing so.

The sky was still heavy with rain when we left for Yugoslavia over the Dolomites, and the dark sky suited the Italian mountain villages. It also suited the mood of the E-type crew as it worked to change yet another flat tire, this one within yards of the day’s first checkpoint.

Kranjska Gora, just over the border into Yugoslavia, was swarming with British tourists, who swarmed Stirling while I changed five bucks into fifty zillion pazooties and bought us coffee that tasted like dirty socks.

Our selective was another horror, this time a hill-climb up twenty-four cobbled hairpins (open to the public), to the fabled Moistrocca summit. It was a busy day for the tourist bus trade; we passed seven going up and made it with twenty seconds to spare.

Back in Cortina d’Ampezzo, we washed our faithful mount as three ancient Italian crones in black sipped espresso nearby. One toddled over, handbag clutched over her arm, pointed to Stirling’s name on the side of the car, and pointed to my driver as he toweled the car. I nodded; she beamed and pulled a camera from her bag.

Saturday

“I called my son last night,” said Stirling over breakfast. “I said, ‘Elliot, Daddy and Jeannie are lying third overall.’ He said, ‘Oh, Daddy! You’ll just have to try harder!’ Isn’t that cute?”

And we tried like hell, beginning our last circuit of the Dolomites with the Giau hill-climb. We turned the same time as the second-place Cortina, while the Jaguar (which had suffered three flats the day before) played safe. Timo blew us all in the weeds, climbing from seventeenth place to seventh in the process. We maintained our slim lead over Tony Dron’s MGB, but when Piggy told us that he had rejetted the Cortina’s carburetor, we knew it would take a miracle to better our position. Before ten in the morning, we had climbed four major mountain passes over icy roads, past waterfalls, and above the clouds that sunk over jagged peaks into the valleys below. Passo di Sella lay more than a dozen hairpins up another of those roads guarded by thin wooden slats. We slid wide on the ice at one point, and Stirling got the MGB stopped against one of the worthless rails. We looked at each other, my breath coming a little faster.
“I thought we were going to nudge it” was all he said as he backed away and roared on.

We had one test left: the climb from Lago di Misurina up to Tre Cime di Lavaredo. Everyone’s last chance, and everyone took it. The top three teams—the Jaguar of Henry Pearman and Gordon Cruickshank, Piggy Thompson and Eddie Ganderton in the Cortina, and our stalwart MGB—turned identical times and finished the rally one-two-three. The Bees’ Knees won the team prize, with Ron Gammons finishing sixth and son Malcolm in fifteenth. We had won our cups.

But Timo Makinen was the real hero of the day, delivering another blistering performance in his mighty Austin-Healey that edged him, finally, into sixth place overall. The BBC interviewed him at the finish. “What was it like getting back into the old Healey?” they asked.
“Well, it were very hard to get back into,” joked the now-rotund Finn.
And the other stories rolled around us as we stopped for a barbecue in the spitting snow.
Roger Clark had cracked a raw egg into his radiator to plug a leak.
Kate Manley-Tucker had to back up her 1948 Allard M-type nine times on the Stelvio’s hairpins.
Paddy Hopkirk, the world’s largest manufacturer of gas cans, had run out of gas with no spare fuel aboard.
So had Henry Pearman in the winning Jaguar. And the team battling him for the lead, Piggy Thompson and Eddie Ganderton, stopped and gave him fuel.
We had only to check in at Cortina to finish, an anticlimactic run back to town.
“Well done, old girl,” said Stirling.
“Well done, Stirling,” I replied.
Henry Pearman and Gordon Cruickshank beamed as they blew champagne out over the crowd surrounding the finish line. Stirling and I waved from our perch on the roof of the MGB.
“We need an E-type for next year,” he said.

title: Bring Your Bike Along for the Ride
subTitle: Are you ready to spring for a bike rack?
promoTitle: Bring Your Bike Along for the Ride
promoTeaserSmall: Three ways to carry your bicycle on (or in) your car.

metaDescription: Bring Your Bike Along for the Ride: Here are three ways you can carry bicycles and other active-lifestyle gear in or on your car. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Say you’ve got a serious love for biking but don’t love the hassle of getting your bike from your house to the trails—what are your options for transporting your two-wheeler? It’s the conundrum of urban-dwelling outdoor enthusiasts and weekend-warrior triathletes everywhere. We’re here with a few tips to help your car and your bike get along like old friends.

Roof Rack?

Roof racks are standard equipment for seasonal sport lovers from skiers to kayakers, and bikers are no exception. They’re not universal, so you’ll have to put a little effort into finding one that fits your vehicle. On the bright side, you will be able to fit several bikes on top of your car and won’t have to compromise on interior cargo space.

Standby brands Thule and Yakima have guides on their websites that will point you toward the right rack for your car. You’ll likely have to buy mounts and crossbars before you buy the attachment to fit a bike, so buying a roof rack can end up costing several hundred dollars. But once you’ve got a roof rack, you can buy attachments to carry all kinds of gear, so you won’t have to pay for a whole new setup to switch from carrying bikes to carrying snowboards.

Rear Bike Rack?

If your problem with roof racks is that they’re too high off the ground for you to work with, but you’re not fundamentally opposed to strapping bikes to the outside of your car, a rear bike rack could be the answer. These essentially come in two flavors: the cheap universal kind that you strap to the trunk, and the more expensive, more durable hitch-mounted carriers. In both cases, your bikes will be easier to load and unload than when using a roof rack.

Trunk-mounted carriers are less of a commitment than hitch-mounted setups, but since they attach directly to a car’s body panels, they can cause paint damage. Their nylon straps aren’t terribly durable, either (and can be easily sliced by bike-jackers). Hitch-mounted carriers require a vehicle with a towing hitch and are more expensive than the trunk-mounted variety, but they also tend to be sturdier and easier to load. Both types of carriers can be purchased to handle multiple bikes.

Hatchback or Giant SUV?

If you’re really committed to easy bike transport, you can look for a car that will fit bikes in the cargo hold comfortably. Admittedly, this narrows your vehicle choices somewhat, but owning a car with ample cargo space can be useful even when your bike isn’t along for the ride. Large SUVs or vans are the obvious choice for transporting bikes, but hatchbacks can have just as much cargo space with the seats down, can get better fuel economy, and are typically cheaper than full-size SUVs. Transporting a bike inside your vehicle can offer a little more security from theft or damage and won’t affect your car’s ability to go through a drive-through the way a loaded roof rack can.
What’s your preferred method of bike transportation? Let us know in the comments below.

title: Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG Hits the Beach
subTitle: Just enough excess
promoTitle: Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG Hits the Beach
promoTeaserSmall: Just enough excess
promoTeaser: A dream sequence starring the stellar G-wagen and sun-drenched Miami Beach. You're welcome!
keywords: Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG Hits the Beach
metaTitle: Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG Hits the Beach - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG Hits the Beach
metaDescription: Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG Hits the Beach is a short, sweet tale of driving the legendary Gelandewagen on the streets of Miami and South Beach. It's on  JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: You are headed for Miami Beach: the land of the well tanned, the opulent, and the Art Deco style. You have decided that for this occasion, you’d like to play dressup in a vehicle that doesn’t quite fit your everyday persona. You’ve spotted the Mercedes-Benz G63 AMG in pictures, but the shimmery white exterior on your model strikes you as particularly well suited to the South Beach strip along Collins Avenue, where the regular work week feels nonexistent and the traffic crawls along with a constant “look at me” exclamation on a Wednesday afternoon.

Mercedes-Benz calls this shade Arctic White, but you think it should be called Fourteen-Carat Diamond, with all the sparkle in the sunshine. Some would opt for a convertible in South Beach, but you think that’s passé. The point is to be both exclusive and inaccessible, and the G63 fills the bill. Admit it: the G63’s speedy and powerful AMG package makes you want to play. The more outrageous, the better, you sing to yourself as you prepare to pull away in the hefty sport-utility vehicle, which costs a pretty $135,000 penny.

Hoist yourself up high into the black-leather cockpit and gaze down at the cars below. You’ve got an impressive list of technology at your fingertips, including mbrace2, the Mercedes-Benz concierge and assistance system. Crank the sonically superior Harman Kardon Logic 7 surround sound system, preferably to a satellite station with some sort of constant bass as a theme, and let the engine growl. In case anyone asks you what you’re working with, tell him your ride is equipped with a 5.5-liter biturbo engine that makes a whopping 535 horsepower.

But a word of caution: don’t bring up the gas mileage on the G63 AMG. Your guilty pleasure averages 12 mpg in the city. Ouch! But don’t worry—you don’t need to drive long or far to make your point. And luckily for you, you don’t have to test out the rain-sensing intermittent windshield wipers, either. There’s not a cloud in the sky as you open the sliding sunroof. You mean serious beach business.

title: GM Signs Climate Change Declaration
subTitle: Does this change how you see GM?
promoTeaserSmall: General Motors looks to set a good sustainability example among auto companies.
promoTeaser: General Motors looks to set a good sustainability example among auto companies.
metaTitle: GM Signs Climate Change Declaration - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: GM Signs Climate Change Declaration, the first automaker to do this. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
How much should auto companies show they care about global warming? That's a question that may come up more, now that General Motors has become the first automaker to sign the Business for Innovative Climate and Energy Policy (BICEP)’s Climate Declaration.

GM inked the agreement last week and becomes one of forty other major U.S. companies to endorse the declaration.

Is this mere lip service? Maybe. But it does take a stand, calling on businesses and policy makers to acknowledge climate change and address it by encouraging clean energy and efficiency and limits on carbon emissions. Many Americans now believe that climate change is happening and would like corporations and politicians to do more to address the issue. A statement like this could be a start.
The Climate Declaration isn’t specific about what should be done, but that hasn’t stopped dozens of companies—ranging from Nestle to Intel—from signing on.

GM Is an Early Adopter on This Stuff

This isn’t the first we’ve heard from GM about climate change and sustainability. In March, GM CEO Dan Akerson called on President Obama to form a blue-ribbon commission to develop a long-term policy framework for energy security. Mike Robinson, GM’s vice-president of sustainability and global regulatory affairs, has said that he wants GM to be an agent of change in the automotive industry, boasting that the automaker is “at the forefront of changing the way we move.” And GM listed what it has already done and plans to do about the issue in its first Sustainability Report in 2012.

images.caption: 2014 Chevrolet Spark EV
2014 Chevrolet Cruze Diesel
2014 Cadillac ELR (shown here in cold-weather testing)

pageElements.text: Then, of course, there are GM’s green vehicles. The extended-range plug-in Chevrolet Volt (shown above using a solar charging station) will be joined by the fully electric Chevrolet Spark EV this summer and a diesel-powered Cruze this fall. The Cadillac ELR, which shares the Volt’s extended-range technology, will hit showrooms next year.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: 2013 Nissan Juke SL AWD CVT
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Fl1JmDI0j-c?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Vital Stats

Base price: $19,780 for 2013 Juke S FWD, the base model; $26,780 for base Juke SL AWD CVT (prices include destination)
This car: $28,405 (includes destination). This car’s price reflects three options: carpeted floor mats and cargo mat ($180), center armrest ($245), Midnight Edition package with seventeen-inch black alloy wheels, black mirror covers, black rear roof spoiler ($1,200)
EPA fuel economy: 25 mpg city/30 mpg highway (with 188-hp 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine, linked to a continuously variable transmission)
Standard safety features: Six airbags, ABS, vehicle stability control, traction control
Chief competitors: Honda CR-V ($23,625 for LX; $31,125 for EX-L AWD with Navi), Kia Sportage ($19,850 for base model; $29,250 for Sportage X), Toyota RAV4 ($24,145 for LE; $27,855 for Limited); all prices include destination

Key Points

- The Juke is one of the smallest crossovers on the market and not the most utilitarian in the class
- The 2013 Juke is largely carryover, with the exception of the Midnight Edition package that is available on S, SV, and SL models (and is shown in the video)
- Bargain hunter alert: Prices have just been cut, as of May 3, upward of several hundred dollars, depending on trim level
- Review after review calls its radical styling “ugly.” I disagree
- The Juke is aimed at those who might also shop for a Mazda 3, Scion tC or Mini Cooper; Nissan says its design was inspired by motorcycles and rally cars
- It is affordable, especially up against the Honda CR-V and the Toyota RAV4
- But it requires premium gasoline!
- Rear seats will be out of the question for most adults, plus cargo space is minimal
If you need more space, the Mazda CX-5 might be a better choice, since it’s a lot more roomy and offers the same athletic handling
- Optional manual transmission cannot be bundled with optional all-wheel drive, which may annoy purists
- Rear-view monitor is newly added to the navigation package on SV models
- A revised Rockford Fosgate ecoPUNCH audio system is added to the SV navigation package and is standard on SL models
- Three new colors: Atomic Gold, Brilliant Silver, and Pearl White

pageElements.text: Speed bumps are like broccoli: they’re a good thing, a healthy thing, and yet they suck. You know why there are speed bumps in parking lots and in residential areas. They exist to make cars slow down when going through a neighborhood like the one shown here. But what’s the best way to manage them? Should both wheels go over together, or should you maneuver your car to go over the bump at an angle?
You know you can’t just cruise over them at 30 mph, not if you want to protect your car and keep from breaking your teeth. Here’s our handy guide to the best way to handle those humps.
Slowing down allows your vehicle to have full suspension travel, and that will avoid damage and that terrible jarring feeling.

1. Slow down. The whole point of a speed bump is to get you to moderate your speed, usually through a neighborhood or in a parking lot. Treat speed bumps the same way you treat railroad tracks and big potholes. They all require full suspension travel to go through with the minimum amount of jostle and damage to your car. Slowing down allows your vehicle to have full suspension travel, and that will avoid damage and that terrible jarring feeling.

2. Approach the speed bump at an angle. Maneuver one wheel to the side first, and come at the bump at an angle. Then, as you come over the bump, turn slightly in the other direction to go over the bump diagonally. This will minimize the damage and disruption to the underside of your vehicle.

3. Slam on the brakes. No, seriously. If you find yourself coming up on a speed bump unexpectedly, don’t keep going at full speed. That will make the underside of your car go “blammo” onto the speed bump. Not pleasant. So when you brake, really brake hard—enough so that you have almost stopped before you reach the speed bump. Then…

4. Foot off the brake and let your vehicle gently traverse the speed bump. Right before you get to the speed bump, take your foot off the brake, let your shocks recover, and smoothly go over the bump. Your vehicle will again have full suspension travel, which is just what you need for a smooth crossing.

metaDescription: Tesla Motors repays Uncle Sam early, paying back its Department o fEnergy loan nine years ahead of schedule. Read our commentary on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Elon Musk, co-founder and CEO of electric-car startup Tesla Motors, is a man who loves big announcements. He teases big Tesla news from his Twitter account regularly and occasionally has to bump major announcements for other, more major announcements. But we’ll give him a break this time, because yesterday’s Tesla news was genuinely big. The carmaker announced late on Wednesday that it has wired nearly half a billion dollars to the United States government, repaying the remainder of its $465 million Department of Energy loan nine years early.

The $451.8 million payment was funded by the company’s decision to sell additional shares of its stock after glowing reviews of the Model S (right) sent stock prices through the roof. Musk, the billionaire founder of space technology company SpaceX and co-founder of PayPal, purchased $100 million of the stock himself. This isn’t the first time he has shown his willingness to support Tesla personally. In April, Musk announced that he would back the Model S’s residual value guarantee with his personal checkbook, a move we can’t quite imagine from any other CEO.

In the announcement, Tesla claimed that it was the first American carmaker to repay its government loans in full. This prompted an indignant blog post from Chrysler, reminding us all that Chrysler’s loans were repaid in full in 2011, also ahead of schedule.

images.caption: Elon Musk (center) celebrates Tesla Motors' NASDAQ debut in 2010.
Uncle Sam poses with the Tesla Model S.
Elon Musk couldn't resist a coy Tweet.
Model S is the reasonably priced Tesla, starting at $62,400.

title: 2013 Honda Civic Si
subTitle: Should you buy this car?
promoTeaserSmall: This sporty Civic really brings out the boy racer in me. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: This sporty Civic really brings out the boy racer in me. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Civic Si undergoes my real-world review as I answer the question, Should you buy this car? It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $25,005 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.4-Liter DOHC 16-valve i-VTEC four-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Rearview camera, Bluetooth hands-free link, USB audio interface, side curtain airbags with rollover sensor, Pandora Internet radio interface, fold-flat rear seats
Option(s) I can’t live without: XM Satellite radio (free for the first three months)

What I Think:

The Honda Civic is well known as the kind of car that a non-car-loving person would go for. It's affordable, reliable, and predictable. Let's face it: it's kind of dull.

That's why I wanted to try out the Si, the sporty version of the Civic. And in fact, I found out that it is perfect for a buyer who wants the reliability of Honda but craves more performance. Is that you?

To be honest, I generally steer away from manual transmissions, so I was apprehensive about recommending a manual as a daily driver. After lots of shifting on quick trips around town, I have a solid opinion.

From the moment I first sat in the driver’s seat of the Civic Si, it had my attention. The interior was obviously designed for a boy racer, from the red-and-black styling to the emphasis on power and performance. The dash has been split into two: the closer dash is dominated by the RPM readout. The second showcases, in a clean layout, everything from a graph that tracks your progress through the gears to a large digital display of your speed, as well as a multi-system display that shows the vehicle stats including personal information like text messages and the current song on Pandora. (Oddly, the fuel indicator shows full on the left and empty on the right.)

I was disturbed by the split dash and struggled to make it fit with my driving position; the steering wheel was blocking the lower dash. I had a hard time finding the steering wheel adjuster and bemoaned the lack of a more comprehensive seat adjuster. But once I found the steering wheel adjuster I became a fan of the clean split-dash design. The interior is wrapped in a highly textured black fabric—that is somewhat distracting —and a nice red contrasting stitching.

The Verdict:

The six-speed manual transmission obviously dictates that the driver is a fan of a sportier ride, so the automatic lover needs to stick with the standard Civic model. As I mentioned, I tend to prefer an automatic myself; however, sometimes it is fun to unleash the boy racer inside me. The Si shifted smoothly and was fun to drive, and the digital readout assisted me in getting the most out of the engine. I would definitely recommend test driving the Si if you are looking at Civics.

Besides, this car had me at integrated Pandora radio. The sporty interior and split dash coupled with the six-speed make this a no-brainer for the buyer who is looking for a less expensive performance ride.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie: I couldn’t get past the garish interior.
Christina: The manual transmission is a problem, but I'd definitely buy it if I could drive it. It's a good, reliable car, and since it's an Si, it will be fun to drive. (Plus, I already drive a Honda, and I love it.)
Laura: This would be the Civic I'd buy my teenagers, but I'd probably get the "normal" one for my boring self.
Scott: I only buy Hondas because my neighbor sells used ones. But this one lost me at manual transmission.
Jean: I like everything about the Civic Si, but then, you would expect that of me. Right out of the box, when I saw the gauges and the new interior, I was excited, and I love that six-speed. It shifts like rich creamery butter. It's the perfect stick to use to learn how to drive a manual. (Any time, Scott. I'm waiting.)

pageElements.text: I’ve never smashed someone’s car window to rescue an overheated dog inside. Not that I wouldn’t; I’ve just not been in that position, thankfully. No numbers exist on the thousands of animals that suffer and die every year from being overheated inside cars parked by oblivious owners. It is truly tragic. Tragic and preventable.

I’m especially sensitive to the subject because we have especially thick-coated Chesapeake Bay retrievers, one of whom (Bob, at right) spends a lot of time at outdoor dog shows in the summer. We quickly learned how to create the best environment for Irish’s GCH Robert Garcia de Padua (short of keeping him in an air-conditioned motorhome like his better heeled competition has been seen enjoying) to endure a long day outside, waiting for his few minutes of ring glory.
First we arrive early enough to find the shadiest spot. Barring that, we create shade with a pop-up awning we erect to cover the back of the vehicle and our camping chairs.
We open all of the windows and throw a reflective mesh netting over the windshield and two front doors. This beats back the sun’s rays while allowing breezes to blow through.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/BCVh36ykv7U?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJDBKK4xQsBeRQm1nY0FMAyv" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

After an exhaustive search of portable fans, we settled on four large Ryobi fans with built-in stands and hooks that allow two of them to be hung directly on Bob’s cage. The two others are spares waiting with fresh batteries at the ready if the first fans die out. The Ryobi fan’s battery is huge and snaps directly into the back of the fan. Just to be even more anal about our precious pooch, we have a Ryobi charger that works off the car’s cigarette lighter.

The last thing is bringing a small cooler full of mostly ice, preferably made at home from the water that Bob’s delicate system is used to. He drinks directly from the cooler, the same way most dogs drink directly from the toilet. So, of COURSE we put his name on it in indelible ink. (This is Bob's friend Bizee at right.)

Seriously, though, think twice before you “just run in the dry cleaner for a second” and leave Scruffy waiting in the car. As I say in the video, temperatures can go skyhigh in a shockingly short amount of time.
We really want to hear your tips. Please share them with us here!

images.caption: Irish’s GCH Robert Garcia de Padua, a.k.a. Bob
Bizee samples the melted ice in Bob's cooler.
Bizee keeps cool.

title: 2014 Buick LaCrosse
promoTeaserSmall: I think sedan shoppers should give this nice car a chance. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I think sedan shoppers should give this nice car a chance. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: Should you buy the 2014 Buick LaCrosse? My dad and I think you should give it a chance, but what about the peanut gallery? Find out on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $47,295 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Power rear sunshade, rear-view camera
Options I can’t live without: Plethora of safety features including forward collision alert, lane change alert, lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert (Driver Confidence I package, $2,125); tasteful leather and synthetic suede interior plus real wood trim (Tamo ash) (Ultra Luxury package, $2,495)
You might also be considering: Acura TL, Chrysler 300, Kia Cadenza, Lexus ES350, Lincoln MKZ, Nissan Maxima, Toyota Avalon
See more specs on the LaCrosse lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

I am a lifelong Michigander, so I am biased in favor of the traditional Big Three. Nevertheless, I am realistic. I know what “Buick” means to most people: “old man car.” (Except, of course, in China, where it’s a highly desirable brand that lifts all of General Motors with it.) But back here in Michigan, I wondered: How far in the direction of modern luxury did Buick take this face-lifted LaCrosse? Did the company go too far and alienate the base of retired guys who play a little golf? Or not far enough, and eliminate itself from competition with newer mid-luxury brands that are more attractive to modern shoppers?
To find out, I went to the source: my dad, whose garage contains a 2002 Buick LeSabre. Would he buy this car? Should you?

My dad is a card-carrying retired guy; he plays a little golf; he likes his Buick just fine. When I  pulled up in the 2014 LaCrosse, his first impression was favorable, and I can see why: the updated look of Buick’s luxury mid-size car starts at the slanty LED headlights and continues with the shiny nineteen-inch wheels (there’s a twenty-inch option, too, with the Premium 2 package). As for me, I like its looks, too, with one exception: the unfortunate Buick portholes may be traditional, but they’re style demerits as far as I am concerned. They age what is otherwise a pretty good-looking exterior.

On the inside, the seats are improved, legroom and interior space are great, and the interior is truly gorgeous. I wouldn’t normally say I would be into Sangria as a leather color for my car (or anything else), but it’s tasteful in the Buick. The model we tried came with the Ultra Luxury interior package (a $2,495 option), which includes real wood accents (that actually look like real wood), a sunroof, and attractively soft-looking synthetic suede headliner and trim.

We climbed in. “There’s no way Shaq fit inside here,” my dad had to say. I watched that commercial, too, and if you call the way he squashed into the car “fit,” Shaq did. But I try never to argue with my dad! The seats are supportive and comfortable, not squashy. I especially approve of the wide cupholder console that opens up in the center of the back seat, for when you are carrying two instead of three back there. Almost (almost!) kid friendly, but you wouldn’t want them spilling their juice boxes on these seats.

Perhaps in a nod to the older, less tech-savvy customer base—and perhaps just because it’s the right thing to do—the LaCrosse’s instrument panel and controls are laid out in a clear, intuitive way, with an eight-inch information screen. There’s a height-adjustable head-up display, now in color, and I’m a big fan of those for how they cut distraction while driving. The IntelliLink infotainment system is newly upgraded and made its debut at the New York Auto Show this spring; I had no trouble figuring it out.
Aside from the V-6 version I drove, the 2014 LaCrosse is available in an eAssist mild hybrid with a four-cylinder engine. You can also get a four-wheel-drive version, but only with the V-6.

The LaCrosse’s safety features are bang up to date. Side blind zone alert, forward collision alert, lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, adaptive cruise control, a backup camera…I love all of that, and I would love to see my dad driving a car with all of those justly lauded safety features on it. They are part of a Driver Confidence package (a $2,125 option); there’s also a $1,745 Driver Confidence II package that adds adaptive cruise control and a driver's safety alert seat.

Speaking of which: I was driving down narrow West Huron Street in Ann Arbor, having very positive feelings about the liveliness, comfortable ride, and even (can I say this about a Buick?) agility of the LaCrosse, when…bazinga! A vibrating feeling in my left thigh that about made me jump out of my skin. Did I trigger the weight limit on the side bolsters or what? It took a few minutes to register, then I realized it was the famous Safety Alert Seat that’s a GM exclusive. It jiggles the side of your leg when you stray too close to the edge of the lane. Too far to the left? A left jiggle. The right? A right jiggle. An appreciated, if squicky-feeling, safety feature. So much more tolerable than an annoying chime sound. I prefer the way Mercedes-Benz’s Active Lane Keeping Assist alerts you, by vibrating the steering wheel—a more dignified place to jiggle a person, in my opinion.

The Verdict:

Not to put too fine a point on it, but you can buy a lot of car in the $47,000 range. You can get a Lexus ES, an Audi A4, or a Volvo S60, and probably a lot of mid-luxury shoppers will. For a few thousand more, you’re in Mercedes-Benz E-Class territory. It is important to mention, though, that the base 2014 LaCrosse starts at $34,060, including destination. That one has a 2.4-liter four-cylinder and much better fuel economy (25 mpg in town and 36 mpg on the highway), although you can also get the V-6 at no additional charge over the four. If my dad actually shocked the family by deciding to replace his LeSabre with a new car, that’s the one he would get. His verdict was, "I'd consider this new Buick if I were still driving long distances like when I used to go down to Florida. Now I mainly just go over to the grocery store."

If somebody is already interested in the Buick brand, this is one impressive Buick. I’m not sure it will excite the person who is also looking at the Lexus ES, though. But let me sound like my dad for a minute and offer you a word of advice: Get over your Buick bias and at least try this, if you’re shopping for a sedan in this price range.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: This is a car for Mr. Spock: everything is logical. The buttons and readouts are large and conveniently placed. It appears that the user's experience was the guiding principle when the interior was designed. I especially liked how the window control panel on the door is tilted so the driver can see the buttons easily. The passenger's-side A-pillar combined with the large dash created an enormous blind spot. I felt like right turns required a leap of faith, which is a deal breaker for me.

Christina: This car was just what I expected it to be: comfortable to drive, easy to use, and spacious without being overwhelming. Speaking of being overwhelmed, I was particularly pleased that the center stack wasn't filled with oodles of buttons and switches that required a consult with the owner's manual in order to use. The temperature was easy to adjust and it was easy to switch from the satellite radio to the AM/FM radio and back again. Just press the radio button. It's as simple as that.

Scott: In this car, I felt as if the windshield was farther away from me than in other sedans I've driven in the past. In driver ed, they tell you to look twelve seconds ahead of your vehicle to maintain a safe distance between your car and the one in front of you. Driving the LaCrosse, I felt that I had to look twenty-four seconds ahead.

Annie: The first thing I noticed about the LaCrosse was its extremely high beltline and teeny, tiny windows. They look fine from the outside, but from the driver's seat it can feel like you're sitting in a hole. An attractive hole, but not one with great visibility. I'll admit I wasn't expecting to like the LaCrosse and was for the most part pleasantly surprised by it. But even if Buick keeps building interesting cars, they've got a long way to go before they've solved their branding problem.

title: EV Prices Unplugged
promoTeaserSmall: Interested in going electric, but stopped by the MSRP? Check out price cuts from major EV makers.
promoTeaser: Interested in going electric, but stopped by the MSRP? Check out price cuts from major EV makers.
metaDescription: EV Prices Unplugged! Check out price cuts on 2014 hybrids and EVs that might make you more willing to consider a purchase. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Depending on whom you believe, electric cars might be the wave of the future. Ten years from now, we could all be driving battery-powered cars. But right now, many buyers are still nervous about making the switch to an electric vehicle. Of course, plenty of drivers are turned off by short driving ranges and long charge times. Another problem is that electric and hybrid electric vehicles often carry multi-thousand-dollar price premiums over their gasoline counterparts, which are hardly big selling points for buyers.

Faced with lackluster demand, several automakers are offering price cuts on their electric vehicles to sway buyers who might be on the fence. But how close will the discounts get you to the price of a gasoline-powered car? Here’s a rundown of manufacturers' deals on electric vehicles and how they compare with what you'd pay for their gasoline counterparts. All prices include destination.

Fiat 500e

The Fiat 500e is available to lease for three years for $199 per month after a $999 down payment. If you’re looking to buy, the 500e will set you back $32,600. Fiat offers the same lease deal for the 500 Pop, the base version. Lessees of the 500e may be on the better end of that deal, since the 500e has a standard aftermarket navigation system and automatic climate control; only the standard navigation system is available on the 500 Pop.

Ford Focus Electric

Ford is the most recent automaker to slash prices on its electric vehicle, reducing the price of the Focus Electric by $4,000 for 2014. That corresponds to a price cut of nearly ten percent. The price cut brings the base price of the car down from $39,995 to $35,995. By way of comparison, the similarly equipped Ford Focus Titanium starts at $24,910.

Honda Fit EV

Honda dropped the monthly payment on a Fit EV lease by more than $100 in June. Honda has eliminated the down payment and added a home charging station to the three-year lease deal, although lessees will have to pay for installation of the charging station. The Fit EV’s warranty will include unlimited mileage, routine maintenance, and collision coverage. The Fit Sport with navigation and the Fit EV have similar features, but the Fit Sport starts at $20,580. The quoted MSRP of a Fit EV is $36,625; with destination, the price comes to $37,415.

Nissan Leaf

The Nissan Leaf starts at $29,650 for the base model, and Nissan has a three-year lease deal with a $1,999 down payment and a $199 monthly payment. There isn’t a gasoline-powered counterpart to the Leaf, so there’s no way to say for sure how much electrification adds to the Leaf’s cost.

All of these cars qualify for a $7,500 federal tax credit and may qualify for additional state and local tax incentives, depending on where you live. In some cases these credits can take the price of a car down by as much as $10,000, which goes a long way towards closing the price gap between the gasoline and electric versions of the cars.

Even with these incentives, it’ll still be a while before you see EVs on every street corner. Honda is only planning to lease about 1,100 of its Fit EVs over a two-year period, and Ford has sold fewer than 2,000 Focus Electrics since they went on sale last year. The Nissan Leaf has made huge sales gains in the last year but still accounts for just a tiny fraction of Nissan’s car sales.
What do you think? Will price cuts make EVs an accessible technology upgrade or are they still out of reach?

Ford Focus Electric
