title: A Girl and Her Jeep
promoTeaserSmall: I was born a car designer's daughter, but my 2003 Jeep Liberty is perfect for my high-school life.
promoTeaser: I was born a car designer's daughter, but my 2003 Jeep Liberty is perfect for my high-school life.
metaTitle: A Girl and Her Jeep - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Girl and Her Jeep: A high-school student has a challenging time but still appreciates her 2003 Jeep Liberty. Read her story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I suppose that if you hit a mailbox and destroy your mother’s Chevrolet Equinox one month after receiving your driver’s license, you are not entitled to a luxurious first car. So, when my parents surprised me with a battered blue 2003 Jeep Liberty, I had no complaints. The rusting Jeep came complete with tattered seatbelts, coffee-stained cupholders, and the perpetual stink of cigarette smoke. She was no Ferrari, but she had a sunroof, I had a license, and we were going to taste freedom until our taste buds went numb. But first, I had to name her, and this car was a Britney if ever I saw one.

My daily seven hours of school and three hours of swim practice really limited where Brit and I traveled, and soon we almost exclusively had three destinations: home in Bloomfield Hills, Notre Dame Preparatory School in Pontiac, and the natatorium at Waterford Kettering High School. En route to these various locations, Brit developed a stalling problem. After an abrupt stop, her engine would grumble. When I tried to accelerate, she would refuse to move. My car enthusiast father (who designed the 2003 Liberty when he worked at Chrysler) assured me that it was nothing to worry about and advised me to simply put the Jeep in park, kill the engine, and then restart it. I mastered this little maneuver, and my confidence in Brit never wavered.

On Halloween 2012, I certainly wished my confidence in Brit had wavered a bit. Every Halloween, the Notre Dame Preparatory swim team dresses up together, and this past year, Team America was the theme. While the freshmen timidly applied red, white, and blue temporary tattoos to their cheeks and carefully tied ribbons in their hair, I threw caution to the wind and painted the American flag across my entire face. My blue tights, red shorts, and homemade U.S.A. T-shirt really pulled the ensemble together. Go big or go home, right?

After a long day of patriotism and attempts to stay awake during classes, I walked out of school under an angry-looking sky. The downpour soon began, and traffic quickly clogged the roads. I sat waiting at a red light on my way to practice in Waterford, and when the light changed and I pressed down on the accelerator, nothing happened. This was standard Brit behavior and did not really faze me. But when the engine refused to turn over after I performed my quick fix, I panicked and resorted to Plan B: call my dad. I made my way across the street in the pouring rain and tried to ignore the less-than-friendly hand gestures of the drivers behind me.

A police car soon arrived to find a very frazzled sixteen-year-old girl with a now-dripping American flag painted across her face, waiting in an abandoned Tubby’s parking lot. The officer was clearly having a hard time taking me seriously as I explained the situation. When he asked to speak to a parent, I handed him my iPhone, which was unfortunately covered in a yellow bunny case complete with ears and a fluffy tail. He did not succeed in stifling a laugh. My father and the officer straightened the situation out, and a tow truck came to the rescue and removed my Jeep from the congested road. My heart ached at seeing my beloved Britney on the hook.

To my delight, Britney’s only problem was her battery! After a few days in the shop, I picked her up, and the dynamic duo was reunited. She has displayed model behavior since that fateful day, and our destinations have expanded to include the Twist 'N Dip, a shacklike ice cream shop in downtown Auburn Hills where I now work. On my seventeenth birthday, Brit and I received a Life Is Good tire cover. It could not be more appropriate, because when I’m driving her, life really is good.

About Annie Boniface: I am seventeen years old and going to be a high-school senior this fall. After a year of AP Composition, I realized I really enjoyed writing and would perhaps want to pursue a career in it. When I announced my interest in journalism, my dad immediately suggested I visit Jean. (My dad, the epitome of the car guy, has a detached garage brimming with old Alfas, spends questionable amounts of time tinkering on sickly engines, and works as a designer for General Motors.) Apart from being a new fan of writing, I am on the varsity swim and tennis teams, volunteer at a hospital, and work at the Twist 'n Dip.

title: Car Insurance Fail!
promoTeaserSmall: Beware of flying tires—and the fine print on your insurance policy. I learned the hard way.
promoTeaser: Beware of flying tires—and the fine print on your insurance policy. I learned the hard way.
metaDescription: Car Insurance Fail! Read your insurance policy before a flying piece of tire hits you. I learned the hard way. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

promoLarge.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

promoSmall.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

header.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

homepage.title: beware of flying tires and the fine print

pageElements.text: I had just a split second to react as the snakelike retread spun off the wheel of the semitruck in front of me on I-275 in Michigan one recent afternoon.

Because my Honda CR-V was hemmed in on either side by other cars, I had little choice but to grip the steering wheel and plow into the huge piece of rubber at about 70 mph. It felt like hitting a chunk of concrete. The retread wound itself around my front tires, taking down the bumper and the wheel arch on the left side. I managed to get the car to the side of the road, my hands still shaking from the ordeal. Of course, the truck driver never stopped.

I was grateful that I was unhurt and that the tire tread didn’t smash into my windshield. My younger son was in the car with me at the time; he managed to disengage the rubber pieces and push the front end back into place temporarily. We immediately headed toward the local car dealership and put in a call to my insurance company.

An Interesting Way to Define "Accident"

I told the insurance company that a large piece of a tire from a semitruck had struck my vehicle. But that’s not how they interpreted the accident. According to their rules, the accident was my fault because I hit something while driving! Keep in mind that I live in Michigan, a so-called no-fault insurance state.

AAA, my insurance carrier, explained that since the accident was not the result of a collision with another vehicle, it fell under the comprehensive portion of my insurance policy, rather than the broad form portion. This is a critical distinction, since, if the accident fell under the latter, it would have meant the deductible would be waived. And, as it turns out, the deductible ran into the hundreds of dollars.

An Even More Interesting Way to Define "Damage"

The insurance company told me that if my vehicle had been damaged in a parking lot, even if I was not inside it at the time, the damage would have been covered and the deductible waived under the broad form section of the policy.
AAA said damage from flying tires is “always” covered under comprehensive, which means the owner must always pay the deductible.
When I threatened to cancel my policy and switch insurance carriers, I was told that this is “industry policy” and it would be pointless to make the change.

Since the accident, I have noticed that every highway I travel is littered with tires and the retreads from semitrucks. They serve as a constant reminder of how unfair this crazy policy is to consumers. It makes me double my effort to steer clear of the big rigs on the road.
The author has chosen to remain anonymous, but she wonders (and so do we), Have you looked at your own insurance policy recently? And do you think this is fair?

title: Bridgestone Racing Academy
promoTeaserSmall: My two glorious days in an open-wheel car on the track. Watch the video; you'll want to be next.
promoTeaser: My two glorious days in an open-wheel car on the track. Watch the video; you'll want to be next.
metaDescription: Bridgestone Racing Academy: I spent two days learning to drive an open-wheel Formula SCCA racing car on the Canadian Tire Motorsport Park driver development track. It was great! See the video and read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

relatedArticles.name: article0
relatedArticles.promoTeaser: I don't mind being beaten on the autocross circuit by a girl. OK, I do mind when it's all of them.
relatedArticles.title: Mean Jean's Humiliation

pageElements.text: The most common questions I get asked about my job as an automotive journalist are “Can you drive stick?” and “Are you scared?” The first (also the most common question men in bars ask when they find out I write about cars) has legitimate practical applications. The second is almost always asked when I’m behind the wheel of a fast car, and it completely baffles me. It has never occurred to me to be scared of driving fast. Poisonous spiders are what I’m scared of. Fast cars are what I dream about.

Most recently, the question was posed by Jean Knows Cars videographer Scott Allen while he was filming me from the pit lane of a driver development track. We were at the famous Canadian Tire Motorsport Park, outside Toronto, Ontario, where I was participating in Bridgestone’s two-day racing academy. At that precise moment, I was sitting behind the wheel of a tiny Formula SCCA open-wheel racing car, waiting for my first turn around the mile-long track.

I guess it was a fair question, though, since I was sitting just a few inches off the ground, with nothing but a helmet and a five-point harness to protect me if I sent my car spinning into a wall. Not that I was planning on that. I’d never driven an open-wheel car before, and I had resolved to spend my first few sessions on the track taking my time and familiarizing myself with the car. This strategy landed me squarely in the slower of the two groups of auto journalists, but I didn’t mind; I’ve always preferred exceeding low expectations to disappointing high ones.

Our cars were 1,000-pound rockets: Van Diemen Formula SCCA cars, with 2.3-liter, 170-horsepower engines capable of going from 0 to 60 mph in four seconds. The cars were fitted with Bridgestone's Potenza RE-11 performance tires, which can also be fitted to your street car. Our instructors said that top speeds for those cars on that track would top out around 70 to 80 mph, achievable on the long straight stretch just before the last, sharpest corner. In lieu of a speedometer, we had digital tachometers in the steering wheel, with a row of lights that glowed green in the power band between 4,500 and 6,500 rpm, then red as the engine neared redline.

I focused on hitting the apex cones at each corner and experimented with braking later and hitting the gas harder. We were driving in groups of three, following an instructor. I don’t have much experience on the track, so for the first few sessions I was glad to have a guide. But by the end of our first day, I was itching to circle the track at my own pace.

Day two brought with it unforgiving heat, with temperatures heading into the nineties. Not the kind of day you want to spend zipped into a full-body racing suit. With just a few hours left before my racing car turned into a pumpkin, though, I wasn't about to complain.

The instructors still went out on the course with us, but we weren't playing follow the leader anymore and could move at our own speed. And by the time lunch rolled around, we were on the track alone, and our laps were being timed.

If I was holding back before, letting my desire to perfect my technique overpower my love of pure speed, all it took was one look at my group's lap times to set me straight. I was the second slowest of our five-person group. Priorities rearranged, I got back in the car for our second set of timed laps.

This time, I pushed the car as hard as my skill would allow. I braked later, accelerated harder, and took the corners faster. On the back straightaway, where (we'd been warned during our first class) inexperienced drivers often got nervous and spun out, I pressed the accelerator flat to the floor. The car zoomed forward at what felt like a reckless speed, the wind lifting at my helmet, my heart pounding, my eyes wide.
Yes, that's what I've been looking for, I thought to myself. More of that, please.

My new attitude brought with it a new ranking, with my little racing car turning in our group's second-fastest lap during the second session. During our final timed session a spinout slowed me, and I fell back in our group's rankings, but I’d gotten what I came for. Two days on the track gave me my first performance driving experience, and I came away with a dose of speed strong enough to satisfy my lead foot for a while.

Your Turn!

Luckily, you don’t have to be a journalist to get access to a track. Bridgestone runs this two-day racing school every year to give auto journalists a chance to test the company’s high performance tires in a track setting (and the Potenza tires performed admirably, keeping me and my car squarely stuck to the track under very enthusiastic driving). But they also have sessions that you can sign up for.

Drivers can experience the Bridgestone Racing Academy in half-day, full-day, two-day, and three-day courses. All courses include time with an instructor and laps in one of the school’s open-wheel racing cars. Time on the track is directly related, as you might expect, to the price you pay. The half-day course costs $295 to $595 Canadian, and the most expensive three-day course earns drivers a racing license and costs $3,995 Canadian. Check out the details on the Bridgestone Racing Academy website, and don't miss the academy's Welcome Americans! page.

If Toronto’s too far to go to satisfy your craving for speed, don’t fret. There are plenty of racing and performance driving schools in the United States, too. A Google search should point you to nearby tracks, and then it’s just a matter of squirrelling away your extra cash until you can afford seat time.

title: 2013 Hyundai Veloster Turbo
promoTeaserSmall: This turbo hatchback has most of what I want in a car. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: This turbo hatchback has most of what I want in a car. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Hyundai Veloster Turbo: Should you buy it? I think this little hatchback is most of what I want in a car. The Peanut Gallery mainly concentrated on the $1,000 matte paint job. Read my review and their comments on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $25,020 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.6-liter turbocharged DOHC 4-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/35 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Seven-inch multimedia touchscreen
Option I can’t live without: Matte gray exterior paint ($1,000)
You might also be considering: Honda CR-Z, Mini Cooper, Scion tC
See more specs on the Veloster in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

I’ve liked the Hyundai Veloster since first I laid eyes on it. It has most of the things I want in a car: interesting looks, a hatchback body style, good gas mileage, a reasonable price, and a silly name. But the sub-$20,000 base model is also sub-140 horsepower, and I’d heard it wasn’t particularly fun to drive. But wait! The advent of the 2013 model year brought with it a turbocharged version, which kicks the base Veloster’s 138 horsepower and 132 pound-feet of torque up to 201 hp and 195 pound-feet of torque.
Problem solved? Only one way to find out.

I drove the Hyundai Veloster Turbo for a weekend, and, to be fair, I was hoping to be impressed. But I was also ready for the Veloster to disappoint, whether by proving impractically small or by failing to live up to the promise of its beefy engine upgrade. The Veloster was far from perfect. But by the end of my weekend, I found myself wishing I had more time in it—always a good sign.

Just by looking at it, you can tell that the Veloster is a little odd. It has an asymmetrical design, with two doors on the passenger's side and one on the driver’s side. The third door is unusual, but it’s undoubtedly helpful for passengers trying to climb in the back. The back seat is fairly roomy for a car this size, with enough head and leg room for my adult passengers.

Our Turbo came with a blue-trimmed interior that drew criticism from passengers, who thought it looked tacky. A more sophisticated driver would do better to opt for the gray interior trim instead. The standard touchscreen infotainment system is quick to respond and easy to use, and the Dimension Premium audio system (standard in Turbo models) can blast out your eardrums—and those of anyone standing nearby—if you turn it to eleven.

The Veloster Turbo’s exterior comes with a sporty body kit and a grille, both upgrades from the base model. It can also be had, as ours was, with Matte Gray paint. It’s a $1,000 option, and that matte finish requires a lot of special attention: you can’t run it through a car wash, and you must use special products when you hand wash it. But the Veloster looks great with a matte finish, and it turns heads everywhere you go.

A 201-horsepower engine might seem like overkill in a compact hatchback, but I thought it provided the Veloster with just the right amount of pep. The car steers and handles well and can accelerate with enthusiasm when pushed, but it doesn’t go so far into the realm of a hot hatch that you can’t imagine driving it every day. And with an EPA rating of 35 mpg on the highway, you don’t have to feel too guilty about choosing the Turbo model instead of the base Veloster (rated at 37 mpg highway).

The Verdict:

The Veloster is no family hauler, and rear visibility is limited. The trunk is surprisingly spacious but by no means large. The rear seat is adequate for occasional use, but it might not do if you’re driving kids around all day. But for the right type of person—young, unattached, and looking for a relatively affordable car that makes a statement—the Veloster could fit the bill. If you’re more concerned about cost than power, the base Veloster might be all you need. But with sixty-three extra horses just a few thousand dollars away, why not spring for the Turbo?

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: You say Veloster, I say Velociraptor. Like the wolf-size dinosaur, the Veloster will demand your attention. At just over $25,000, this is an economy sports car. The matte paint alone will sell this car to the demographic who would stand in line to buy a phone. The rear third door on the passenger's side, with its hidden handle, came as a complete surprise to me. I only discovered it, in fact, after my passenger had struggled through the front door to climb into the rear seat. We laughed so hard that we had missed it from the outside. Mystery lovers should buy this car for the hidden door alone.

Laura: I have to get this out of the way first: I love, love, love the $1,000 matte paint on this 2013 Veloster Turbo. I am aware that it is hard to take care of and easy to ruin, which is why I drove down the road feeling as vulnerable to damage as a person who has just put on gold-leaf nail polish. I also think Hyundai should put some sort of camera in the cabin so you could admire that handsome matte paint job while you're actually driving the car. But as for driving: I found the Veloster surprisingly easy to drive well (or believe I was driving well). It doesn't feel unpleasantly small on the road, power is more than adequate, and visibility is good. I'd definitely suggest it to anybody looking for a nimble, fun, out-of-the-ordinary car, especially to anybody who is enough of a hobbyist to enjoy taking care of the matte paint job. Hey, I got $1,000 worth of second looks in the first mile.

title: Dogs Get a Safety Boost from Subaru
promoTitle: Dogs Get a Safety Boost from Subaru
promoTeaserSmall: Going on now: Subaru/Center for Pet Safety car restraint tests with dog test dummies. Brilliant!
promoTeaser: Going on now: Subaru/Center for Pet Safety car restraint tests with dog test dummies. Brilliant!
metaTitle: Dogs Get a Safety Boost from Subaru - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Dogs Get a Safety Boost from Subaru: Subaru and the Center for Pet Safety are testing harnesses and car restraints using dog-shaped crash test dummies. Details and early photos are on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Here's some good news: Subaru has teamed with the nonprofit Center for Pet Safety, and together they are working on ways to ensure better safety in the car for dogs. The dog crash test dummy you see here is part of the good work they're doing. Subaru has just shared the photos with us while we wait for results of the testing that is ongoing now.

Dogs are kind of a big deal here at Jean Knows Cars. We own them, we love them, and we do everything we can to keep them safe in the car. But the sad truth is that even with restraints, when you put your dogs in the car, there are dangers for the dogs and for you. The good news: Subaru has partnered with the Center for Pet Safety to create standards for the testing of pet restraints.

As it turns out, even though there are plenty of dog harnesses and restraints on the market, but there’s no system in place to determine how well they actually work. In a pilot study last year, the Center for Pet Safety determined that most pet safety restraints on the market today “do not provide acceptable protection in a crash situation,” according to Subaru’s director of corporate communications, Michael McHale. And since there’s no existing standard, there also isn’t an easy-to-understand ratings system like NHTSA’s five-star designations to guide pet owners in their shopping.
But that could be about to change with the work Subaru is helping to make happen.

Why Subaru?

The automaker has a long history of dog friendliness and marketing to dog owners. “Subaru and Subaru owners have a shared love for our pets and safety,” explains corporate communications manager Sheriece Matias Dick. Remember the "Dog Tested, Dog Approved" ad campaign? The automaker has also previously sponsored many dog-related activities, from a day to honor military working dogs to a Pets on Vacation Photo Contest with the ASPCA humane organization. There's even an ad with the tagline, "Once you sit in a Subaru, you'll stay." So the partnership with the Center for Pet Safety is a good fit.

With Subaru’s help, the Center for Pet Safety has developed four different types of dog crash test dummies. These aren’t just stuffed animals, either. They’re weighted, instrumented dog-like dummies, ranging in size from twenty pounds (a terrier mix, CPS suggests) to seventy-five pounds (a golden retriever, perhaps). The dog dummies, covered in specialty tape, will be used to test the safety of different harnesses.

Subaru and CPS hope that creating a set of safety standards will not only help pet owners choose the safest harnesses, but will allow manufacturers to create better pet restraints going forward. They will announce the top-performing harness brands in October and will also add "an education component" to help people understand the importance and the technique of using a pet restraint in the car. We'll keep you updated!

title: The Tile, Your New Lost and Found
promoTitle: The Tile, Your New Lost and Found
promoTeaserSmall: Ambitious little square is the hub of an upcoming social network for finding your lost stuff.
promoTeaser: Ambitious little square is the hub of an upcoming social network for finding your lost stuff.
metaTitle: The Tile, Your New Lost and Found - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Tile finding device Tile iPhone app
metaDescription: The Tile, Your New Lost and Found: It's the Holy Grail. Attach this to anything, and an app locates it for you.

pageElements.text: Every once in a while, you come across something that you didn’t realize you wanted but now realize you must have. This small, simply but beautifully designed white electronic object should have been introduced on stage by a tall, rangy man wearing a black mock turtleneck and jeans. It wasn’t, but it looks good enough to have been. It’s the Tile low-energy Bluetooth device, it will find your stuff for you, and millions of people will be using at least one by next year at this time.

The inventors at Reveal Labs used a Selfstarter crowdsourcing campaign to raise the cash for the project, and they got $2.6 million worth of it. Almost 50,000 people have preordered the Tile, billed as “the world’s largest lost and found.” You can preorder yours, too (I did), but they won’t be out until winter 2013-14.

What it is:

The Tile is a little square with a battery you don’t have to charge or replace. (Tradeoff: The Tile only lasts a year and then has to be replaced.) It currently costs $18.95, with discounts if you buy several. It is compatible with iPhone/iPad/iPod devices, not Android or BlackBerry. It has a built-in speaker and works with an app.

What it does:

The Tile has a hole in it, so it can go on a key ring. It also comes with double-sided tape, and it attaches to whatever you want to keep from losing: anything from your wallet or keys to your bicycle. (I am thinking of putting one on each of my sons so I can find them, but I don’t know if I will be able to get away with it.) Then you use the app, which saves the GPS location of the Tile—and thus, the thing it’s attached to.

There’s a You’re Getting Warmer feature that shows you getting closer or farther away from the object when you’re within fifty to 150 feet of it. That's where they sold me: find my car keys that easily, without tearing up the whole house? Priceless. For bigger distances, the app saves the GPS location where the Tile was last seen. You can keep up to ten Tiles on your account, and you can share access to Tiles with other people who also have the app.

How it can help you:

The app will remember the last place your item was located, helping you keep from losing it. If you do lose an object that has the Tile on it, you can mark it as lost, and the Tile’s cloud servers send a GPS location to anybody else who also has the app so they can let you know they've spotted it, but not other information about you or the object you’ve lost. In this way, it’s intending to be a kind of social network for stuff. Seems too hard to make that work unless you really focus on setting up your own group of Tile users—but if you look at how many people rushed to invest by pre-ordering, maybe not.

You know my comment about how this could have been an Apple invention? The Tile’s Twitter feed, a few weeks ago, showed a photo of Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak holding the Tile prototype he just purchased.

The Tile
The Tile app
The Tile app

title: Outward Hound Dog Gear! Our Test
promoTitle: Outward Hound Dog Gear! Our Test
promoTeaserSmall: Great name, but how did we rate these comfort products for your dog in the car? Watch and see.
promoTeaser: Great name, but how did we rate these comfort products for your dog in the car? Watch and see.
metaTitle: Outward Hound Dog Gear! Our Test - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Outward Hound Dog Gear: Watch the Test. We test safety and comfort gear for small, medium, and large dogs in small, medium, and large cars. See the video and hear our verdicts on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Based on their name alone, I already liked Outward Hound's car products for dogs before I even saw them. In this video test, I got together small and medium friends and their small and medium dogs. Louie and I were the Big Dogs of the test. We tried four products in the Outward Hound lineup, which are made by Kyjen. All had their good points, but one thing the company stresses that I insist on, too, is that you must always attach dogs using a harness whenever they ride in the car with you. None of these products can be considered safe unless your dog is harnessed in. (See my previous video on how harnesses work to keep your dog safe.)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/8e6FDCK8BR0?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJDBKK4xQsBeRQm1nY0FMAyv" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
These are the products we tested and where to find them.

Outward Hound's Extend-A-Seat ($22.38) stretches across your vehicle's back seat so your dog doesn't jump or fall down into the floor of the car. It's intended for dogs over thirty pounds. There's a center "safety barrier" that is supposed to keep your dog from getting into the front seat, but that's a laugh; it wouldn't stop your average dog from simply pushing its way through to the front (or climbing right over the top). It does make the back seat into a single-level seating area, which is good, but if your dog is restrained with a harness, that will not be an issue anyway. The Extend-A-Seat has adjustable straps; it folds flat for storage when you're not traveling with a pet.

The Up & Lift Out Harness ($9.79) is for those of us with heavy dogs (fifty to ninety pounds), especially the old girls or boys who have trouble getting up into the back seat on their own. It's a nylon thing with Velcro-closing hand straps, and it is a lot less cumbersome than setting up a pet ramp. But, even using two hands, you need to be plenty strong to lift a dog into a high back seat with this sling, even a dog at the bottom of the weight range. And with no stabilizer strap across the chest, Louie almost slid right out of the sling.

The Back Seat Hammock Protector ($17.25) is just what it sounds like: a cover for your seat that doubles as a barrier to keep your dog comfortably seated in the back seat, not on the floor. It has slits to let you attach your dog's harness into the seatbelts, and there's Velcro so you can divide the barrier and leave one seat in the back available to a human passenger. I bought this for our Volkswagen Jetta at home, and I'm going to get another one for our Chevrolet Suburban.

The Booster Seat ($20.07-$25.21) raises a little dog up to window level, a plus when riding with a smaller dog (size Small fits dogs up to ten pounds; Medium fits up to twenty-pounders). It has adjustable straps that attach to the back seat and the headrest, letting you adjust the booster's height. There's a front storage pocket, a back pad that protects your back seat's upholstery, and an interior strap that connects to a harness or collar to hold your pet in place. Interestingly, the company explicitly says it "cannot recommend" you attach the booster seat to your pet's collar, a tipoff that the safety level of this booster seat is questionable. Just say no.

Outward Hound Up & Lift Out Harness
Outward Hound Back Seat Hammock Protector
Outward Hound Booster Seat

title: Great Lakes Swimapalooza!
promoTeaserSmall: My family and I took off in a Chevrolet Suburban to swim all five Great Lakes in a day. And we did!
promoTeaser: My family and I took off in a Chevrolet Suburban to swim all five Great Lakes in a day. And we did!
metaDescription: Great Lakes Swimapalooza: My family and I took off in a Chevrolet Suburban to swim all five Great Lakes in one day. And we did! Read the whole story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: My family and I went on an unusual journey at the end of the summer: we successfully swam in all five of the Great Lakes in just one day. It is not a difficult feat that requires years of preparation or amazing athletic prowess, but it does take a certain passion to accomplish this goal. It combines a passion for sitting in a car for a very long time, combined with the ability to quickly plunge into cold water. During the very same week, Diana Nyad put us to shame by swimming from Cuba to Miami. We still hold our heads high as members of a very elite group—and we didn’t require a support team to fend off jellyfish. How did we know we could do it? Because this is our fifth time going on the ambitious one-day, 500-plus-mile adventure, and we're veterans now.

For weeks prior to our trip, my family discussed which vehicle would be best to carry us on our pilgrimage. It is a true fact that my family consists of just three humans and one ten-pound pup (me; Tom, my husband; Elle, my daughter; and Bizee, our Jack Russell), but we do not pack light. Also, once we completed what we refer to as Swimapalooza, we would be camping for two days and then vacationing in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan for another seven days. Our list of requirements included a roof rack to hold all our camping gear, a hitch to attach our bike rack, and the ability to tote around my almost octogenarian parents, who would be meeting us at the end of our palooza. I set my sights on the Chevrolet Suburban, a vehicle that is perfect in every way for this kind of challenge.

image.caption: We wanted to let everyone know what we were doing.

pageElements.text: I'm here to tell you that dreams do come true. We got a 2013 Chevrolet Suburban and made it the fifth member of our family for the trip. I like to dress up our dog, Bizee, and I like to decorate our cars. We listed each lake on the window with Crayola Window Crayons and our estimated arrival times at each lake, and we also encouraged people in passing vehicles to honk if they love Michigan. As a finishing touch, we made magnetic signs and placed them on the front doors to show our route and tout our slogan: “One Day, Five Great Lakes.” It is telling of my family’s spirit that we were all equally geeked to be driving a giant beast that shouts, “We are having a great time! Are you?”

Swimapalooza Eve: Ann Arbor to Hamilton, Ontario

My daughter, Elle, was ready to go at 5:00 p.m. on Friday. She had already singlehandedly packed the car in preparation for Tom’s arrival home. She had thoroughly explored the Suburban and set up her nest behind the driver. The headphones were prepped, and the first movie was poised to begin. She set a place for Bizee to travel in the seat right next to her. Her beverage was already in one of the cupholders behind the front seat console. A cozy blanket and pillow were strategically placed for her to quickly access when necessary. Then we waited for Tom. And waited. And waited. Finally, around 8:00 p.m., he arrived home and quickly threw his last-minute items into the cavernous interior. We set sail for our first stop: Hamiton, Ontario, a mere 252-mile drive.

We set the navigation for our hotel near Hamilton. The layout of the navigation screen was odd and left us feeling unsure of how many miles were left in our journey, and we couldn’t get our hotel’s address to register. Since you need to be stationary to set it, we opted to keep moving and use our handheld TomTom instead. The drive would take a little over four hours, and we needed to be out of bed by 7:00 a.m. Luckily, we were living off vacation adrenaline. During our long wait for Tom, Elle and I had connected our phones to operate via Bluetooth. It was not an overly user-friendly process, but once we consulted the manual we got it done quickly. We didn’t bother to set up the iPod via Bluetooth but instead opted to use an auxiliary cord. The center console has two accessory plugs, which was perfect to keep all of our gadgets powered at all times.

As we drove, we admired the common-sense layout of the instrument panel. The side blind zone alert signal in the side-view mirrors added an extra set of eyes to make any blind spot created by the bike rack less ominous. The front console housed four cupholders, which were barely enough for my husband. Tom likes to juggle a fresh coffee, an old coffee, flat water, and bubbly water to keep him perfectly hydrated for long drives. He is seriously high maintenance when it comes to hydration and the accompanying rest stops on long drives. But I keep my mouth mostly shut, enjoying the catbird seat with plenty of pillows and flannel blankies for a good portion of the trip. We rolled into Hamilton around 1:00 a.m. and quickly fell asleep dreaming of driving, and driving, and driving.

Lake Ontario

We ate a quick continental breakfast at our hotel and set out to knock off Lake Ontario before 9 a.m. Since we have honed our route over the past few years, we now take the first dip along a thin spit of land between Hamilton and Burlington. The water is clear, and the bottom is sandy, although the high-power electric lines lose the beach points for beauty. The air temperature was a pleasant 70 degrees, but the water was surprisingly frigid. We set up a portable changing room and made a quick change into dry clothes. Tom had created an in-car clothesline to dry his suit, and Elle had brought along five suits to eliminate the need to struggle into a cold, wet suit. And I am a wimp and actually only photograph the swims, since if the team had to wait for me to fully immerse myself in the lakes we would still be on this odyssey.

Hamilton to Port Stanley, Ontario

Once we were heading west, Elle and Tom both engaged their seat heaters, and I enjoyed the fabulous power lumbar support, which I combined with the heated seat to help me recover from a seriously wrenched back that had required a quick trip to the chiropractor on the day of departure. (Not to jump ahead, but I think my seat actually healed me.) The heated steering wheel was a bit of overkill on our August trip, but we imagined it would be a godsend in February.

Elle quickly conquered the whole entertainment system and barked out orders to her minions in the front seat to get her movie started. Phone calls were coming and going. Because we used the car speakers, it was possible for all us to be included in updates to our friends and family. We zipped across the bucolic countryside, enjoying the SiriusXM radio, and Tom became the master of controls via the steering wheel buttons. As we pulled into the quaint tourist town of Port Stanley, the temperature had climbed to 80 degrees, and the cove where we planned to swim was quickly filling up with tourists.

Lake Erie

Our swim spot is always very wavy, and this year did not disappoint. Lake Erie's water was much warmer than Lake Ontario's had been, but Erie also proved to be the murkiest of the lakes. As we exited the beach, I spied a group of ladies doing yoga. This town always makes me want to sit down for a relaxing lunch. But no can do: we still had nine hours of driving, a border to cross, and three lakes to conquer. Tom’s in-car clothesline was a bust; there was no breeze or sun hitting the suits. We went back to shoving them up on the dash and allowing the sun, with an assist from the defroster, to do the work. Since our next leg was six hours, I was confident they would be dry for the next dip.

Port Stanley to Cheboygan, Michigan

As we left Port Stanley, it was time to refuel. We grabbed sandwiches out of our cooler to refuel ourselves and filled the 31.5-gallon tank as well. I was shocked to see the price for that tank climb to $114 Canadian, and with a combined 17 mpg, this wouldn’t be my last stop. I reminded myself that there is a cost with bringing everything you own on vacation. However, I knew that once we arrived at our destination, I would be glad that I had not left my gravity recliner behind. I was a little heated from the high gas price and cooled myself right down by testing the cooling feature of the seats. Elle was turtling in the back seat watching Almost Famous, Bizee was sleeping, and Tom and I spent the next hour or so playing Guess That Tune with the iPod, courtesy of the excellent Bose surround sound. Life was good.

Blue Water Bridge

At 7,400 pounds, the Suburban would be an excellent contestant on The Biggest Loser, but surprisingly the 5.3-liter V-8 engine had no problem making the effort to move this whale down the highway. The Suburban remained stable in quick lane changes, and we didn’t experience any lag when we stomped on the accelerator. The ride is smooth, and coupled with my couchlike seat, I felt like I was flying first class and the pilot had just announced that we were not expecting any turbulence on the flight.

Once over the bridge, Tom was ready for a nap, and I took command of our land yacht. Tom is a fan of cruise control and generally stays within a few miles per hour of the speed limit. I, however, tend to skip cruise control and throw caution to the wind and cruise between 80 and 85 mph. Nothing crazy, but seriously!  Seventy-three mph feels like we are standing still.

In past years, the border crossing at the Blue Water Bridge in Sarnia, Ontario, has proved to be a time suck. We often lost an hour waiting in traffic for our moment to tell the border patrol why we had been in Canada for less than twelve hours. This year was a pleasant surprise: we made it to the booth in less than ten minutes. As usual, the border patrol agent was very serious, and he was not thrilled that I was taking photos. At one point we were pretty sure there would be a strip search. But just as I was envisioning myself naked in a cinderblock room, he released us. Whew—high fives all the way around, including Bizee, who had to be awakened first.

Elle happily moved up to the front seat and complained that she was feeling really cramped in the back seat—too little legroom, and the seat couldn’t recline with the cargo behind it. None of these First World problems concerned Tom as he slept like a teenager for the next five hours. Meanwhile, Elle went into DJ mode, and the hours flew by with her spinning the tunes. I made sure to savor the moment of mother-and-daughter time as we discussed her upcoming junior year of high school. There is something about talking in the car that has the same effect as the confessional on The Real World.

Another stop for gas, and another $100 flew out of my wallet. A fellow gas pumper took notice of our window painting and asked about our quest. He shared our enthusiasm for the Great Lakes and said he thought it was a great idea. Maneuvering around the gas station was easier with the Suburban's backup camera, even though the bikes partly impeded the view.

Lake Huron

As we neared Cheboygan, my bestie Tam Schirmer met us in the nearby town of Indian River, and I hopped into her car for the drive to the shore of Lake Huron. Tom resumed his captain duties and was happy to discover that indeed his suit had dried nicely in the sun. With our fan base of one, Elle and Tom dashed into the water to check off lake number three. The water remains at waist height for what seems like miles, so the two actually had to submerge themselves and swim in the shallow water. Every year we discuss finding a better spot, but we never do.

Cheboygan to Brevort

We waved goodbye to Tam, feeling a bit jealous that she would be sitting lakeside in a few minutes with a beverage in her hand. But our two favorite lakes were calling. In fact, our swim in Lake Michigan was less than an hour's drive away, and this portion of the drive was indeed the most picturesque of the day. Once we spotted the Mackinac Bridge, we were stoked. The drive over the five-mile-long bridge is always a highlight. Mackinac Island is off to the right, power boats are zipping around, and often there is a barge passing through the Straits of Mackinac. If you haven’t ever heard one of the Pure Michigan ads with Michigan’s Tim Allen, do yourself a favor and watch this one. This moment was Pure Michigan.

Lake Michigan

As we traveled along U.S. 2, Lake Michigan dazzled us with its beauty as it came and went from sight. The route is peppered with scenic overlooks, but just over thirty minutes later, we reached a point where the water comes almost right up to the road. A small sand dune is all that separates this stretch of road from the water. There were a dozen or so cars pulled over, but the beach is so vast that each group seemed to be on its own separate beach. The waves were pure perfection, and Elle and Tom were practicing cartwheels and happily bodysurfing, but I reminded them that Lake Superior was still an hour and a half away. Even though this beach is right next to the highway, it is idyllic, and you barely notice the road. Again I wished that we could linger here.

Brevort to Grand Marais

This portion of the drive is the most difficult—we were all tired, sick of sitting, and thinking about the chilly waters of Lake Superior and the prospect of having to set up our tent. In past trips to the U.P., before there was satellite radio, the radio selection was horrible. I have heard Gordon Lightfoot’s Lake Superior classic, "The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald," at least once on every trip. However, the XM and another round of Guess That Tune saved the day. This leg is mostly through heavily forested terrain that is riddled with deer with a death wish, so at night all human eyes need to scan the horizon for glowing animal eyes.

Lake Superior

Luckily, we did not spot too many suicidal deer, and we pulled into the harbor town of Grand Marais at 9:40 p.m. My parents met us at the beach, where the temperature had dropped to 65 degrees. Tom and Elle quickly changed into their suits under the cover of darkness and screamed as they ran into the chilly water. They were pleasantly surprised that Superior was warmer than Ontario had been for the morning swim fourteen hours earlier.

The Suburban had proved to be a worthy companion on our trip despite the fact that it is a gasaholic. We still had over a week to recover from our blast through the Great Lakes and were sure happy that our pole barn on wheels had all of our toys inside to help us enjoy our favorite lake that is named Superior, because it is.

title: Is Your Kid's Car Seat Safe?
promoTitle: Is Your Kid's Car Seat Safe?
promoTeaserSmall: National Seat Check Saturday is Sept. 21. Do it!  It's free, and it's the right thing to do.
promoTeaser: National Seat Check Saturday is Sept. 21. Do it!  It's free, and it's the right thing to do.
keywords: Is Your Kid's Car Seat Safe?
metaTitle: Is Your Kid's Car Seat Safe? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Is Your Kid's Car Seat Safe? Child Passenger Safety Week is your opportunity to find out. Go get your kid's seat checked by a trained technician now, or on National Seat Check Saturday, September 21. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Forget about all the Hallmark holidays, National Cheese Weeks, and American Dental Floss Days. There’s one nationally announced occasion that all parents should take seriously: It’s Child Passenger Safety Week, which this year starts on September 15.

Did you know that child safety seats saved the lives of 8,616 children aged four and under between 1975 and 2011? Or that, if you put your child into the appropriate child safety seat, you are cutting an infant’s likelihood of being killed in a car crash by 71 percent? (It’s 54 percent for toddlers.) NHTSA, which collects that data, states the obvious in saying, “Car seats work best when used correctly.”

Of course, you have every intention of strapping in your child correctly. But “correctly” also means that your child is in the right seat at the right age. Here is the rundown on that, and below is the latest infographic from NHTSA, to ensure you are up to date on the regulations and recommendations.

You probably know that putting your child’s safety seat into the car is more than just tossing it in the back seat and loosely fastening the seatbelt around it. But did you realize that, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), fully 20 percent don't even read the directions before installing it? And beyond that, parents make five classic errors when installing the seat that can lead to unsafe riding: using the wrong slot for the harness straps; positioning the chest clip too low or too high; letting the straps be too loose; not attaching the seat to the car tightly enough; and attaching the car's seatbelt in the wrong way. It sounds complicated, and that's why there's help out there.

If you are a parent, or if you ever transport other people’s kids in the car, you need to celebrate National Seat Check Saturday (September 21). This is a day when you can quickly and easily get a trained Child Passenger Safety Technician to look at your child’s car seat in your car. If any fixes need to be made, they’ll do them, and it’s free. Find a child seat inspection station here. If one isn't listed near you, go here and let Safe Kids Worldwide help you find a technician.
We made a video of technicians at work. Watch the great work these people are doing! Why wouldn’t you put these trained helpers to work to keep your kids safer?

pageElements.description: JeanKnowsCars.com visits a Safe Kids car seat installation event in our town.

title: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Gets ACC
promoTeaserSmall: Full-range adaptive cruise control comes to Chevrolet. It's a real nerve saver out on the road.
promoTeaser: Full-range adaptive cruise control comes to Chevrolet. It's a real nerve saver out on the road.
metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Gets ACC: Read about the full-range adaptive cruise control you can get on the Impala, the first time it has been available on a Chevrolet. Details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: I’m generally not particularly taken by in-car technology. Give me four wheels and a steering wheel, and I’m good to go. I know that tech like blind spot monitoring, lane-keeping assist, and pre-collision alert are huge leaps forward and will help people drive more safely, but I have been known to turn them off when I’m driving in favor of what I think of as a simpler, more pure driving experience. But I do make one exception, and it’s for adaptive cruise control (ACC), which I consider to be a life-changing addition to the driving experience.

Adaptive cruise control has been around since the late 1990s but has had relatively limited availability. It looks like that might be about to change, though, because Chevrolet just announced that it will bring ACC to its flagship sedan, the 2014 Chevrolet Impala, making it the first Chevrolet ever to offer the technology.

The Impala’s ACC will be “full speed range,” meaning it can operate at cruising speeds and in some stop-and-go traffic situations (Chevrolet mentions passing through a tollbooth as a possible low-speed application of ACC). Some iterations of ACC are not capable of bringing cars to a full stop and need drivers to take over during stop-and-go traffic. Chevrolet is billing the technology as a stress reliever for drivers who spend a lot of time driving on the freeway, saying that ACC can reduce brake applications by up to twenty-five times, significantly reducing the workload on the driver.

The Impala’s ACC system works using forward-looking radar to measure the space between it and the car ahead. Drivers can select one of three following distances, and the car will maintain the desired gap by automatically applying the brakes and accelerator as needed, with minimal input from drivers. If you’re worried that this is the beginning of the self-driving-car apocalypse, don’t be. It’s a far cry from autonomous driving; drivers still need to provide steering input and may need to override the system for emergency braking and other maneuvers, so you can’t just switch on cruise control and take your eyes off the road. What ACC can do is lighten the load on long highway drives or busy early morning commutes.

Adaptive cruise control isn’t hard to find if you know where to look, with offerings from Audi, Volkswagen, Mercedes-Benz, Chrysler, Honda, and others. The 2014 Infiniti Q50 sedan has made waves recently for something closer to autonomous driving: that car will manage speed and keep a car centered in its lane, even around slight corners, with no input from the driver. General Motors first introduced ACC to its Cadillac XTS sedan in 2012 and also offers it in the Cadillac ATS and SRX. The technology’s move to GM’s non-luxury brand is a good sign for those of us who can’t quite justify a Caddy.

The cost of the Impala is still nothing to sneeze at, either, since adaptive cruise control will be available only to drivers who choose the Impala’s top LTZ trim level and the 3.6-liter V-6 engine. The car's price is $36,715, including destination, and adaptive cruise control will add $1,695.

2014 Chevrolet Impala

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz C250
promoTeaserSmall: I think this entry-level Mercedes is C for charming. But what did the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I think this entry-level Mercedes is C for charming. But what did the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz C250: Should you buy it? Here are my thoughts, and those of the JKC Peanut Gallery. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $42,775 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.8 liter turbocharged inline 4 engine with direct injection
Transmission: 7-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: mbrace2
Option I can’t live without: Dynamic Sport package ($3,050)
You might also be considering: Audi A4/S4, BMW 3 Series, Cadillac XTS, Infiniti Q60 (formerly Infiniti G), Lexus IS
See more specs on the Mercedes-Benz C-Class in our Car Guide.

C does not stand for cookie in the case of the Mercedes-Benz C-Class, but it may stand for cowbell. The C250 sedan that I drove had plenty of cowbell. In fact it had a $3,050 Dynamic Sport package that included eighteen-inch two-tone wheels, AMG spoiler, silver shift paddles, “agility suspension,” and enough red stitching to make a grown man cry, but the pièce de résistance for me was the red seatbelts.

The C-Class is the entry level for Mercedes, but it truly feels like you could swing by your best friend Kim Kardashian’s house for mimosas, and your car would be right at home. The base price for the C250 is $36,255, so many will not make it past the velvet rope, but for those who do it will not disappoint.

Mercedes has built its reputation as a luxury marque and has relied on its subsidiary AMG to provide performance versions of its models. Rather than a full-blown AMG model—that would greatly increase the performance and the price—the sport package in this model featured AMG’s styling and suspension. At first, I thought that it was just a marketing gimmick with no real substance, but once I sat in the cabin I understood the choice. AMG is more than power and performance; it also demands an unrelenting attention to design and detail.

The 1.8-liter turbocharged engine with the seven-speed transmission, in combination with the so-called “agility suspension,” delivered a sporty driving experience rather than a more floaty, luxury experience that you might expect from a C-Class Mercedes. The steering was precise, and the cornering was tight. It made me yearn for a long drive on a twisty road. For those who want an even sportier experience,  there is a sport mode that makes the ride firmer and the steering sharper and pumps up the performance by starting in second gear.

The included equipment list is longer than an NBA player’s arm, but of note is the inclusion of mbrace2. This feature connects with a smartphone to keep track of the keys, accept Google maps, and remotely set off horns and lights. It also has monitoring features that can act as an in-car nanny for new drivers to track routes and alert you if the car is speeding.

The C-Class is also available as a coupe, which has styling that is actually even more beautiful. Both body styles are available with either a V-6 or, for those who want even more power and are willing to pay for it, a V-8.

The Verdict:

Every time I buckled the bright red seatbelts in the C250, I felt special. Even though the version I drove had the standard 1.8-liter turbocharged engine, it was the perfect amount of performance to make the experience fun without feeling like more power and torque than I could handle. The exterior and interior design is utterly modern, and the red seatbelts and red stitching look like they could be featured in a MOMA catalog.

The C250 is in an ultracompetitive segment, and the one to beat has always been the BMW 3 Series. But now there is a new contender, the Cadillac ATS, which arrived in late 2012. For buyers who lean toward domestic, this is a viable option. For 2014, the ATS's base price of $33,990 comes in just $515 above the 3 Series' base 320i ($33,475) and $705 below the Audi A4 ($34,695). GM is specifically going after the BMW on sales and has called it out by name in advertisements. If buyers do shift from BMW to Cadillac,  that could split the vote and help the C-Class close the sales gap. With that being said, if design trumps all for you, then the C250 is the better option. And for me personally, after a week in this entry-level luxury sedan, I declare that C is for count me in.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie: The C250 was fun and felt sporty despite having the smallest engine in the C-Class lineup. I really like the mbrace infotainment system; I find it logical and easy to use. I can't stand those bright red seatbelts, though. I'll take mine without the AMG styling package, please!

Laura: I liked the red seatbelts and trim! To me, they mean that this upwardly mobile car doesn't take itself too seriously. They appeal to me as a Mercedes-Benz hesitater: I don't want to drive some middle-management mobile. Between these colorful styling touches, the unobtrusive but exhaustive mbrace2 telematics, and the low-key but attractive body, the C250 may be a Mercedes, but it easily won over this lefty Democrat. The turbo engine reacted to the light, undemanding pressure of my right foot the way a ten-month-old golden retriever puppy reacts to a slack leash in the park: it went along with me cheerfully, but it was clearly eager to do much, much more. I think it's worth the price to have a runner in your driveway, even if you're usually only going to go out for a mild stroll.

2013 Mercedes-Benz C250, interior detail.
2013 Mercedes-Benz C250, interior detail.
2013 Mercedes-Benz C250 with red seatbelts and trim.
2013 Mercedes-Benz C250
2013 Mercedes-Benz C250

title: The Weekly Windup
promoTeaserSmall: More glorious randomness and fascinating things to click on. A great way to start off the weekend!
promoTeaser: More glorious randomness and fascinating things to click on. A great way to start off the weekend!
metaDescription: The Weekly Windup: More glorious randomness and fascinating things to click on. A great way to start off the weekend! It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.
