pageElements.text: Some things we ran across on the way to finding what we were looking for. Go ahead, click on them and let these random items sidetrack you. It's fun.
1. Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr. does not drive 190 mph. Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr. is a band. And we predict that its new album, The Speed of Things, will be included in the playlist of one NASCAR driver.
Also, Daniel Zott, one of the band members, is now featured in the Free Credit Score commercials, so this band's songs may have the potential to get stuck in your head.
2. Midas hired the Hamburger Helper hand and painted it gold…I am not impressed.
3. For those who are diesel-curious, Audi steps in to show you how easy it will be to find your juice.
4. First there were crop circles that amazed and confused us; now there are circles on our bumpers. Our fellow journalists at Slate explain this phenomenon.

5. Hershey, Pennsylvania, is known for chocolate, but for the car geek it is also home to the Antique Automobile Club of America’s Eastern Division National Fall Meet. They have a little flea market, and by little I mean huge—9,000 market spaces, 1,000 car corral spaces, and 1,500 show cars. So if you would rather look at old cars than the deciduous display of autumn, try Hershey.

6. Something smells musky. It is fun to poke fun at the rich and successful, and Elon Musk’s outrageous, push-the-limits mentality is ripe for the picking. It is not bullying if the person can literally buy you, is it?

7. I daydream about decorating my car, but I don’t even have a single bumper sticker. Perhaps the Alan Moyes Art Cars and Carried Away! Wheels & Limbs collections on Pinterest that merge transportation and art will push me over the cliff.

8. Are you one of thousands of people who looked at the YouTube video this week of the Tesla Model S burning to a cinder? Don't let the YouTube commenters make you afraid of electric cars. Here's a smart analysis from our friends at MIT about What the Tesla Battery Fire Means for Electric Vehicles.

9. Out in Google territory in California, people on the street have a nickname for wearers of the Google Glass computer headgear: "Glassholes." It's still in Beta, so you might not have seen Google Glass on anyone yet. But Google demonstrated its Google Glass to Chevrolet executives this week, and they liked the high-tech specs. Better hands-free navigation, or more Glassholes out on the roads?

title: Falling in Love with Motorcycles
promoTeaserSmall: I've ridden hundreds of thousands of miles on bikes. Thank God for helmets and waterproof mascara.
promoTeaser: I've ridden hundreds of thousands of miles on bikes. Thank God for helmets and waterproof mascara.
metaTitle: Falling in Love with Motorcycles - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Falling in Love with Motorcycles: The story of a woman who started out riding a small Suzuki and, several hundred thousand miles later, shares her experiences with us. Read her story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: My parents were teachers who drove sensible cars, so I was an unlikely candidate to ride something as frivolous or as dangerous as a motorcycle. No one in my family had, to my knowledge, even straddled one.

But when the bicycle I'd been using as my primary form of transportation was skeletonized by thieves, a motorcycle didn't only seem like a logical and low-cost upgrade. It was kismet. My stripped-to-its-skivvies bicycle had been parked outside a biker bar.

And now look. I'm the woman on the motorcycle in every photo on this page.

Twenty-one years later, I've logged a few hundred thousand motorcycle miles, only taking a break from riding when I became pregnant and thought better of resting my baby bump on the gas tank. I've owned seven motorcycles personally and formally tested 200 others as a motorcycle critic. I've biked the Isle of Man, China's Silk Road, and the twisting asphalt outside Sturgis, South Dakota.

A motorcycle has evolved from mere transportation to a form of personal empowerment and, eventually, my career. That's a trajectory I would never have predicted when I took my first, terrifying, exhilarating, scream-inducing motorcycle ride down San Francisco's Haight Street on the back of a dented, high-mileage, decade-old Suzuki that would later be mine for a mere $600.

It was my boyfriend at the time who arranged the thrill ride that would change the course of my life. Oddly, he had given up motorcycling because he said he was tired of risking his life that way. He did, however, encourage me to save my own by taking a formal safety class to learn how to tame a machine that is essentially an exposed motor balanced on two wheels.

Six hours of tedious classroom instruction, followed by a more harrowing on-bike experience that had me wobbling and swerving through cones, ended in failure. I didn't pass the riding test I needed to get my motorcycle license.

But I had already bought the bike my boyfriend called Sue's Uki, so I pushed through my fears of crashing and doubts that I would ever master the clutch. If I'd had another way to get around, that Uki would surely have stayed parked. Instead, I rode it daily—rain or shine, in city traffic and up steep hills that had me working the clutch overtime and crying in frustration.

Thank God for helmets and waterproof mascara.

I was intimidated by the weight of the machine, especially when negotiating corners, and dropped it while making a turn over uneven pavement within my first couple weeks of riding. I don't enjoy playing the damsel in distress, but that early incident made me recognize a corollary benefit to being a woman rider: Unprecedented amounts of male attention.

Sometimes, as with lifting a downed 400-pound machine, that's a good thing. Other times, like the many occasions over the years when I was invited on dates simply because I rode, I was pushed beyond my comfort zone to man up and ride faster and split lanes between rows of moving cars.

Each overcome obstacle propelled me to keep riding and enduring ever greater challenges, like stalling on the Bay Bridge during rush hour and learning to bump start a bike with a dead battery by rolling it down a hill and popping the clutch.

Five years and four bikes later, I was teaching the same class I had failed, having fallen in love with motorcycles, gotten properly licensed, and mastered its most essential skills. Ten years and another three bikes from there, I was reviewing motorcycles for the Los Angeles Times as its first motorcycle critic in the paper's 125 years.

What I most enjoy about motorcycles these days is the physical sensation of riding. I love the immediacy of their acceleration, the ease with which I can get through traffic and the sensory connection to my environment: the smells, the sounds, and, for better or for worse, the weather.

My most exultant and miserable experiences in life have been on board a motorcycle.

And I wouldn't trade either type for anything.

title: Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law?
promoTitle: Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law?
promoTeaserSmall: Pro/Con! Laura: Safety advances should be universal. Molly: Let the driver choose whether to buy it.
promoTeaser: Pro/Con! Laura: Safety advances should be universal. Molly: Let the driver choose whether to buy it.
metaTitle: Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act
Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety
metaDescription: Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law? It's not just safety groups, parents, and automakers who are quarreling over that. Laura and Molly of the JKC.com staff are at odds, too. Read their pro and con on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Yes! The Government Should Mandate Rearview Cameras

Laura Sky Brown, Executive Editor (That's me on the left)

Have you used a rearview camera yet? They're becoming more common, and having used several in test cars, I now resent any vehicle I get into that doesn't have one. They're definitely on the list of things, like the iPhone and Vitamin Water Zero, that I never knew I needed but, having tried them, can no longer live without. The camera shows an image on your dashboard monitor (or sometimes your rearview mirror) of what's behind the car. The best part is the set of helpful lines that go from green to yellow to red as you get closer to that pole or curb behind you.

Just this morning, in fact, I climbed into a Dodge Avenger and put it in reverse, without the help of a rearview image. I was backing out of a diagonal parking space and had already clearly seen that the coast was clear and there was no chance anyone was anywhere nearby to walk behind me. Still, I just felt at a disadvantage, without a rearview camera in place, using the traditional mirrors and turning my head to the back. Those cameras show you the full picture of what’s behind you, and I don’t feel as good about doing without them now that the technology exists, even though I do know how to back up without one.

Government-mandated safety standards are undoubtedly controversial. Is it Big Brother to require motorcycle helmets? Seatbelts? Those high-mounted brake lights on the back of cars, which became a requirement with the 1986 model year? How about airbags? So, how about rearview cameras?

Yes, how about them. I am all in favor of seeing a law go into effect that makes car companies provide them, especially on big SUVs that ride high up off the ground, to make sure the driver can see small children behind the vehicle—but on any kind of car.

No! The Government Should Not Mandate Rearview Cameras, and Here's Why Not

Molly Jean, Senior Editor (That's me on the right)

I am a believer in choice. I agree with everything Laura says about the rearview camera, but I think it should be up to car buyers to decide whether or not they want to purchase it. When will the nanny state stop? A navigation system could also be considered a safety product by helping to keep the driver’s eyes on the road. Should the government mandate a navigation system in every car? I think the safest backup method is to walk around your car before slipping into the driver’s seat, and then to actually swivel around to view what is behind you as you slowly back up. I also know that some individuals, such as some older people, have a difficult time turning to look behind them and could really benefit from a rearview camera. But I still believe the individual should make the decision on whether one is needed. I have been lucky enough to drive many cars that are equipped with a rearview camera, and in fact the car I own has one. But it was not one of my requirements, like the heated seats were. Because I have been driving for over twenty years, it is not second nature for me to use the screen as I back up, so I rarely even remember I have one. But my teenage driver relies on it, especially when parallel parking.

At my husband’s job, employees were required to take a Smith System driving safety course. The program has a whole segment of the curriculum that focuses on reducing backup collisions. It's true that the amount of time that drivers spend backing up is minuscule compared with how much time they spend driving forward, yet a high number of collisions happen while reversing. The Smith System advocates for always backing into parking spots and grabbing pull-through spots whenever possible. Basically, the idea is to eliminate those blind-backup times altogether.

The bottom line is that a driver needs to be alert at all times, and especially while reversing. The rearview camera is a great tool, but I would like to be the one to make the decision on whether it is worth the investment.

Related story:

The Rearview Camera Fight: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that. October 9, 2013

title: 2014 Acura RLX Advance
promoTeaserSmall: This high-end Acura doesn't quite drive itself (yet).
promoTeaser: This high-end Acura doesn't quite drive itself (yet).
metaDescription: 2014 Acura RLX Advance: My short, sweet video review from out in western Michigan. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/g4YeWlGvaQM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Vital Stats

Base price: $60,450 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $61,345 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 20 mpg city/31 mpg highway
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6 engine, 310 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety features: Advance package (included in this top-of-the-line model) includes adaptive cruise control with new Low-Speed Follow and a collision mitigation braking system. The long list of standard safety features includes Blind Spot Information, seven airbags (including driver’s knee airbag), stability control, and a lane departure warning system
Tech features:Tech package includes navigation system with voice recognition, AcuraLink with real-time traffic, blind spot monitoring; all-wheel steering; Krell fourteen-speaker premium audio, SMS text messaging, Bluetooth, Pandora Internet interface, driver recognition memory system
Chief competitors: BMW 528i, Hyundai Genesis, Lincoln MKS, Mercedes-Benz E350 Sedan

Key Points

• The RLX is not a self-driving vehicle, but this car’s Adaptive Cruise Control with Low-Speed Follow is an example of technology inching us closer to the day when cars drive themselves. It lets the RLX independently maintain a set following distance in low-speed traffic situations, including stop and go traffic, and to initiate vehicle braking when necessary. When the car in front moves forward (out of danger), a vehicle icon on the multi-information display will start to blink. The driver then presses a steering-wheel-mounted button or the accelerator, and the RLX will resume the prior set speed.

• Many automakers, including Mercedes-Benz and Nissan, say “robot cars” are less than a decade away. The self-driving trend began in 2007 when Lexus offered an auto-parking feature that automatically parallel parks the car, a skill that few human drivers possess. The feature has moved into mass-market cars, including the Toyota Prius, Ford Escape, and Volkswagen Tiguan.

• More and more cars are getting these self-piloting features. The Infiniti Q50’s lane departure prevention with Active Lane Control/Predictive Forward Collision is a new option. It is an optics-based lane-keeping system that will intervene with steering if the system sense the car is driving out of lane. PFCW can judge the relative speeds of the cars ahead and alert the driver of imminent danger and intervene to lessen the impact.

• Of course, Google famously demonstrated its self-driving car in a YouTube video by putting a blind guy behind the wheel.

Audi rolled out Piloted Parking at the 2013 Consumer Electronics Show (see our article). The prototype system would allow drivers to exit their cars and send the cars off to park themselves. Drivers could summon the cars remotely with a phone app.
• All these high-tech goodies push the RLX Advance’s price up $12,000 over the $$49,345 cost (including destination) of the base model. Also, all the high-tech controls can be confusing.

• Despite all the high-tech stuff, the RLX barely keeps up with the stiff competition from the Germans. It’s a serious question whether the RLX feels and drives different enough from a Honda to justify a $60,000-plus price. The Mercedes-Benz E350 is much more luxurious. And competitors like the Hyundai Genesis offer many of the same tech features but undercut the RLX on price.
• The RLX gets kudos for a spacious interior and comfortable seats.
• But the base 2014 Audi A6 gets better fuel economy at 25 city/33 highway, according to EPA.

• The 2014 Acura RLX has not yet been rated for safety by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (and the website says no updates during the government shutdown). It gets just two ratings by Insurance Institute for Highway Safety; the RLX earned the top Good rating in moderate front overlap crash test and side crash tests.

title: Who Wants to Drive an Audi R8?
promoTitle: Who Wants to Drive an Audi R8?
promoTeaserSmall: Make a video to show Audi you really mean it, and you might get seat time in the V-10 supercar.
promoTeaser: Make a video to show Audi you really mean it, and you might get seat time in the V-10 supercar.
metaTitle: Who Wants to Drive an Audi R8?  - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Who Wants to Drive an Audi R8? This contest lets you show Audi you really mean it when you say you want one of these supercars. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you’re an Audi fan, you probably already know about the brand’s recurring #WantAnR8 Twitter campaign, a contest that gives enthusiasts the chance to win seat time in the Audi R8, a V-10-powered supercar, with a price that can top out close to $200,000. The campaign first started in 2011 when a Washington, D.C., woman Tweeted at Audi using the hashtag #WantAnR8. The company brought one to her house so she could drive it for a day, then expanded the contest to give other R8 fans the same opportunity.

Audi brought the contest back in 2012, asking entrants to compose a Tweet proclaiming their love and desire for an R8. Last year, eight winners were given the choice between a day with an R8 in their hometown and a weekend on the racetrack at the Audi sportscar experience driving school in Sonoma, California.
Audi’s bringing back its successful campaign for 2013, offering entrants the same choice of prizes as 2012’s contest. You’ll have to do more than just write a Tweet this time, though.

The 2013 #WantAnR8 contest asks enthusiasts to edit a video from clips and music provided by Audi, which shows the R8 embarking on a lap around California’s Sonoma Raceway. The contest launched on October 23, and contestants can upload their video entries to YouTube or Twitter until November 10 for a chance to win time in an R8.

If you want to enter, head to Audi’s Tumblr page, where you can edit view the clips and music that Audi has provided to create your own interpretation of the R8’s trip around the racetrack. Audi has provided songs called Two Door Cinema Club, La Vida Boheme, Miami Horror, and others to serve as the backdrop to your video. Once you’ve edited your masterpiece, post the video to YouTube or Twitter with the hashtag #WantAnR8 to put your hat in the ring.

For some inspiration, visit Audi’s YouTube channel, where you’ll find dozens of short videos cut together using the footage that’s available to contest entrants. Then it’s up to you to create the perfect montage. Good luck!

title: Seen at SEMA: Toyota Tacoma by DC
promoTitle: Seen at SEMA: Toyota Tacoma by DC
promoTeaserSmall: DC Shoes turns the workaday pickup into a combination snowplow/campground/snowboard hauler. Radical!
promoTeaser: DC Shoes turns the workaday pickup into a combination snowplow/campground/snowboard hauler. Radical!
metaTitle: Seen at SEMA: Toyota Tacoma by DC
metaDescription: Seen at SEMA: Toyota Tacoma by DC. DC Shoes customizes the pickup, making it into a snowplow/campground/snowboard hauler. Radical! Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) show is a little like a Paris runway fashion show: you’re never going to the grocery store dressed like that, and neither is your car, but it’s a lot of fun to admire the artistry. And one of the most outrageously wonderful concoctions at this year’s SEMA show is this DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma Ultimate Snow Team Truck.

I think what I like best about it is that it started with such a workmanlike vehicle as the Tacoma pickup and then turned it into a snowboarder’s fantasy. I have bought my sons more than enough DC brand skateboarding shoes and apparel to get why DC Shoes was the perfect choice to customize a pickup to represent the snowboarder’s lifestyle.

Could any student slouched in the back of a classroom have drawn a better fantasy vehicle for winter adventures? It all starts with a pop-up tent on the roof, accessed by ladder. There’s a snowplow on the front to get you farther into the wilderness, and a telescoping ramp so you can put your snowmobile into the truck bed and take it along. A secure Jobox container for snowboards and gear completes the weather-readiness profile of the Tacoma. Making this work on the mid-size pickup was the off-road suspension specialist Camburg, which put one of its racing suspensions on the snowboarding Tacoma.

But the fun goes on. All-weather Scosche boomBOTTLE speakers work in the snow, a forty-inch LED light bar illuminates the outdoors for nighttime snowboarding, and an iPad Mini is mounted high on the dashboard for navigation or video watching. The seats are black-and-white with the DC logo on the seatbacks. The DC Snowboarding team promises to take it out on the road post-show.

images.caption: Snowplow on the front of the DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma is by Meyer.
Light bar on the DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma will illuminate the mountainside by night.
Jobox container slides out to hold gear and snowboards on the DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma.
An iPad Mini and leather seating add to the cachet of the DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma.
DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma Ultimate Snow Team Truck at SEMA 2013.
DC Shoes Toyota Tacoma Ultimate Snow Team Truck with tent and ladder in place.

title: Tesla's Trial by Fire
promoTeaserSmall: Don't count Tesla out yet, despite media eagerness to burn Elon Musk's company to the ground.

pageElements.text: Yes, there was a Tesla fire two days ago (11/6/13), the third in six weeks, and the breathless national news corps is in full hyperventilation mode. (Stop breathing through your mouths, maybe?) Let’s regroup.

1. The first fire began when a Model S hit a curved piece of metal in the road in Washington State, which breached the battery pack’s protective shield. The curve of the metal and its angle at impact magnified the force of the impact to the equivalent of twenty-five tons, said Musk in a blog on Tesla’s website. "At no point did fire enter the passenger compartment." After a systems warning, the driver pulled over and exited the vehicle unharmed. The fire that broke out was contained in the damaged cells by firewalls built between the battery’s sixteen cell modules. Vents designed to direct fire down toward the road and away from the vehicle did just that.

2. The second fire (10/18/13) began after a Model S in Merida, Mexico, crashed through a concrete wall at a high rate of speed and then hit a tree. Oh, ouch. The driver fled the scene, seemingly indicating that he wasn't hurt. There were two small explosions from the resulting fire captured on video by a bystander. The fire was contained in the front of the Model S.

3. Wednesday’s fire began when a Model S hit a trailer hitch on a Tennessee road…yes, that pesky hunk of metal in the road again! Here is the full story on that one from the car's owner, who walked away unhurt and says: "This experience does not in any way make me think that the Tesla Model S is an unsafe car. I would buy another one in a heartbeat."
Will they find a smoking gun? Are two Model S drivers really unlucky and the third just an incredible moron?

In the wake of the first fire, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) went to the unusual trouble of announcing that there would be no formal investigation of the Model S because there was no evidence of a safety defect or breach of safety standards. This newest fire has prompted NHTSA to send a team to Tennessee to investigate the car. Will they find a smoking gun? Are two Model S drivers really unlucky and the third just an incredible moron?
Is the Tesla Model S dangerous? Or can we all agree that ALL CARS ARE DANGEROUS?

Gasoline-powered cars have been exploding in fireballs for more than 100 years, and they continue to crash and then burn furiously under much less dramatic circumstances than faced by these three Teslas.

Highest Safety Ratings Ever

In fact, NHTSA just gave the Tesla Model S its highest safety ranking ever recorded. Not only did it achieve five stars in every single test performed—a feat accomplished by just one percent of all cars tested—the Model S aggregated an unprecedented 5.4 total stars in the testing. After the additional and onerous side pole intrusion test, the Model S retained 63.5 percent of driver residual space compared with 7.8 percent for the Volvo S60 (the only other car to get a Good rating in the side pole test). Tesla explains the advantage by comparing the Model S’s safety engineering to that of the Apollo Lunar Lander. And that sounds right, doesn’t it?
Elon Musk, for all the quirks and bristliness, is more likely than anyone in the world to be able to fix this problem.

Elon Musk, for all the quirks and bristliness, for all his brash posturing and unforgivable brilliance (just who does he think he is?), is more likely than anyone in the world, anyone in the world, to be able to fix this problem, if the problem turns out to be random metal debris in the road. Musk has a hard-core following on the Tesla Forums who’ve started a thread to brainstorm a solution.

Meanwhile, the stock price, which Musk himself says “has a higher valuation than we have any right to deserve,” has taken some hits over the course of these six weeks in the wake of intense press coverage, but by Friday afternoon it was already starting to recover.
Overvalued or not in the market, Tesla is a brilliant player in the automotive space, where you would think that one man could never be able to achieve such automotive brilliance (COUGH Fisker).
Don’t count Tesla out. Elon Musk isn't.

title: 4 Automatic or Semi-Automatic Motorcycles
promoTeaserSmall: Guide to bikes with semi-auto transmissions: easier to drive, and potentially easier to live with.
promoTeaser: Guide to bikes with semi-auto transmissions: easier to drive, and potentially easier to live with.
metaDescription: 4 Automatic or Semi-Automatic Motorcycles: A guide to bikes with semi-auto transmissions, which are easier to drive, and potentially easier to live with. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pages.metaDescription: Guide to motorcycles with semi-auto transmissions -- in the same style and length (400-600 words) as the previous Small Motorcycles story.
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: When deciding on what type of two-wheeler to buy, the choice often comes down to the clutch. Most motorcycles have one. Scooters do not, which is part of the reason scooters have twice the female ridership of bikes. But recent years have seen a growth in the number of motorcycles that can be shifted with the push of a button instead of the pull of a clutch.

For many aspiring riders, ditching four wheels for two is intimidating enough. Add the need to coordinate all four appendages to clutch with a hand, shift with a foot, and apply the front and rear brakes separately with the other hand and foot can seem like an insurmountable task, especially since the likelihood that a beginning rider has any experience with a manual is almost nil. Two-thirds of 2012 model year cars aren't even offered with manual transmissions.

Semi-automatic motorcycles remove the most complicated, and necessary, act of coordination required for motorcycle riding by replacing the clutch lever with a button, while automatic motorcycles do away with the need to manage shifting entirely. Here are some worth looking at.

Honda NC700X

Honda is the primary innovator of modern clutchless-motorcycle technology. Last year, it introduced its $7,499 NC700X sport bike with a dual-clutch transmission, or DCT. More commonly found on cars, the DCT is operated with a button on the left handlebar. Behind the scenes, the mid-size 670-cc NC700X uses two clutches that, together, combine the ease of an automatic transmission with the quick acceleration of a manual. All the rider has to do is twist the throttle with the right hand and push a button with the left.

Honda's Mid-Size CTX700

Honda first introduced the DCT in 2010 on its significantly more powerful supersport bike, the VFR1200. For the 2014 model year, it made the DCT available as an option on its new mid-size cruiser, the CTX700 (also shown at top of the page), for a $1,000 price premium. The CTX700 DCT costs $8,799.

Honda's DCT replaces the hydromechanical transmission it first introduced for a street bike with its short-lived motorcycle-scooter crossover, the DN-01. Produced from 2008 to 2010, the DN-01 could be operated in fully automatic or manual modes.

Aprilia Mana 850

Italian sport bike maker Aprilia makes a mid-size motorcycle that can be operated as a semi-automatic, like the Honda 700s, or in a fully automatic transmission mode. First introduced in 2008, the $11,199 Aprilia Mana 850 uses an "autodrive" transmission similar to the pulley-driven continuously variable transmissions, or CVTs, found in some cars and most scooters. Operated as a full automatic, the Mana 850 doesn't require any action from the left hand other than holding on. Just twist the throttle and go. Used as a semi-automatic, all riders need to do is push the shifter button.

Ridley's CVT Bikes

Billing itself as the company that builds America's Automatic Motorcycle, Ridley, in Oklahoma City, is the only motorcycle maker to specialize in twist-and-go bikes. None of its models even have the option of a clutch or foot-operated gearshift. Combining the look of a mid-size cruiser motorcycle with the easy rideability of a scooter, all Ridley bikes are operated with continuously variable transmissions.

Targeting women and new riders, Ridley's bikes have some of the lowest saddles available: just 24.5 inches. They also weigh a reasonable 450 pounds, though they are quite expensive: $13,500. Ridley has been building bikes since 1999 but was sued by Harley-Davidson for using the term "Auto-Glide" to describe its automatic transmission. It stopped producing bikes in 2009, but the company continues to sell its 2009 models. All of them are powered with a mid-size 750-cc V-twin.

title: Four Electric Cars on the Horizon
promoTitle: Four Electric Cars on the Horizon
promoTeaserSmall: Kia and Tesla EVs will be on sale within the year. The Nissan and Toyota are concepts (for now).
promoTeaser: Kia and Tesla EVs will be on sale within the year. The Nissan and Toyota are concepts (for now).
metaTitle: Four Electric Cars on the Horizon - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Four Electric Cars on the Horizon: Kia, Toyota, Tesla, and Nissan have EVs in the works that could be out on the roads in the next few years. Well, maybe not the Nissan. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: To hear some people tell it, electric cars are about to take over the world. And yet, there are only a handful of fully electric cars available for sale in the United States. Are we going to live in a world where everyone drives a Nissan Leaf? Probably not. More and more automakers are getting in on the plug-in car game, and that means there will be more variety for drivers thinking about taking the plunge and going electric. Here are four upcoming EVs you can’t help but get excited about.

2015 Kia Soul EV

An electric version of the Kia Soul will go on sale in 2014 as a 2015 model. Kia’s still developing the car but aims to get 120 miles of driving range out of a 27-kWh battery. They say the final product will charge in five hours on a 240-volt wall charger or twenty-five minutes when attached to a 100-kW charging port. Those stats are about in line with what we’ve come to expect from EVs (the Tesla Model S and its 200-plus miles of range excluded). What will set this EV apart from the crowd will be its funky styling, shared with the gasoline-powered 2014 Kia Soul.

2015 Tesla Model X

It seems as if startup automaker Tesla and its polarizing Model S sedan are in the news almost constantly these days. And Tesla’s hoping it can capture our attention again with its third production car (the company made a Lotus Elise-based Roadster from 2008-12). This time, they’ll bring us a seven-passenger crossover, dubbed the Model X and billed as "blending the best of an SUV with the benefits of a minivan." It will be available with a 60- or 85-kWh battery pack, shared with the Model S, and will feature all-wheel-drive technology and unique "falcon wing" doors, which hinge on the roof and open up instead of out. Tesla has said customers will see the first Model Xs in late 2014, but the schedule has already shifted once to allow for changes in Tesla’s business plan.

Nissan BladeGlider Concept

Nissan will unveil its three-seater BladeGlider electric car concept at this year’s Tokyo Motor Show, which opens to the public on November 22. It's unlike any other car, whether concept or production, that you’ve ever seen. Conceived as a street-legal version of Nissan’s Delta Wing racing car, the BladeGlider would have a center-mounted driver's seat with a two-passenger back row. It would also feature a removable hard top, so drivers can enjoy all the clean air they’ll be preserving with their zero-emissions vehicle. Sadly for those of us with a passion for offbeat cars, this vehicle is still an early concept, so don’t expect to see it on the road anytime soon.

Toyota FCV

Like the BladeGlider, Toyota’s upcoming fuel cell car is on display at the Tokyo Motor Show, and like the BladeGlider, it doesn’t have a firm release date. Or a name (they’re calling it FCV—Fuel Cell Vehicle—for now). Or a fully realized prototype. What it does have, though, is a fuel cell drivetrain that uses a chemical reaction between hydrogen and oxygen that creates electricity, which in turn powers the car’s electric motor. Unlike the electric cars we see on the streets today, which need hours of charging to replenish a depleted battery, fuel cell vehicles can be refueled using hydrogen gas, at a pump much like the one you’re used to using for your gasoline-powered car. The Toyota FCV will be based on the Lexus HS, a dedicated hybrid nameplate that’s sold in Japan, and if all goes according to plan you could see them for sale in select U.S. markets by the end of 2014.

We’ve still got a long way to go before EVs are as common as SUVs on American roadways, but if you’re hoping that day comes sooner rather than later, you should take heart in these grand plans from major automakers. I’m most hopeful to see the oddball BladeGlider whizzing by me a few years from now. Which of these green cars are you excited to see on the roads? Let us know in the comments below.

title: What I Drove Last Weekend
promoTeaserSmall: A quick trip to New York City, where I proudly awarded Automobile of the Year to a car from Detroit.
promoTeaser: A quick trip to New York City, where I proudly awarded Automobile of the Year to a car from Detroit.
metaKeywords: Automobile Magazine Automobile of the Year
metaDescription: What I Drove Last Weekend: A quick trip to New York City, where I proudly awarded Automobile of the Year to a car from Detroit. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Mercedes-Benz GLK250 took me to the airport for an overnight trip to New York City to unveil Automobile Magazine's 2014 Automobile of the Year on CNN's New Day. It is always a treat to celebrate a car instead of the usual hectoring and lecturing of the great unwashed media "elite." But CNN anchors Victor Blackwell and Zoraida Sambolin proved to be totally in the spirit of hot car love, so we had a good time.

First, I can't tell you just what it means to me to be able to award AOY to a Detroit automaker. It was a nightmare living through the dark days. I was born in Detroit and I will always be a Detroiter at heart. It is my spiritual home as far as cities go, although I grew up on a farm thirty miles away and live on one now. I'm from a big family, and isn't family defined as "where they always have to take you in"? Detroit is family to us. That is a big reason why we started the My Detroit series at Jean Knows Cars. I am your rah-rah girl, you brave souls committed to starting businesses in the strife-torn rubble of a city that was once great. We want to get past The Troubles, past the endless "artful" ruin-porn coverage of Detroit as a post-apocalyptic wasteland.

It is difficult for me to even talk about The Troubles without getting choked up. Three years on, the emotion is still surprisingly close to the surface. Automobile Magazine contributor Lawrence Ulrich won the Ken Purdy award—the most prestigious award in automotive journalism—taking a Corvette to Detroit and writing about both. The first sentence? "We almost lost Detroit." I read it aloud to CNN Money reporter Peter Valdes-Dapena. I read the sentence and choked up. The end of Automobile Magazine senior editor Joe Lorio's fine feature about AOY closed with: The 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray is a world-class car with no apologies to make, an expression of greatness from a town and a car company that have been dismissed as losers. It is also the Automobile of the Year.

Don't make me cry.

From what I can tell, GM North America president Mark Reuss feels the same. He has welled up so much over the raw emotion of really hitting this one out of the park during Chevy's darkest hours, that now he gets all gnarly and gruff, I suspect so that he won't just weep in front of his men and women.

That's where I am. I want to cry in relief that GM and Ford and Chrysler have put heads down to the task of showing the world their vast technical, design, and engineering talents. I am also YOUR rah-rah girl, Tadge Juechter, Corvette's brilliant chief engineer, for being the equivalent of MVP on the Corvette team. You and your team never wavered from the mission of making this the best Covette in its sixty-one-year history. You are unequivocally Automobile Magazine's 2014 Man of the Year.

And I am most certainly your rah-rah girl, brothers and sisters at the Corvette assembly plant in Bowling Green, Kentucky. God bless you, each and every one. And thank you for giving the world the best Corvette ever.

I arrived on the street in front of the CNN studios, expecting a gray Corvette. It was waiting at the curb, taking the first spot on the cab stand, and it was YELLOW. We threw the drape on, revved up for the live shot, and whipped that silk off as the producer frantically waved off yellow cabs trying to pull all around it. My people!!!

<object width="416" height="234" classid="clsid:D27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000" id="ep"><param name="allowfullscreen" value="true" /><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always" /><param name="wmode" value="transparent" /><param name="movie" value="http://i.cdn.turner.com/cnn/.element/apps/cvp/3.0/swf/cnn_embed_2x_container.swf?site=cnn&profile=desktop&context=embedwww&videoId=us/2013/11/16/newday-vo-automobile-of-the-year-reveal.cnn&contentId=us/2013/11/16/newday-vo-automobile-of-the-year-reveal.cnn" /><param name="bgcolor" value="#000000" /><embed src="http://i.cdn.turner.com/cnn/.element/apps/cvp/3.0/swf/cnn_embed_2x_container.swf?site=cnn&profile=desktop&context=embedwww&videoId=us/2013/11/16/newday-vo-automobile-of-the-year-reveal.cnn&contentId=us/2013/11/16/newday-vo-automobile-of-the-year-reveal.cnn" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" bgcolor="#000000" allowfullscreen="true" allowscriptaccess="always" width="416" wmode="transparent" height="234"></embed></object>

Then I flew back to the Motor City, where the Mercedes GL waited to ferry me back to the farm. I unpacked, repacked,
 and headed out on Sunday to the Los Angeles Auto Show, where I am now. There will be a lot of radio interviews first thing Monday morning about AOY, and I just hope the waterworks don't take over. It's so embarrassing.

Love,
Jean

title: Toyota DAR-V: L.A. Show
promoTeaserSmall: I drive in Southern California, so I'm a big fan of this safety-enhancing research project.
promoTeaser: I drive in Southern California, so I'm a big fan of this safety-enhancing research project.
metaKeywords: Toyota at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Toyota DAR-V: L.A. Show

contributors.bio: I am a car geek dating back to my childhood, when I took notice of the various sizes, shapes, and designs of cars. I named all of our family cars and cried when they reached the end of their useful life. I’ve been mentally composing automotive reviews for years, but it wasn’t until some years ago, when I read one of Jean Jennings's columns while waiting for an appointment, that I realized that it was possible. And here I am… grateful and enjoying every second. My next goal in life is to learn to drive a manual.

pageElements.text: My day at the Los Angeles Auto Show was drawing to a close, and with my energy and blood sugar flagging, I took a seat in Toyota’s press area to hear about the automaker's Driver Awareness Research Vehicle, or DAR-V. As a hardy veteran of freeway driving, I’ve seen it all in terms of distracted drivers: texting, applying makeup, disciplining the kids, corralling the dog, you name it. All while the car is in motion.

Toyota is endeavoring to eliminate or reduce these distractions altogether, and as someone who has seen her fair share of distracted drivers, I can say that it’s not a moment too soon for this technology. The press conference was very detailed and comprehensive, but in a nutshell, Toyota wants to actively reduce the number of accidents caused by distracted drivers.

In a series of initiatives focused on enhancing vehicle design to reduce or eliminate distracted driving, Toyota has been working in partnership with Microsoft. You, the driver, would see a display of various pieces of highly personalized information as you approach the vehicle. Before even entering the car, you'd be able to check the weather and road conditions, get caught up on the news, and take care of any other tasks before you even start it up. Furthermore, since the system can recognize various passengers, children could encounter a game that encourages them to buckle up quickly.

Toyota presented a mobile laboratory for this upcoming technology: the Driver Awareness Research Vehicle shown here. Utilizing Microsoft Kinect technology, a series of icons appears on the side window, allowing drivers to gather the information they need to get through their day.
As a driver on Southern California’s crowded highways, this technology could be priceless and potentially lifesaving. I hope to see this come to fruition.

images.caption: The Toyota Driver Awareness Research Vehicle uses a Sienna as its base.
Collaboration with Microsoft Kinect program is part of the magic.
Get your essential screen time before you start driving the vehicle: that's the Toyota idea.
Toyota DAR-V.

title: Hyundai Santa Fe to the Rock Hall
promoTitle: Hyundai Santa Fe to the Rock Hall
promoTeaserSmall: A road trip in a great mid-size SUV to introduce my daughter to the musical heroes of my youth.
promoTeaser: A road trip in a great mid-size SUV to introduce my daughter to the musical heroes of my youth.
keywords: Hyundai Santa Fe to Rock Hall
metaTitle: Hyundai Santa Fe to the Rock Hall
metaKeywords: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
metaDescription: Hyundai Santa Fe to the Rock Hall

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe was our home away from home on a family jaunt to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland, Ohio. The idea to make the pilgrimage had started on our summer vacation when my daughter, Elle, watched Almost Famous and declared that she loved rock music. Even though the movie is based on a fictional band, Stillwater, she did hear a lot of legit rock music on that soundtrack. For the remainder of that vacation trip, my husband, Tom, and I set out to share the music of our youth with her. We took a musical trip down memory lane with some of our favorites such as Janis Joplin, Eric Clapton, Jimi Hendrix, Led Zeppelin, and Pink Floyd. But we realized that she needed a more thorough education and decided to make the trip to Cleveland.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: Even though some may argue that we should have driven an American vehicle, I disagree. To me, rock and roll celebrates a lifestyle of freedom—just experiencing things as they come and not caring what others think. Hyundai’s headquarters may be in Seoul, South Korea, but the Santa Fe is an American car that was custom made for us. In fact the Santa Fe was conceived in Hyundai’s design studio in California, and the majority of Santa Fes are made in Georgia. The same Georgia that is the childhood home of the godfather of soul, James Brown.

The Santa Fe is not a complete unknown. It has sold over a million vehicles since its debut as a 2001 model. But the current model does not even remotely resemble its predecessor, which was intended as an inexpensive way to get into a sport-utility vehicle but was definitely not a looker. This generation of Hyundai has all the trimmings of a premium vehicle, including choice of materials, ride, and styling. It has both style and substance, and at $38,840 for our tricked-out Limited AWD version with Saddle interior to seat seven, it is hard to beat.

How does it feel
How does it feel

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: Elle brought her friend Gloria on our trip. They loved the second-row captain's chairs and immediately switched on the seat heaters. If you require a seventh seat, you will need to forfeit those captain's chairs, but the access to the third row is effortless. And folding half of that third row was a snap and provided a flat surface to accommodate our pup and her house. The panoramic roof allowed the sunlight to pour into the cabin, adding to the spacious feeling of this mid-size SUV. The interior sported handsome saddle brown seats that nicely contrasted with the black interior. There were excellent storage spots and ample cupholders.

We needed to make haste: it was a 169-mile drive each way, the Hall of Fame would require at least two hours of our time, and of course we needed to eat. The drive down gave us the normal experience of most SUV owners—highway driving with teenagers ignoring us in the back seat. The Santa Fe ate up the miles while showing us its manners.

There is only one powertrain available, a 3.3-liter V-6 with a six-speed automatic transmission, but the all-wheel drive is optional. Rough Michigan roads didn’t make the ride unbearable, and lane changes were nimble and smooth. There are three modes for steering, but this driver had trouble telling much difference. The navigation barked out directions and gave us notice well in advance. As we neared our destination, the computer helped us locate a restaurant.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: We settled on Barley House in Cleveland's Warehouse District. It actually has taps at individual tables, so you can pour your own. Clearly this is a genius move, but not for us on this trip. Adding to the charm, or rather lack of, there were a few birds loose in the restaurant and the girls were not digging it. Perhaps it was a ghost of the rhythm and blues band the Byrds trying to get our teens'  attention. Regardless, we persevered and had a lovely lunch, then hightailed it to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum to school these girls and get them to loosen up a bit.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The glass pyramid exterior of the Hall of Fame is a tad reminiscent of the Louvre. It celebrates our musical history, and it is not limited to what I think of as rock and roll. If you are wondering why Cleveland, let me tell you. In 1951 Alan Freed, a disc jockey from Cleveland, coined the term "rock and roll" to describe the up-tempo black rhythm and blues records he played. He hosted the nightly Moon Dog House Rock and Roll Party on WJW radio and organized the first ever rock concert in Cleveland. So enough said, Cleveland makes sense.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The curators have done an incredible job of exploring the context of the past and present of rock and roll, both culturally and musically. The museum is set up so that the first area visitors experience has listening stations of the influencers who helped create rock music, and it continues to showcase the opposition that the early years experienced. Then, bam, you run into Elvis. Giant screens tell his story and his various memorabilia surrounds you as you walk through.

The next section is set up by city, from Memphis to London to L.A., and by time period, from 1948 to the mid-1990s. It carries you through  the British Invasion, soul, grunge, and heavy metal. As we weaved our way through the cities it was amazing to see all the outfits and artifacts that we have all seen so much through the years. I especially liked the handwritten lyrics, and somehow shoes worn by the greats intrigued me.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The museum houses so much history that I actually think it would take two days to do a thorough job of absorbing all that it has to offer. It had listening stations that would show you the influencers behind a current artist, and another exhibit that was a tribute to one-hit wonders. There is a theater that showcases all of the members of the hall of fame, and if we had time to listen to the entire show that would have been worth the price of admission alone.

To be without a home
Like a complete unknown
Like a rolling stone?

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: The featured exhibit was Rolling Stones: Fifty Years of Satisfaction. It was chock full of the band’s personal items, including many of their costumes that I immediately recognized. Even though it was all behind plexiglass, it somehow felt like you were getting to sneak backstage at a concert. I regret that we had to make the trip in just one day and felt like we still have a lot to do to help our daughter understand rock and roll.

image.altText: hyundai santa fe to rock hall

pageElements.text: We headed back to Ann Arbor as the sun was setting like a rolling stone. We flipped over to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame station on Sirius radio to continue our education and spent the drive churning over all that we had just seen. Highly recommended! Go to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum website to plan your own musical nostalgia tour, or an educational trip for your kids. And if you can go there in a vehicle as all-around comfortable and luxurious as the Santa Fe, you'll be lucky.

images.caption: The Hyundai Santa Fe's navigation system went beyond mere point-to-point directions.

The 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe was a great transport for this trip.
Two interesting sculptures: Rock Hall and Hyundai Santa Fe.
Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum is on the waterfront in downtown Cleveland.
The Elvis exhibit is prominent near the entrance to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland.
Stagewear is some of the most fascinating stuff at the Rock Hall.
The Janis Joplin display at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum.
The Ramones wrote those lyrics by hand, and here they are.
"My Adidas" and other Run-D.M.C. memorabilia.
This is the couch on which Jimi Hendrix used to play as a teenager.
Remember 45s? If you do, or even if you don't,  you will love the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum.
The girls headed, nonplussed, past this hanging hot dog at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum.
Yes, this was an educational trip for the girls.
Unlike many venues where these legends played, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum is airy, modern, and bright.
But the rock and roll spirit is still everywhere.
The Rolling Stones are the subject of an ongoing special exhibit.
The girls had never heard of most of the names on this guitar.
Visitors to this museum had better keep looking up.

title: Our Thanksgiving Weekend Playlist
promoTeaserSmall: For over the river and through the woods, and for cooking (and recovering from) Thanksgiving dinner.
promoTeaser: For over the river and through the woods, and for cooking (and recovering from) Thanksgiving dinner.
metaDescription: Thanksgiving Playlist: For over the river and through the woods, and for cooking (and recovering from) Thanksgiving dinner. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

pageElements.text:
It is the season of traveling, perhaps just across town, but still we will all spend a little seat time this week. We give you this playlist to nourish your ears during your travels, a veritable feast to help the miles fly by. Our choices are meant to help us all take a moment and think about what we are most thankful for this week. At Jean Knows Cars, we are thankful for all the fabulous cars that we get to share with you.

Have a great Thanksgiving!

See the complete playlist on YouTube, or click through it below.

My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

title: What I Drove Last Weekend
promoTeaserSmall: A 2014 Lexus LX570 was more than big enough to get everything done.
promoTeaser: A 2014 Lexus LX570 was more than big enough to get everything done.
metaTitle: What I Drove Last Weekend - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: What I Drove Last Weekend: A behemoth of a weekend in a bruiser of a Lexus. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The first thing you notice is just how tall this vehicle is from the outside. It’s HUGE!!! It could be bigger than the family Suburban. Wait; let me check the specs. No, it's just an optical illusion. The Suburban is more than two feet longer. At least I knew the Lexus would be big enough for our long Thanksgiving weekend plans.

The next sense of imposing bulk overwhelms you when you slide behind the wheel. The LX's seating position is very high. You can't lower the seats, so if you have a long torso, you may be banging into the headliner. In any case, it feels like you're at the wheel of a Greyhound. Getting coffee at the McDonald’s drive-through involves leaning down to the window to pay.

The price of this particular LX is also vast at a grand total of $88,555. Of course it’s absolutely loaded, but options account for only $5,860 of that, so you might as well enjoy the $2,005 DVD entertainment system, the $2,350 Mark Levinson nineteen-speaker (!) sound system, and the $1,510 luxury package (heated and ventilated leather seats, wood trim, and coolbox). I did, because it's been abnormally cold in Michigan this month.

It's a little bit fussy opening the center console to get at your pops, because the lid has two armrests side by side above it. The buttons you first see slide the armrests fore and aft. You actually have to reach under those armrests to find the release for the center console.

The rear hatch is split horizontally, so when you open it, the top flips up, and a simple lever lowers the tailgate, which is heavy. The third row splits and folds up against the sides and out of the way via electric controls mounted inside the cargo area by the tailgate. Side-folding seats compromise the available width somewhat compared with seats that flip and fold down into the floor, but the LX is so vast that you might not notice any lack of space. My bigger concern was whether or not it would fit in the garage next to the Volkswagen Jetta. It did, but it made the Jetta look like a miniature car.

We had a long trip to make to northern Michigan for Thanksgiving, and it was easy to put all the food we brought in the back. We hit the snow head on for three hours, but the full-time four-wheel drive worked very well.

It’s easy to appreciate the 5.7-liter V-8 and its 383 horsepower and 403 pound-feet of torque when gas comes free with your job. But why do all Japanese V-8s need premium fuel? It was kind of embarrassing (and this coming from an owner of a Suburban) that we were in such a large vehicle that got pretty bad fuel economy and needed premium fuel to boot.

The ride is pretty sloppy unless you select Sport mode, and then it settles down without being rough at all. If you have a lot of large adults, this is a super comfortable vehicle, almost wasted on kids.

We bought our Volkswagen Jetta as Bob’s show-dog kennel, so we wouldn't have to take the Suburban to dog shows with only one dog banging around in back. Bob had a big dog show on the weekend in Lansing, Michigan, and I wasn't about to take him in the Lexus, even though the gas was free.

The dog show was was good to Bob. He won both days.

I did a lot of cooking this weekend. I cooked a turkey that my husband managed to leave behind on the counter when he went hunting in Iowa on Monday morning. I at least made soup from the carcass. I also whipped up a pumpkin pie, and I made bread pudding with the leftover bread crusts in the freezer.

I couldn't bring myself to do anything on Black Friday but stay home, but while at the dog show on Saturday, I went out to lunch with my brother, who is a grad student at Michigan State University. We went to Best Buy, where all the deals that were happening on Friday were still in place in place on Saturday. Only no one else was in the store. Score!

I spent several days during the weekend talking to my niece about buying a car. We talked extensively about how to do the negotiations and how to evaluate the desirability of the options listed on the cars that she was interested in. This got me all exercised about helping my brother find a used car. Car shopping is not for the faint of heart if you do not have a dealer you can trust. You really need to do your research and take your time.

I found myself looking at all the used cars advertised in the weekend paper as Black Friday specials. You know, it's funny, even knowing what I know about buying cars, how these terrible feelings wash over me just looking at the ads for used cars. Am I getting taken? Is 2003 a good year for a Pontiac Vibe? Am I going to be able to negotiate a good and fair deal? Is it going to break in a year?

Heavy sigh.

Onward and upward,
Jean

The 2014 Lexus LX570 is big, all right, but at 197 inches it's a good two feet shorter overall than our Chevrolet Suburban.
Would the 2014 Lexus LX570 fit in the garage?
It did, but it made our Volkswagen Jetta Sportwagen seem minicar sized.
The 2014 Lexus LX570 fills every inch of its space with luxuries.
