Other than the DVD screens for rear passengers, this kind of luxury is pretty much wasted on kids.
That heated steering wheel was much appreciated in a colder-than-normal late November in northern Michigan.
2014 Lexus LX570 with the Luxury package gets wood trim.
2014 Lexus LX570 with the Luxury package has this very deep coolbox in the center console.
That gasoline bill was hefty, though; the 2014 Lexus LX570 gets 12 mpg in town, 17 mpg on the highway, and it craves premium fuel. Lots of it.

title: 2013 Land Rover LR4 Goes Ivy League
subTitle: A 1,400-mile weekend round trip to the Harvard-Yale game in this capable luxury cruiser? Why not?
promoTitle: 2013 Land Rover LR4 Goes Ivy League
promoTeaserSmall: A 1,400-mile weekend round trip to the Harvard-Yale game in this capable luxury cruiser? Why not?
promoTeaser: A 1,400-mile weekend round trip to the Harvard-Yale game in this capable luxury cruiser? Why not?
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover LR4 Goes Ivy League - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2013 Land Rover LR4 Goes Ivy League

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
2013 Land Rover LR4

Price: $63,670 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 5.0-liter V-8, 375 horsepower, 375 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 12 mpg city/17 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Seven-inch color touchscreen with USB and iPod connectivity
Option I can’t live without: Seven-seat LUX package ($9,225)
You might also be considering: BMW X5, Lexus GX, Acura MDX

Access to a fleet of brand-new press cars and company-funded gas cards are two of the best perks of my job. They’re also the reasons that I end up making plans like this one: one of my oldest friends, who recently moved to California, told me she would be in Connecticut at the annual Harvard-Yale rivalry football match on the afternoon of Saturday, November 23. Connecticut, I thought, is much closer to Michigan than San Francisco is. I’ve got a car that weekend. I’ve never been to Connecticut before. In those circumstances, a three-day, 1,400-mile round trip makes perfect sense.

My car for the weekend was a 2013 Land Rover LR4. To my way of thinking, this is a truly unattractive automobile with the off-road capability of a small tank and an interior swathed in luxury. It would be nearly perfect as a road trip vehicle if it weren’t for its prodigious appetite for premium gasoline. If I’d been paying for it myself, the weekend’s wanderings would have cost me more than $400 in fuel. At that point, you may as well fly.

It’s not only the fuel that’s expensive. Just getting into an LR4 requires a largish bank account. My test car came with more than $13,000 in options, tipping the scales at $63,670 after destination. Standard equipment on the LR4 includes a 5.0-liter V-8 engine making 375 horsepower, keyless entry with push-button start, a seven-inch color touchscreen infotainment system, and, of course, total off-road competence. My car’s options got us twenty-inch wheels with blackout rims, black lacquer accents on the interior and exterior, black leather interior trim and seats, a cooler box in the center console, and an 825-watt, seventeen-speaker Harman Kardon sound system. With all that and more, I figured the nine-hour drive would be a piece of cake.

And it was. I stocked the cooler box with drinks and a few snacks before taking off (although I was sad to find that the glass bottle of Coke that I’d bought on a whim was too tall to fit; it was enjoyed warm). The LR4 had more than enough oomph to get us up to highway speed, but I did feel a little like I was driving a barn down the road. Once I got used to its trucklike manners, though, I quite enjoyed my time behind the wheel of the LR4.

Unfortunately, that time was frequently interrupted by trips to the gas station. Although it was rated to earn 17 mpg on the highway, we were lucky to break 15. The LR4’s tank is nearly 23 gallons, which seems like a lot. But when you put those numbers together, you only get about 300 miles between fill-ups. The makers of diesel and hybrid vehicles are marketing range as the ultimate in luxury. Land Rover still needs some convincing.

It felt like a waste to drive this off-roading mobile on the smooth highways of New England, but Saturday morning’s drive to New Haven proved that I was hardly the only person in Connecticut wasting a Land Rover’s capabilities. Range Rovers were practically a dime a dozen, universally gleaming and spotless, looking like they’ve never been off the pavement in their lives.
It’s not quite the status symbol that the Range Rover is, but it still carries the benefits of the Land Rover badge, and for a relatively reasonable sum.

Our LR4 came equipped with an optional third row as part of the $9,225 Seven-seat LUX package. Those seats were tiny and hard and are best enjoyed when folded flat to create more room for luggage in the cargo area. The second-row seats, on the other hand, were comfortable and had plenty of legroom. I gave my friend a ride to the train station after Harvard’s 34-7 trouncing of Yale, and she stretched out in the back seat and fell asleep almost immediately, only waking for a few minutes to eat the chicken nuggets I bought her at the McDonald’s drive-through.

After a very comfortable and successful weekend in the LR4, I was almost looking forward to the long drive home. I’d hooked my up iPod to one of the two USB ports stashed in the center console and was listening to the fourth Harry Potter book on tape (if you can still call it that when it’s actually an MP3) and scarfed down a Wendy’s Baconator for dinner, my absolute favorite fast food meal. I hit a patch of near-whiteout weather in the mountains and confidently switched the LR4 into snow mode, thankful for the snow tires I’d noticed earlier in the week. I tested the brakes and detected not even a hint of trouble on deceleration. No sweat.

Sadly, my peaceful drive home was not to be. Somewhere in the middle of Pennsylvania, what I’d taken to be mild carsickness that afternoon turned into an emergency stop on the side of the freeway and me losing my dinner in the snow on the shoulder. I soldiered on for three more hours, slowly coming to think of the LR4 as a prison of misery. Half a state and several panic stops later, I threw in the towel and spent the night at a hotel outside Cleveland before limping home to Michigan the following afternoon.

I can no longer think of my time with the Land Rover LR4 without thinking of the worst nine-hour drive I’ve ever had. Before all the wretchedness, though, the LR4 proved itself a worthy choice for a cross-country outing. The luxurious interior was spacious and comfortable, the ride was smooth, and the car felt capable. It’s not quite the status symbol that the Range Rover is, but it still carries the benefits of the Land Rover badge, and for a relatively reasonable sum. I would have been sorry to see it go, if only I could have forgotten the amount of fuel the LR4 sucked down. I’m no tree hugger, but with every mile I thought of oil-soaked sea birds and smog-covered cities. If I ever own one of these, I’ll have to buy a Nissan Leaf as my second car for days when my conscience feels heavy.

2013 Land Rover LR4 in Fuji white.
This was hardly the only Land Rover I saw on the smooth roads of Connecticut.
The LR4 was a worthy car for a 1,400-mile weekend round trip.

title: Hey, NASCAR Fans!
promoTeaserSmall: Here's an opportunity to bid, for charity, on four VIP tickets to the 2014 Daytona 500. Do it!
promoTeaser: Here's an opportunity to bid, for charity, on four VIP tickets to the 2014 Daytona 500. Do it!
metaDescription: Hey, NASCAR Fans! An opportunity to bid, for charity, on four VIP tickets to the Daytona 500. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If your New Year’s resolutions list has “have more fun” written near the top (as it should), here’s something you’ll appreciate. NASCAR has donated four VIP All Access passes to the 2014 Daytona 500. Mark your calendar for the weekend of February 23 to attend, and get in your bid on eBay by December 29: it’s for charity.
Where to bid? Here.

What is in the package? Besides the four VIP All Access packages—which let you in to the NASCAR garage and pit road—you’ll get four grandstand seats and four autographed hats that will be signed by team drivers.

Our friends at the Danville d’Elegance Foundation, who support organizations in the effort to find a cure for Parkinson’s disease, are behind the ticket package. The Danville people are in the Michael J. Fox Foundation’s top three fundraisers, and they also support the Parkinson’s Institute of Sunnyvale, California, with charity dollars in six figures.

The eBay auction ends on December 29, so if you’re interested, bid here, keeping in mind that all proceeds will benefit the Danville d’Elegance Foundation’s charity to support Parkinson’s research and patient care. Be prepared, though: bids on Monday were already up to $1,252.

title: Merry Christmas, Everyone!
promoTeaserSmall: I had so many plans....and I changed them to be home with the family. My holiday letter to you.
promoTeaser: I had so many plans....and I changed them to be home with the family. My holiday letter to you.
metaDescription: Merry Christmas, Everyone! I had so many plans....and I changed them to be home with the family. My holiday letter to you on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: We were readying the four dogs for the trip to the kennel and packing the 2014 Acura MDX for the drive to New Orleans to see the family, eat cousin Mark’s famous Christmas day gumbo, go fishing for redfish south of Delacroix with cousin Tim, look for stray dogs in the ditches of Mississippi…

But here we are in snowy Michigan. The dogs are snuggled around us with new blankets and giant biscuits. Hall and Oates's Home for Christmas unraveled everything. I was running last-minute errands, popped it in the changer, and the weeping began. My mom is in a nursing home, and I wanted her in my living room by the fire. I wanted to see my brothers. And what if fourteen-year-old Lulu Belle, the love of our lives, shot through at the kennel while we weren’t home with her?
I began to unwind the Big Plan.

Right now, I am simultaneously vacuuming up the tumbleweeds of dog hair, decorating the house, cooking the ham and sweet potatoes (with lots of bourbon), and wishing that each and every one of you is Home for Christmas, if only for a day, if only in your heart. And thank you so very, very much for welcoming us into your home for the past year.
Have a happy, blessed, healthy, and joyous year to come!
Love, Jean

title: Why Kevin Loves His Nissan Titan
promoTitle: Why Kevin Loves His Nissan Titan
promoTeaserSmall: The perfect vehicle for an urban cowboy, dad, bow hunter, and gourmet cook. Kevin tells us about it.
promoTeaser: The perfect vehicle for an urban cowboy, dad, bow hunter, and gourmet cook. Kevin tells us about it.
metaTitle: Why Kevin Loves His Nissan Titan - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Why Kevin Loves His Nissan Titan: JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: Kevin Kanz loves his 2005 Nissan Texas Titan so much that he says, “I’m going to drive it until the wheels fall off!”

Kevin refers to himself as an “Urban Redneck.”  We are in Sunset Canyon, a subdivision of Austin, in Texas Hill Country west of downtown, emerging from his spacious pickup.  Kevin has masterfully driven through twenty-five acres of rugged fields bursting with blue-green buffalo grass, vegetation native to North America for at least seven million years.  I watch him change the batteries on some jury-rigged feeders, which are distributing cracked corn, millet, and pumpkin seeds, revivifying local animal life that had been vanishing from the region and attracting native pigs, deer, bobcats, and wild turkeys.  Kevin is not only passionate about his Titan, but deeply committed to wildlife management.  He repairs fences and tracks returning flora and fauna, helping to restore various local lands to their pre-developed states.  These are properties that have been decimated from years of pasturing horses, cattle, and goats.  He shows me pup tents, where deer are photographed and counted.  And even though suburban houses are nearby, all is quiet and the fields are full of persimmon, red oak, native ash, and juniper trees.

His muscular full-size truck has 205,000 miles on it, and he swears it has been almost problem-free. A dedicated fisherman and bow-and-arrow hunter, Kevin shows me how his bed extender and removable tailgate are ideal for carrying feed, camping gear, and other equipment. And he explains that unlike some other pickup trucks, his rear cargo area has a spray-in bedliner coating rather than the typical plastic, which he finds much more durable and less prone to scratching and rust.
I bought it brand-new in 2005.  At the time, it had the largest interior of a half-ton pickup, and I have kids.

Kevin is by profession a chiropractor with offices near the University of Texas campus.  That bed extender and the Titan’s dampened assist tailgate have also proven useful when he has needed to carry his professional tables to various athletic events.  As the former president of the Texas Chiropractic Association, Kevin was often required to drive across that grand state of his.  He also travels for hunting and angling excursions, out to Port Aransas on Mustang Island, a barrier island on the Gulf Coast, or to the swamps of Bedias Creek, a tributary of the Trinity River between Dallas and Houston.  A single dad of two, he makes locally legendary organic meals from his catch and kills.  And he partners with both a UT biology professor and a Texas Natural Resources attorney in wildlife management and preservation efforts, including the restocking of the fields.

Nissan’s Titan, the Japanese carmaker’s pickup, manufactured in Mississippi, is so popular in these parts that there is a special Texas limited edition, introduced at the Texas State Fair in 2004. Kevin’s fine white vehicle is from that first crop. The original Texas Titan package included a state badge on the tailgate, a chrome billet front grille, chrome step rails, eighteen-inch chrome-clad wheels, chrome outside mirrors and door handles, fog lamps, a rear sonar system, special dash accents, lockable bedside storage, carpeted floor mats featuring the Texas star, and a power adjustable driver’s seat with lumbar support (excellent ergonomics are very important to a chiropractor!).

Kevin purchased the Crew Cab, which offers roomier rear seating than the King Cab. He also has a leather-clad steering wheel, traction control, a cargo lamp, a power sliding rear window, and great center consoles and storage. Aftermarket, Kevin added power struts and power shocks and the largest tires for his vehicle; he gained two and a half inches of lift. And I sat on his camouflage fabric seat covers in the front cab.

Kevin says, “I bought it brand-new in 2005.  At the time, it had the largest interior of a half-ton pickup, and I have kids. I like a nice big engine and wanted to haul anything I needed to haul: bicycles, kayaks, a trailer.  Other people might even tow a mobile home.  It had a real good maintenance record and an excellent transmission. And it’s comfortable.”

And while native Texan Kevin Kanz sits up high and clearly requires four-wheel drive for his wilderness forays, his Nissan offers 305 horsepower, 379 pound-feet of torque, and up to 9,500 pounds of towing.  It has a 5.6-liter V-8 engine.  While Titans are not known for their fuel economy, and this one is rated at 13 mpg city and 17 mpg highway, Kevin describes his truck as “greener,” and it definitely is at least a little cleaner and less carbon intensive, as it is a flexible fuel vehicle burning E85 and reducing emissions.
[Guys like me] may have other cars, but we all have a pickup because there are things you can do with a pickup you can’t do with anything else.
Kevin says about guys like him: "We may have other cars, but we all have a pickup because there are things you can do with a pickup you can’t do with anything else."
Kevin mentions that he is cooking a venison roast tonight, in a Crock-Pot, with apples, apricots, potatoes, and garlic.
The Texas Titan lets out a deep growl as we drive back on U.S. 290.

metaDescription: BMW Concept x4: Adrian van Hooydonk takes a  walk around the latest BMW at the L.A. Show. See the video on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: I had just delivered Automobile Magazine's 2014 Design of the Year trophy to design chief Adrian Van Hooydonk for the brilliant i8, which made it very easy to sashay him over to the centerpiece of BMW's display at the 2013 Los Angeles Auto Show. The Dutchman is an exceptionally erudite tour guide, as you will discover watching him discuss the finer points of the X4 concept. The production version of the concept, the 2015 BMW X4 crossover, is expected to make its debut at the New York Auto Show in April.

title: A Toyota Land Cruiser Country Drive
subTitle: I felt like Old Money when I took this high-priced, thoroughly capable SUV on a family trip.
promoTitle: A Toyota Land Cruiser Country Drive
promoTeaserSmall: I felt like Old Money when I took this high-priced, thoroughly capable SUV on a family trip.
promoTeaser: I felt like Old Money when I took this high-priced, thoroughly capable SUV on a family trip.
metaTitle: A Toyota Land Cruiser Country Drive - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Toyota Land Cruiser Country Drive: I felt like Old Money when I took this high-priced, thoroughly capable SUV on a family trip. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $78,555 base price of this model
$79,728 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 5.7-liter V-8, 381 horsepower, 401 pound-feet of torque, full-time four-wheel drive
Transmission: Six-speed automatic transmission with sequential shift mode and uphill/downhill shift
Fuel economy: 13 mpg city/18 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature:Center console cooler
Options I can’t live without: all-weather floor and carpet mats ($250), remote starter ($425), ball mount and trailer ball ($98)
Notable standard features on this model: Multi-terrain select, hill start control, crawl control with off-road turn assist, multi-terrain monitor, DVD rear entertainment system
You might also be considering: Cadillac Escalade, Land Rover Range Rover, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class

For me, winter calls for a vehicle that can handle snow, haul a lot of people, and cover many miles comfortably. When I chose the Toyota Land Cruiser, it met all three requirements. Luckily, I didn’t require great mileage, a quiet ride, or a price that was less than I make in a year.

I guess I had never paid attention before to how much the Land Cruiser costs. I would have guessed that the base model was around $50,000. I was shocked when the window sticker showed that the base price is actually $78,555. It is only $4,200 less than a Range Rover. I should point out that pretty much everything is standard, including navigation, heated and cooled seats, rear-seat entertainment, and a small cooler built into the center console. The window sticker also mentioned that you receive a full tank of gas. I am not sure if the average consumer realizes that the Land Cruiser is so expensive.

My second jaw-dropping lesson was the fuel mileage: 13 mpg in the city and 18 on the highway. But since its  competitors' numbers are nearly the same, I guess it is irrelevant. The buyer who is in this lofty niche is not going to be concerned about the cost of fuel.

So it was with a new understanding of the Land Cruiser that we set out to make our rounds on Christmas Day. As luck would have it, we had received enough snow to make the drive worthy of a full-time four-wheel-drive  vehicle.

As we loaded up our gifts and gear for an overnight, we explored the interior of the Land Cruiser. The rear cargo area is made much smaller by the two seats that fold up against the walls facing each other—waiting for the moment that a seventh or eighth passenger needs a seat. With these seats occupied, there would still be room for a small amount of gear, but it would be difficult to scramble into the jump seats over the cargo. We also located the center console cooler and popped some water in to give it a test.

The rest of the amenities were as expected in a vehicle at this price point, and my daughter was pleased with the heated rear seats. There is nothing opulent about the interior. I would expect the leather to be of the highest grade, but it wasn't; the seats could just as easily have been in a Highlander. The instrument panel was not state-of-the-art, and it wasn't old school, but somewhere in the middle. I would like it more if it had been more classic.
With the wintry conditions, it was nice to have a lower number of morons driving SUVs thinking they have a free ticket to drive like the roads are dry and clear.

As we pulled out of Ann Arbor, the roads were quite empty, which is always a plus, but with the wintry conditions it was nice to have a lower number of morons driving SUVs thinking they have a free ticket to drive like the roads are dry and clear. I was determined not to be a part of that segment and was happy that the Land Cruiser was equipped with technology to keep our four wheels firmly on the road. It was reassuring to have full-time four-wheel drive, stability control, active traction control, and ABS. Sadlywe did see plenty of other vehicles that were not as lucky and ended up in the median. I almost wished that we would have needed to call on one of the five special multi-terrain select modes to increase traction.

The Land Cruiser is also equipped with hill start assist and crawl control, but I really wanted to see the multi-control monitor in action. This feature is a monitor that displays the front, side, and rear areas of the vehicle on the center navigation screen. The Interstate, however, did not call for any of these tricks.  I have been in a few off-road situations where one person gets out and guides the driver. This feature would eliminate that need.
Against the competition (Cadillac Escalade, Land Rover Range Rover, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class), the Land Cruiser comes out on top with the ability to tow 8,500 pounds.

One more important ingredient in the SUV recipe is the ability to tow. Among the competitors listed above (Cadillac Escalade, Land Rover Range Rover, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class), the Land Cruiser comes out on top with the ability to tow 8,500 pounds. The Chevrolet Suburban can top that, and it can actually hold nine passengers, but it is a behemoth and not nearly as nimble as the Land Cruiser would be as an everyday driver. And the Range Rover only holds five passengers, but status seekers are drawn to it like a moth to a porch light.

We ate dinner with my husband’s family, and we asked his relatives to guess how much the Toyota costs. No one even came close. Later, when we stopped at his brother’s house, he guessed around $50,000 as well. Everyone knows that Range Rovers are very expensive, but to the average buyer, Toyota is more indicative of economy.

And that, I believe, is the beauty of the Land Cruiser: an Old Money sensibility. The Land Cruiser is not showy, but it will get the job done. It will last for years, and its resale value helps make the original hit to your wallet a little softer. And according to the deputy editor of Automobile Magazine, Joe DeMatio, who has owned three, the resale value is outstanding. People will line up to buy a properly cared for used Land Cruiser.

After a good night’s sleep and a few more inches of snow, we headed back to Ann Arbor. I decided to spend a little seat time in the second row and was shocked at the road noise. At first we thought it was the tires, but we determined that the noise was actually coming from the tailgate. Disappointing. We also noted that the cooler  kept our water cool but not cold. On a hot summer day, the cooler would surely make an impression, but in the frigid Midwest in December, not a big deal.

We decided to stay off the Interstate and amble home via paved back roads. It seemed appropriate to take our time and take advantage of knowing that if we did come across adverse conditions we were well equipped. Fortunately, the sun decided to blaze a trail for our trip, and we enjoyed an uneventful drive. The highlight of our trip was a farmhouse in the country that had hung a sign offering tours of a small log cabin and blacksmith's shop.

The owner shared cookies and hot cider and told us the tale of moving the log cabin through farm fields and the painstaking restoration project that had returned it to its original, simple roots. The tour was so unexpected and wholesome that it was the perfect end of our family day. As we drove the last few miles home I contemplated the Land Cruiser. I realized that it was similar to this cabin: the bones are so good that it will serve its owners well. It may not be flashy, but once you are inside you will appreciate its strengths. And good times are sure to follow.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text:
1. TuneIt

Ditch the confusing audio controls for your car’s compatible Alpine head unit and download this Android app. Not only does it make it fun and easy to adjust the bass and treble right from your phone–just connect it to the head unit via Bluetooth but this just-launched new version of the app will also let you connect your Facebook account to your car so it can read your notifications aloud as you fly down the Interstate.

2. Aha Radio

If you go through life wearing headphones, driving a car can feel like you just stepped into a strange audio wasteland. But if you download the Aha Radio app (Android or iOS), and your car sports just about any in-car app system, you can take all your favorite sounds with you. Just gather all your music, radio stations, and audiobooks into Aha to create a station specially for you. When you get in the car, you’ll be able to play it all through your stereo system. No more channel surfing.

3. ChargePoint

Drive an electric car? This app will make finding a charging station for your next route super simple. Plug in your destination, and it shows you all the chargers along your way. Need to charge now? It will tell you what’s near you. Hate to wait? It will also tell you–because the ChargePoint people have networked a vast army of charging stations–which chargers are currently not in use. You can even reserve some stations so that, when you arrive, you don’t have to fight some stranger for power.

4. Parkopedia

Ever driven in circles, frustrated and late for a meeting because you can’t find parking? This app (for iOS, Android, BlackBerry, and Windows) means to end that. Just tell it where you want to park, and it will direct you to an open spot. A growing community of parkers and parking-space owners tells it where the parking is to help you get out of the car faster and with less frustration. Ford announced at CES that this app is now part of its Sync Applink market, so Ford drivers can use it right from the dash.

5. Parkmobile

No more getting ticketed because your collection of quarters went to your candy habit. This app lets you pay for parking in a growing number of public spots around the country. Just set up your payment source once. And when you park, type in the space number and go. Your phone will let you know when your parking is due to expire. And you can add more money with a few taps. A new partnership with Ford (announced at CES) means Ford drivers can do all this from the car, even more convenient.

title: The Women of the Dakar Rally
promoTitle: The Women of the Dakar Rally
promoTeaserSmall: I spotted them in the legendarily grueling endurance race in South America and became their fan.
promoTeaser: I spotted them in the legendarily grueling endurance race in South America and became their fan.
keywords: The Women of the Dakar Rally
metaTitle: The Women of the Dakar Rally - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Women of the Dakar Rally: Three Fast Women from the grueling endurance race. Read about them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: I was there when they departed before dawn on Sunday, January 5, steering through the throng of spectators who had stayed all night near Argentina’s national flag memorial to see them off. Among the 196 motorcyclists entering the Dakar Rally, two women had a great chance, although they were also subject to the same potential perils awaiting all riders.

One week later, the Dakar—the marathon 6,000-mile rally through three South American countries—neared its halfway point. Then, everything came to a stop: this was the scheduled rest day for riders, drivers, and their crews.

By this time, Laia Sanz, the Spaniard who has multiple world championships in the difficult sport of motorcycle trials, had distinguished herself, climbing to nineteenth place overall after the first six of thirteen grueling daily stages. She went on to finish in sixteenth place.

Another Spaniard, Rosa Romero, with two previous Dakars to her credit, dropped out of competition after the fourth stage. (Her husband, Nani Roma, and his co-driver were the winners of the Rally in a field of 154 cars.)

Sanz, aboard a Honda 450 Rally, had an especially strong second day on a grueling special stage that covered nearly 400 miles. Not all of the 196 riders listed in the class could say as much; dozens withdrew during the course of the rally. The Belgian rider Eric Palante was found dead during Stage Five.
As if technical and physical skills weren’t enough, riders must also do their own navigating, scrolling through the route instructions on a console above the handlebars.

I was following the Dakar in person through its first two stages, from the starting point of Rosario, the third-largest city in Argentina, to Mendoza, in the wine country at the base of the Andes Mountains. Flying out the next morning, I waited in the security line with a rider for KTM, the powerhouse Austrian team, whose right arm was in a sling. “A lot of rocks and stones,” he told me.

Besides Sanz and Romero, Italian Camelia Liparoti was one of forty-seven human rag dolls in the ATV class. Motorcycles somehow made sense when we saw them on the back roads and trails, but ATVs—or quads, as they’re called here—look as though they want to pitch the person onto an Andean peak. Liparoti, on a Yamaha, held thirteenth in class as the Dakar resumed for stage seven, having averaged ten-plus hours in the saddle on each of the first six days. More than half the starting field of quads had dropped out. Liparoti finished the Dakar Rally, still thirteenth in class after more than 111 hours of riding.

Formerly known as the Paris-Dakar Rally, this craziness was initiated in 1979 and ran from various points of origin—initially Paris, but also from Valencia, Spain, and once from Cairo, Egypt—before finishing in Dakar, Senegal. It took three weeks—and sometimes a life. Terrorist threats in 2008 caused the rally’s cancellation that year. Coming back the next, it was relabeled the Dakar, and it ran through South America, where it has been a big success.

Besides the quads and abundant motorcycles and cars (and buggies, Jeeps, and pickups bundled in that class), there is a fourth class for the most beastly-looking heavy trucks anyone could imagine. They all run the same course. This involves transit stages over normal highways, but then, in special stages contested against the clock, the “road book” filled with course instructions leads competitors onto secondary byways, across sand dunes, and over narrow trails. The motorcycles have a unique two-day interlude at high altitude in Bolivia.
The finishers receive accolades but no money—this is all for glory—on reaching Valparaíso, Chile, on Sunday, January 17.

No motor race is more demanding, especially for the riders. As if their technical and physical skills weren’t enough, they must also do their own navigating, scrolling through the route instructions on a console above the handlebars. The driver of a car has it comparatively easy, communicating by intercom with the navigation specialist.
During the night, everybody puts up with the noise as mechanics tear down each vehicle and replace key parts, as well as tires, in order to be ready for the next stage.

Adding to the difficulty, there isn’t much sleep for anyone doing the Dakar. A mobile camp is set up at each overnight stopping point. The luckiest competitors and drivers have motorhomes. Others, though, crawl into tents. Everybody puts up with the noise as mechanics tear down each vehicle and replace key parts, as well as tires, in order to be ready for the next stage. Throughout the night, engines are heard revving insanely.
Leading the way each morn, the motorcycles are off again at a ridiculously early hour, well before 5:00 a.m.
Despite all this, my brief exposure made it easy to see how the bug would bite—and not the bizarrely camouflaged grasshopper I almost squashed when climbing into my own tent.

That’s why my hat goes off to Sue Mead. In 2010, after about a decade spent reading the road book as a co-driver, Mead, who was then sixty years old, took the wheel and guided her Ford pickup to a class win within the automotive category, becoming the first American woman to triumph in the Dakar.

We can expect that, as this amazing rally becomes better known in the United States, more American women will follow the tire tracks of Mead, Laia Sanz, and other women who persevere and excel in the Dakar.

images.caption: The U.K.'s Susan Jones navigated alongside her husband. They finished 51st in the Car class. Photos by Ronald Ahrens.
Spain's Laia Sanz, on a Honda, was competing in her fourth consecutive Dakar Rally.
Laia Sanz has fifteen world titles in endurance racing.
Laia Sanz at the start of the rally.
Laia Sanz of Spain during the first stage.
Rosa Romero of Spain attracted attention on her Yamaha. She bowed out after the fourth stage.
Map of the 2014 Dakar Rally.

title: Car Insurance: 4 Reasons NOT to Switch
promoTitle: Car Insurance: 4 Reasons NOT to Switch
promoTeaserSmall: Should you be hunting online for the cheapest deal? Here's why you may be better off not doing that.
promoTeaser: Should you be hunting online for the cheapest deal? Here's why you may be better off not doing that.
metaTitle: Car Insurance: 4 Reasons NOT to Switch - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Car Insurance: 4 Reasons NOT to Switch. Should you be hunting online for the cheapest deal? Here are four reasons that is counterproductive. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Most people assume that car insurance protects a depreciating asset (the vehicle). What it really protects is your family’s financial well-being.  Ideally, you should review your coverage annually. If you have a major life event such as marriage, divorce, inheritance, or job change, that’s also a time to revisit your insurance. Moreover, most people bundle their home insurance with their auto insurance.  Life events have trickle-down effects for home and auto.

In that annual review, should you be jumping ship (or cars for a more appropriate metaphor) to the insurer with the lowest rates? My agent, Nathan Lamb of Farm Bureau Insurance, had a convincing argument that it's not the right thing to do, for these five reasons.

1. A company’s rates vary year to year, depending on the number of claims the company has had. If you stay with the same company for many years, chances are you’ll come out even or better than if you constantly switched. If a company offers to give you a “better rate” just for being you or “to keep you as a valued customer,” warning: it’s a marketing ploy. Insurance rates are filed with the state. Your parameters determine coverage, but special offers do not.

2. When determining your rates, every company looks at your “insurance score,” which is akin to a credit score. Constant changing could affect your insurance score, which also could affect your premiums.

3. Constantly changing prevents you from the benefits of developing a long-time relationship with one agent. If you constantly change, you become a number, and something can fall through the cracks. (For example, when my previous insurance company neglected even to process the insurance on my Fiat.)

4. Agents know things you don't. In the days of online everything, auto insurance is marketed as a widget you buy. We tend to pick our insurance by lowest premium, even though lower prices inevitably mean lower coverage. We’re talking quite the widget, given the issues at stake. Do you really want to figure it all out by looking at the Web?

As a consumer, you are not a licensed agent with the knowledge, training, and continuing education that licensing entails. If you have a good agent, he or she becomes the fourth wheel that drives your financial security. Along with your banker, your lawyer, and your accountant, your insurance agent should be looking at the big picture and at what’s best for you and your family. He or she should be asking you about net worth, what you make per year, and how long you intend to work as the two of you consider your insurance coverage. Those factors, and your stage in life, not “how low do you want your premium,” should be driving your decision.
Image at top from xie/iStock/Thinkstock

title: Humans of the Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: Some of the people I met while walking around public days at the Detroit Auto Show with a camera.
promoTeaser: Some of the people I met while walking around public days at the Detroit Auto Show with a camera.
metaTitle: Humans of the Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Humans of the Auto Show: I do Humans of Ann Arbor on Facebook. It was a small step to rooting out the human interest side of the Detroit Auto Show. See my photo story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a person who loves to study other people. I like to interview them, learn about their lives, photograph them, and write their stories. The people at Jean Knows Cars noticed me through my project, Humans of Ann Arbor. In that project, I tool around the city of Ann Arbor, introducing myself to anyone who draws my eye. If they are open to it, I take a photo of them and hear a little bit about them. Then I post the photos and stories on Facebook. Humans of Ann Arbor has followers from all over the world who check in on a daily basis to see ordinary people and their extraordinary stories. I have been studying people since I was a little girl in Missouri. Where I grew up, studying people often led you to the cars they loved. My grandpa had a gas station in Claycomo, Missouri, which he opened in the 1950s, and he passed his love of cars and taking care of the people who drove them down to my dad. Dad was a mechanic and a service supervisor all his life. We had a steady barrage of cars coming into our lives…mostly Chevys. To impress my dad, I learned to identify every car I could, and I used to name the cars while we drove down the road. Car culture is big in Missouri. Would you believe that I had friends who were sisters named Nova and Chevelle? If you didn’t grow up the way I did, you might not get the significance of that, but suffice it to say that my people love their cars. The car I adored most was the Chevrolet Corvair my dad gave me when I was in high school. It spent more time in my dad's shop than it did on the road, but in those moments when it was drivable, I knew what it was to love a car. It was a thing of beauty: pale cream with a plaid madras interior. I loved the sound and feel of the engine…it was more like a soft purr than a roar. I can still remember how it smelled and what it was like to drive it with the windows rolled down on a warm day. I've had lots of cars since then, and I loved some of them, too. But the Corvair was my first car love and will always be my favorite. After high school, I drove my car to Springfield, Missouri, to study communications at Missouri State. Later, I drove a different car to Chicago to study photography at Columbia College. I worked in Chicago as a freelance photographer and studio manager for many years before moving to Ann Arbor, where I continue to do freelance photography. I am excited about combining my love of studying people with my interest in cars. I want to explore how cars serve us, how they are intertwined in our lives, and what makes us love them. I can't wait to let you know what I find out.

pageElements.text: I was so happy when Jean Knows Cars asked me to go to the North American International Auto Show and take a look around. Most people go to see the vast array of amazing cars, but as the street photographer and photo blogger who does Humans of Ann Arbor, I went to see the people. For one day I introduced myself to every stranger who caught my eye and asked if I could take their picture and tell their story. Here they are: Humans of the Detroit Auto Show.

Pregnant Woman at Trunk of Cadillac

When I saw her, she was opening the trunk, and closing the trunk, then opening it again, over and over.
Me:  I noticed you are really checking out that trunk.  What’s up with that?  Is a good trunk important to you?

Her: (laughing) Yeah, I work in engineering, and I work on parts like these.

Me: Oh, cool, so you can tell me what to look for in a trunk?
Her:  Well, space for sure, the quality of the opening and closing, and the weight.
Me:  It looks like you are going to be putting lots of stuff in your trunk soon…
Her:  Yes, like strollers and diaper bags.  I’m having my first baby.

Ladies with Wigs and Puppets

They come from a true Detroit family, with family members who are ironworkers, or work for GM and Ford. When I saw them, they were in a 1963 Chevy Greenbrier van that had been turned into a photo booth.

“We’re cousins, and we were the first girls in our family, so it was a big deal.  There are lots of pictures of the two of us together while we were growing up, some where we were trying to pull things away from each other.  Since there are so many pictures of us together, we thought it would be fun to do this.”

Cleaner

“I’ve been working for Mini and Ford. The Minis are a lot easier to keep clean.”

Three Teenagers

Me: Isn’t this a school day?

Them: Yes…But we are on a field trip with our Graphics class!

Car Model with Charger

“The models are all chosen specifically for the car they represent," a company rep said. "We chose her because we wanted someone who looked like they were from the Seventies. She may do five to ten shows this year. I would call her a model because she did receive training on the car and can answer quite a few questions about it, but she hasn’t gotten in depth training at this point. Some of the other people are product specialists. They have received more training. Some specialists are educated and become very knowledgeable, and they may then become narrators and give presentations about the vehicles they represent.”

Two Women, Two Kids

I kept trying to get him to smile.
Me:  On the count of three, say Elmo!  One…two…three…
(silence)
Me:  You don’t like Elmo?  What do you like?
Mom:  He just likes cars.

Woman with Glasses

Her: I work in Engineering at GM.
Me:  What’s it like being a woman in the automotive industry?
Her:  I honestly don’t even think about it.  It’s just not an issue.  Everyone in our department is treated with the same respect.  And we have a female CEO now.
Me:  What advice do you have for young women who might be interested in automotive engineering?
Her:  Study your math and science.  Get a good education, and if you are interested, just go for it!

Couple

Him: We are looking for a car that can pull a trailer for when I retire next year. And we need to pull our two motorcycles.
Me: Cool!  Do you guys ride together a lot?
Her: Oh, yes.
Him:  But I have to ride in front, because she’s a speed demon!
Her:  Well, I drove a school bus for thirty years, so…
Me:  You’re a professional?
Her:  Yes!

Molly Jean of Jean Knows Cars

Molly Jean kept checking to see if an attendant would open this booth up and let people try on these crazy costumes. No one ever came, and she couldn’t hide her disappointment.

UAW Blue Shirt

“Just about everyone in my family is in the UAW. My mother, my sister-in-law, my brother-in-law. But this is the first time I’ve been to the Detroit Auto Show.”

Lady in Red Coat at Red SUV

She’s a lifelong resident of Detroit.
“I love the Big D!”

title: Bentley Home Collection
subTitle: Who better to bring luxury to the home? My tour of the collection at the Paris Maison & Objet show.
promoTeaserSmall: Who better to bring luxury to the home? My tour of the collection at the Paris Maison & Objet show.
promoTeaser: Who better to bring luxury to the home? My tour of the collection at the Paris Maison & Objet show.
metaDescription: Bentley Home Collection: Who better to bring luxury to the home? My tour of the collection at the Paris Maison & Objet show. See the video on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I went to Bentley’s historic headquarters in Crewe, England, for the first time in my long career as an automotive journalist. I wasn't there to test cars (except for a few exceptional backseats behind a chauffeur). Instead, I was welcome where few have been invited—the back rooms where veneers are mirror matched by hand and finished by skilled artisans, and where large southern German bull hides are scrupulously examined for the slightest flaws (unacceptable!) before a laser cuts pattern pieces dictated by a computer. I was able to take part in some of the hand work, which I found much more interesting than scrapbooking, I must say! We made a short video before we jumped on the Eurostar for Paris, where we toured Bentley's inaugural furniture collection at the Paris furniture show, Maison et Objet.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/6L9H2ZY34tQ?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Maison & Objet show in Paris displayed the new line of Bentley-themed luxury home furnishings. They were created in conjunction with Luxury Living Group, an Italian furniture maker. As you'll see in this video, I was shown room after room of furniture that expresses the Bentley attitude toward the "living environment," in the company of Bentley Motors' director of product design, Daniele Ceccomori. For more about the collection, see the Bentley Home Collection website.

Related stories:

A Trip to Bentley's Headquarters January 30, 2014

pageElements.text: At a recent Bridgestone Racing Academy event, Bridgestone employee Doug Niman went over some basics about the fluids in your car. It’s a good reminder to check your owner’s manual and make sure you are keeping your fluids fresh and changed at the recommended intervals.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Rb8TW8wrXZo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

1. Oil

Engine oil is perhaps the most important ingredient in a healthy car: it keeps the engine and all its parts cool, lubricated, and working properly. That’s why it’s essential to stay on top of oil changes. Check your owner’s manual for recommended intervals and oil types for your car. And, while you’re at it, have the oil filter changed whenever you change your oil. Older cars may need their oil levels checked frequently; aim for every time you fill the tank.

As Doug points out, there are newer synthetic and synthetic blend oils in addition to conventional oil types. Synthetic oil is more expensive; a quick search of traditional versus fully synthetic oil shows prices in the $3.99 range for a quart of traditional and $8.99 and up for the synthetic. But synthetics tend to be popular among owners of high-performance cars and people who want to maximize gas mileage.
Feel adventurous and want to do your own oil change? Check out this video.

2. Transmission Fluid

Transmission fluid is a miracle of technology, full of additives that simultaneously protect your transmission against friction, oxidation, and changes in temperature. However, it shouldn't be something you need to top up or add to; if the level gets low, it means there's probably a leak. You can use the dipstick that's provided in the compartment to check your automatic transmission's fluid, but checking the transmission fluid on a manual-transmission vehicle means putting it up on a hoist to look under the car. Suffice it to say, don't let your servicer omit the transmission fluid check at the maintenance interval in your owner's manual.

3. Coolant

Coolant, a.k.a. antifreeze, is the liquid that keeps your car's operating temperature stable. It's designed to have a low freeze point and a high boil point. It's also got additives to keep the cooling system from rusting or corroding. Check your owner's manual for what kind your car is intended to use and the interval at which it's recommended to flush your car's coolant system.

4. Brake Fluid

The important thing to know about brake fluid is that it easily absorbs moisture and can start to break down over time. You can use a test strip, available at auto parts superstores, to check the cleanliness of your car's brake fluid. But stick to the recommended service interval in your owner's manual and have the fluid flushed when the manual suggests.

promoTeaserSmall: Concept shows what to expect from the 2015 TT. Exterior design chief Steve Lewis did the walkaround.

metaDescription: Audi Allroad Shooting Brake Concept: This Detroit Auto Show concept shows what to expect from the 2015 TT. Exterior design chief Steve Lewis did the walkaround. See the video on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Pay attention to Steve Lewis, chief of exterior design, as he points out the most important design cues on Audi's Allroad Shooting Brake Concept. And then think Audi TT. Because that is really what you're looking at. That doesn't mean there won't be an Allroad station wagon (which is what "shooting brake" means, in U.K. parlance) based on this platform. It looks very doable and desirable.

pageElements.text: I went to Bentley’s historic headquarters in Crewe, England, for the first time in my long career as an automotive journalist. I wasn't there to test cars (except for a few exceptional backseats behind a chauffeur). Instead, I was welcome where few have been invited—the back rooms where veneers are mirror matched by hand and finished by skilled artisans, and where large southern German bull hides are scrupulously examined for the slightest flaws (unacceptable!) before a laser cuts pattern pieces dictated by a computer.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/wqFXxH3pZzs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
I was able to take part in some of the hand work, which I found much more interesting than scrapbooking, I must say!
We made a short video before we jumped on the Eurostar for Paris, where we toured Bentley's inaugural furniture collection at the Paris furniture show, Maison et Objet. That video is on its way!

images.caption: Skilled Bentley artisans do make dreams happen in the private workrooms at Crewe.
A fortune in superior quality wood veneers are stored on the premises until they are mirror-matched by hand, cut, layered over soiled wood substrate, formed, finished, and polished to perfection.
Finished veneer trim pieces are examined for flaws.

Leather hides are stretched and imperfections are marked, then scanned by laser and event to a computers the computer arranges pattern pieces and send to the laser cutter which cuts the patterns while avoiding all imperfections.
A day in the company of the talented artisans at Bentley is a fine day, indeed.

title: Taxi Driver Revisited
subTitle: In Nissan's NV200 taxicab, I made the rounds in Ann Arbor. It was just like old times, only newer.
promoTeaserSmall: In Nissan's NV200 taxicab, I made the rounds in Ann Arbor. It was just like old times, only newer.
promoTeaser: In Nissan's NV200 taxicab, I made the rounds in Ann Arbor. It was just like old times, only newer.
metaDescription: Taxi Driver Revisited: In Nissan's NV200 taxicab, I made the rounds in Ann Arbor. It was just like old times, only newer. Read about it in JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:
