pageElements.text:
Nissan's new taxicab, as Molly Jean described in her story Big Yellow Taxi on this site, is the latest in cab fashion. As a former cab driver myself, I was happy to have the opportunity to spend a day reliving the experience by driving the Nissan NV200 around Ann Arbor, picking up friends, and catch it all on video. That brought back some memories, which I am happy to share with you here.
Love,
Jean
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/F_4E__LqRwI" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

images.caption: Who's paying this fare?!?
Totally illegal.
Plenty of room for four plus gear.
Flashback to the bad old days.
Bonding with my home girl.
A free ride would make me happy, too.
The passengers aren't always clean.
Another runout.
I'll always trade a free ride for dog kisses.
Don't worry; I'll clean the seat.
All my friends were happy about their free rides.
The garden store run. Everybody in Michigan had spring fever.
The triangulation of the running board foot step and the left and right upper hand grips are difficult for older passengers to negotiate.
All cab drivers should get out and help their older customers.
Once inside the cab, older passengers have a hard time turning around and getting to the seat.
Any cab driver would be happy to have a built-in nav system.
The back of my 1975 vintage wind-up Halda meter.
The front of the Halda meter. Takes a licking, and it's still ticking.
At the end of the day, the Halda rang up $11.90 in fares after five  runs, none of which my Ann Arbor deadbeat friends paid, despite the bargain-basement 1975 rollback fares.

pageElements.text:
Back When I Was Yellow

I went to the University of Michigan in 1971 at the tender age of sixteen. But I was way too busy waitressing and marching in anti-war demonstrations to study. So I bolted the Big U after three non-productive semesters, and I got a job driving a cab. I was eighteen, and my parents were now truly horrified. I think I was, too.
A year later, I owned my own taxi, just to prove I could. The rest of my life has been spent crawling up the mountain of my shame by my fingernails.

I bought a used Plymouth Fury with 56,000 miles on it, painted it yellow, and joined Ann Arbor Yellow Cab Company.  Within two months, I had to teach myself how to work on it because the repair bills were staggering.  I taught myself tuneups in my friend Cowboy Bill’s gas station, using library books on car maintenance.
I did a brake job at the curb in front of my house, by drawing a picture in my sketchbook of every part I took out, so I would put it all back together correctly.

My cab-driving outfit was bib overalls and a ski hat, or long hippie skirts down to the ground with army boots.  You could see the salt stains along the bottom edge of the skirt in the winter.  I didn’t shave my legs. I smoked cigars. I was so cool. I used to keep a bottle of wine under the seat, and if I liked the person in the back seat, I’d offer them a slug.

The cab drivers were an uncertain lot, shall I say. Oh, there was the occasional Ph.D. candidate, like David Wilson, who got in trouble for practicing his saxophone on the cab stand in front of the old U Hospital. There were also a couple of more-or-less professionals who considered cab driving a craft. There was Lester, Cab #1, who had a Lincoln with suicide doors, and who spent most days off the Yellow Cab grid, running a long list of private clients on errands. There was another guy, who today—forty years later—drives a city bus. Not to alarm you. And there were several college graduates who went on to buy the company. That was ridiculous. They’re all gone.
About once a year I’d have someone famous in the back seat. Like the time I picked up Jason Robards at the back door of the Power Center.

The rest of the cabbies were transient reprobates like me. Our hero was a guy who turned the tables on a would-be robber. Think De Niro in Taxi Driver. When the guy in his back seat pulled out a knife, our Colleague pulled out a giant Maglite flashlight from under his seat and gave his assailant a helluva thumping with it. He then rolled him in the gutter and took $250 from his pockets.

About once a year I’d have someone famous in the back seat. Like the time I picked up Jason Robards at the back door of the Power Center, where he’d just finished a performance in A Moon for the Misbegotten with Colleen Dewhurst.

He wanted to go to the old theatre on South U next to the Brown Jug, to see The Hound of the Baskervilles. I was so excited I could barely drive. “I just saw you in Tora! Tora! Tora! last night!" I’m pretty sure I shouted at him. He looked pained. "That‘s one I’d like to forget," he said. The meter ran a dollar twenty, and he gave me ten bucks. Jason Robards!

But most of the time it was drug addicts and drunks. I carried one guy into his house over my shoulder after he’d been slashed in a bottle fight. I propped him on the toilet, cleaned him up with alcohol, and put him to bed. A driver began stalking me. Another woman driver was murdered. I was robbed at gunpoint. After five years, it was clearly time to move on. But not before I wrote a training manual for new cab drivers, was elected president of the Yellow Cab Board, and completely redesigned the taxi stand system in Ann Arbor.
You know, the typical things one does.

title: 2014 Honda Civic
subTitle: Wide appeal, compact car.
promoTeaserSmall: Wide appeal, compact car.
promoTeaser: Wide appeal, compact car.
metaDescription: 2014 Honda Civic: Wide appeal, compact car. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The 2014 Civic inherits multiple updates from the previous year and a few fresh touches for this year’s model.  Starting at a base price in the $18,000 range, the Civic's price and options widen out from there, beginning with a sportier-looking two-door coupe or the popular four-door sedan body style. Fuel savings are a Civic calling card, and several trims are available with creative ways to up the mpg from the aerodynamic HF to an electric Hybrid or a natural gas hybrid. The interior of this historically well received compact is where the improvements really stand out. Thanks to acoustic glass and other noise-dampening materials, the ride is quieter than ever before.  Changes from the staid and sometimes cheap-feeling 2012 model include an updated interior color palette, refashioned vents, and higher-quality seat coverings. Technology upgrades are available to navigate, monitor your blind spot, connect to Apple’s Siri Eyes Free,  and increase fuel efficiency.  While it’s no performance vehicle, it has an improved feel between the steering and the road that previous Civic owners will appreciate.  Comfortable for its size and reliable for the long haul, the Civic has enjoyed a loyal and wide following which can be expected to continue for years to come.

Competitors:

Dodge Dart
Toyota Corolla
Ford Focus

Cool Tech:

Natural gas hybrid is a game changer for those who have access to a compressed natural gas station.
Apple’s Siri Eyes Free mode comes factory installed with the Display Audio option.
Seven-inch customizable touchscreen option is available for audio system and connectivity.

Looks:

Sculpted panels on coupe and a diving front end give it a ready-for-action stance.
Dash curves efficiently toward the driver.
Multiple blue-lit displays take some getting used to.

New for 2014

All-new CVT (continuously variable transmission) offers quicker smoother acceleration and better fuel efficiency on equipped models.

title: 2014 Honda Ridgeline
subTitle: Unique utility.
promoTeaserSmall: Unique utility.
promoTeaser: Unique utility.
metaDescription: 2014 Honda Ridgeline: Unique utility. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Honda Ridgeline is Honda’s unorthodox take on a pickup truck. Of course, different doesn’t have to be bad, as the Ridgeline stands out from other pickups on the market with a design that gives it the air of an SUV with a chunk missing.  It bucks another pickup tradition by being the only mid-size truck on the market with a cab and truck bed built in one piece, meaning that the sections don’t bounce around separately while driving.  This gives the Ridgeline a smoother ride than most of its rivals, while still maintaining the convenience of an open-bed truck. It is, however, significantly more expensive than many of its competitors, with a base price range in the $30,000s. The Ridgeline has a one choice of engine, a 250-horsepower V-6, and is rated to tow 5,000 pounds. Another desirable feature is the standard four-wheel drive. It has four doors and two rows of seats, so the Ridgeline can seat five, although the cabin is not appointed quite as well as the rest of Honda’s fleet. As if the Ridgeline needed any more cargo space, there is a lockable in-bed trunk with 8.5 cubic feet of storage for anything you don’t want flying around the truck bed.  Reliability and good driving character are the hallmarks of Honda vehicles, and the Ridgeline follows suit.  Opt for the Sport edition to add some welcome style to an already competent and roomy utility vehicle.

Competitors:

Toyota Tacoma
Nissan Frontier

Cool Tech:

In-bed trunk locks up your tools.
Standard rearview camera.

Looks:

Half SUV, half truck looks like nothing else on the road.
Black mesh grille on Sport model adds some flash.

New for 2014:

A new special black trimmed edition adds some much needed visual appeal.

title: Nissan Smart Rearview Mirror
subTitle: Brilliant invention! The mirror is an LCD monitor, using a rearview camera for perfect visibility.
promoTeaserSmall: Brilliant invention! The mirror is an LCD monitor, using a rearview camera for perfect visibility.
promoTeaser: Brilliant invention! The mirror is an LCD monitor, using a rearview camera for perfect visibility.
metaDescription: Nissan Smart Rearview Mirror: Brilliant invention! The mirror is an LCD monitor, using a rearview camera for perfect visibility. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: Anyone who drives with a big dog in the back seat will want to give Nissan a pat on the head for inventing the Smart Rearview Mirror. The dog, too, will probably want to give it a happy lick. Here’s how driving with that dog goes now: "Sit down!” I say urgently to the dog who, although safely ensconced in the back of the car, is completely blocking the (already made too small by aerodynamic car designs) view out the back. I want to keep my eye on the neighborhood boys as they race past on bikes, but the dog has his own worries. “Huh, huh, huh?” he says, concerned by the urgency in my voice but struggling with that canine inability to sit still while the ground moves under him. He looms closer, now completely blocking my view.

Here's where Nissan's invention would save the day. With the flick of a switch, what looks like a normal rearview mirror instantly transforms into an LCD screen that shows everything, with no obstructions. How? It shows a feed from a high-resolution camera that's embedded in the back of the car, just above the rear window.

The Smart rearview mirror increases visibility even when the dog stays home, since it bypasses the glass of the rear mirror, which can fog up, get dirty, or be covered in ice or snow. And in some low-visibility conditions, the camera gets a better view than the mirror can, because it does a bit of image processing to reduce glare and enhance crispness. This subtitled video from Nissan shows how easily it works.
<iframe width="500" height="281" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/2yxHAj79kh8" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Nissan will officially introduce the Smart Rearview Mirror at the Geneva Auto Show this week. After that, it will be used in the company's Nismo racing car for the 24 Hours of Le Mans and will be a dealer-installed option on Japan-market Nissans this spring. It won't start reaching buyers elsewhere in the world until 2015. We can't wait.

images.caption: A clearer view than you're used to: Nissan Smart Rearview Mirror in a parking garage.
View from the Nissan Smart Rearview Mirror is thanks to a rearview camera.
A simple flick of the wrist is all it takes to switch from "normal" to awesome.
Glare and other drivers' lights are compensated for.
Nissan draws you a picture to make sure you see how the Smart Rearview MIrror works.

title: The Weekly Windup!
subTitle: Corvettes get out of sinkhole (#2). Consumers get into one (#7). Plus the Rabbit Hole of Cold (#3)!
promoTeaserSmall: Corvettes get out of sinkhole (#2). Consumers get into one (#7). Plus the Rabbit Hole of Cold (#3)!
promoTeaser: Corvettes get out of sinkhole (#2). Consumers get into one (#7). Plus the Rabbit Hole of Cold (#3)!
metaDescription: Corvettes get out of a sinkhole (#2), while consumers get into one (#7). All this, plus the Rabbit Hole of Cold (#3), in this week's Windup. Read 'em all on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
1. Subaru WRX STI vs. Stick Bomb: I had never heard of a StickBomb, but now I am obsessed. See the behind-the-scenes video; it is just as mesmerizing.

Now you need to see the details on StickBombs.
2. Sinkhole Saga: You can follow the recovery process from the sinkhole at the Corvette Museum. I keep thinking that it is going to suddenly swallow up the recovery team.
3. Rabbit hole of cold: 30,000 miles of winter in a Land Rover Discovery for the Pole of Cold Expedition. Seriously fascinating stories of living in extreme cold.
4. Ninety-Eight is the new fifty-eight. Evelyn fights the man to get her driver’s license back.
5. You decide: Is vulgarly violating Vipers a PR blunder for Chrysler?
6. Jay Leno’s retirement may be a win for car enthusiasts.
7. Is this exciting news or depressing? One in five new-car buyers is stretching that loan over six years or more.
8. This is for the children. Remember that.
Dog photo: rsester/iStock/ThinkStock

title: Crash Test Live
subTitle: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too! Ford invited us.
promoTeaserSmall: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too! Ford invited us.
promoTeaser: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too! Ford invited us.
metaDescription: Crash Test Live: Ever want to see a car smashed into a barrier, with a dummy at the wheel? Us, too--and Ford invited us.

pageElements.text:
Photos by Molly Jean

Cross another one off the bucket list: I got to see a real live crash test. Call me weird, but I have kind of always wanted to see a brand-new car smacked into a wall with a crash test dummy seated behind the wheel, and Ford invited me to do just that. It was partly in celebration of the automaker’s 20,000th (!) live crash test, dating back to 1954, and partly to celebrate a 50 percent increase in the computer power Ford is dedicating to the study of crash data.

It was fascinating to meet some crash test dummies up close, although it was extremely jarring (and loud) to watch a 2014 Ford Explorer smacked head-on into a rigid barrier at 30 mph. But it was also very informative, and here are five questions I got answered while having the experience.

1. Do they really have to wreck actual vehicles?

Yes! That’s the best way to get accurate and useful data that ensures that worldwide safety standards are met. But Ford does about 10,000 computer simulations, like the one shown in the video clip below, for every live crash. The computer simulates tests of roof strength and safety systems as well as front, side, and rear impact crashes. Each simulation measures two million elements, which is up from 500,000 only five years ago. Simulations also let the automaker check out various vehicle designs to see how they work out for safety.

2. How many crash tests do they do at Ford?

Worldwide, Ford has crashed more than 31,000 cars. The company has a team of more than 500 engineers dedicated to safety, and there are crash test labs in Germany, Australia, and Brazil as well as the one in Dearborn, Michigan, where the Explorer shown here met its fate. At Ford’s Crash Barrier Building, they crash two or three cars a day—up to 800 a year.

The types of tests include the one we saw, a perpendicular front impact into a rigid barrier at 30 mph, but also overlap, offset, and side impact tests, including vehicle side impacts into a rigid pole.

3. How do the engineers gather information—other than from looking at the smashed-up front end?

The Ford team can download all the test data from a crashed vehicle within thirty minutes from impact—a much better use of modern computer speeds than Angry Birds, don’t you think? Each crashed car has a plethora of switches, accelerometers, and high-speed digital video cameras on board to give up to thirty views of a single test, which will be slowed down for analysis. In fact, we were shown a Science Fair in Hell table covered with a tangle of intimidating-looking data devices of the type they use.

Up to 300 data channels from “data acquisition electronics” are carried on the test vehicle; they measure acceleration, force, and displacement. Obviously, all of them are “sophisticated, crash-hardened devices,” in the words of test operations engineering supervisor Jerome Ng, so the equipment can be reused on future tests. In fact, they’re packed to be able to survive shocks up to 100 G in force.
There was an unmistakable feeling of geek camaraderie in the building: smart people breaking up perfectly good new vehicles in quest of knowledge.

4. What do they learn from the dummies, beyond checking to see if their heads were knocked off?

The dummies are not just department-store mannequins, which is obvious, but did you realize that even their clothing and shoes meet specific test standards? They are stuffed with instrumentation from head to toe—with up to 100 instruments inside a single dummy, including sensors and accelerometers—and tested and certified for consistency before they ever ride inside a crash-test vehicle. Ford has a fleet of more than 100 crash test dummies, ranging from a three-year-old to a 95th percentile adult male.

5. What are all the markings on the dummies and cars?

The one I immediately wondered about was the artistic splatter-paint finish on the Explorer. Ng explained that the shiny surface of a brand-new Ford Explorer would make it hard to see body deformation, dings, or other damage in a crash test—thus the mottled, matte-finish paint job. The markings on the crash vehicle were more obvious: identifying numbers on the sides, tire pressures on the wheel wells, and painted-on markings as points of reference when pre- and post-crash changes to the vehicle are being checked. And then, on the dummies, there’s paint in areas where the dummy might make contact with a surface, so it’s easy to see what smacked into what.

images.caption: Senior editor Molly Jean (second from right) with Ford's crash test dummy family.
Something tells me this car and this handsome dummy face are going to go through some changes.
Goodbye, 2014 Ford Explorer! Photos by Molly Jean.
Jerome Ng, supervisor of full data testing, stands where the Explorer will soon be making impact.
Markings and swirly paint job help Ford figure out exactly what's happening to the vehicle body on impact.
That's not just a ribcage: it's a plethora of safety measurement equipment.
Here is a bunch of Ford's data-gathering equipment.
The poignant post-crash raised hand position of the driver dummy will no doubt be measured and quantified by Ford's team.

pageElements.text: My little outing to the Crash Barrier Building was good fun, but it was also immensely reassuring to see the graphic evidence that automakers are this focused on safety. Of course they are not doing it out of missionary zeal but because they have standards they are required to meet—what Ford’s global auto safety director, Steve Kenner, called “the global regulatory environment.” But there was also an unmistakable feeling of geek camaraderie in the building: smart people breaking up perfectly good new vehicles in quest of knowledge. Now that I’ve crossed that crash test off my bucket list, I have a new daydream, one in which I hear one of my kids tell me, “I want to smash up brand-new cars for a living.”

title: A Classic-Chevy Bonanza in Nebraska
promoTeaserSmall: Elderly ex-dealer offers hundreds of Chevrolets at auction. Is this Norman Rockwell or Hoarders?
promoTeaser: Elderly ex-dealer offers hundreds of Chevrolets at auction. Is this Norman Rockwell or Hoarders?
metaTitle: A Classic-Chevy Bonanza in Nebraska - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Classic-Chevy Bonanza in Nebraska: Hundreds of old Chevrolets, many never driven or owned before, and many more left out in a field untended, are up for auction this weekend. See some of them at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: It was probably the 1950s for quite a bit longer in small-town Nebraska than anywhere else in the country...but still: the Chevrolet dealer in tiny Pierce, Nebraska, a mom-and-pop operation since 1946, held on to hundreds of Fifties and Sixties Chevys, many of them never driven. Years have passed; Lambrecht Chevrolet closed its doors in 1996 and left a huge inventory right where it was. All these years, the cars have been kept, but not well cared for. And just like that, like a Fifties dream deferred, Mom and Pop realized they are now in their nineties and it's time to cash them in.

So the Lambrecht Chevrolet collection, nearly 500 cars and trucks, is up for auction this weekend. Previews are happening Friday, September 27, with a live auction to follow on Saturday and Sunday. Some 10,000 people are expected to flock to this village about 130 miles northwest of Omaha. Many of them will come with trailers, but online bidding is sure to be frenetic as well, and the Chevys will surely disperse to the four corners of the world right afterward. Imagine the circus that will be downtown Pierce this weekend. Lemonade stands, sidewalk sales, and all kinds of outside commerce are sure to make a great news story--and to leave the town in a bit of shock for months afterward.

You've got to ask: How did this happen? Having read the biography of Ray P. Lambrecht by his daughter, titled The Man behind the Legend, I think it's a Norman Rockwell painting mixed with an episode of "Hoarders." Apparently Lambrecht, home from the Aleutians after his tour of World War II duty, married his pre-war sweetheart, built them a house in Pierce, then opened up a Chevy dealership across the street. He only wanted to sell the brand-newest Chevrolets, so when he took cars as trade-ins, he just parked them out back and left them there untouched. For decades.

Likewise, he picked out some cars that he especially liked and never sold them at all. These are the ones the collectors are salivating over: cars with less than ten miles on the odometer, never titled. The collector blogosphere has been blowing up for weeks: Will these be sold to wealthy foreign collectors who will restore them? Will they be kept as is, dust, mold, and all, like a Mouton Rothschild bottle in the wine cellar? Is this guy a genius or a villain? The latter designation comes to mind because he left so many cars out in a field until trees grew through them. I do wonder: Why didn't he put these in a bunch of garages or pole barns? Why didn't he hire somebody to keep them in running condition? Instead, his faithful sole mechanic, the guy who worked at the dealership all those years, kept people from stealing them and, apparently, didn't do much else. He has passed on, and reportedly vandals have been stealing the chrome and radiators off the untended cars. So, as I said, a fascinating story that's really kind of sad.

Now, I was born in 1957, and I suppose I look about as fashionable and current as some of these dust-covered, tailfin-spouting Bel Airs. I hope I have at least as much retro charm as my favorite at this auction: a 1958 Chevrolet Cameo Pickup in turquoise with 1.3 miles on the odometer, which was never issued a title. That one, shown at the top of this page, has already been bidded up to $46,000 in pre-auction online action, although all of the cars will be sold live.
This auction is too fascinating not to watch. Here's where you can see it online live, starting at 9:30 a.m. Central on Saturday: VanDerBrink Auctions.

title: What I Drove Last Weekend!
promoTeaserSmall: (and other things that happened)…
promoTeaser: (and other things that happened)…
metaTitle: What I Drove Last Weekend! - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: What I Drove Last Weekend! A brief rundown of my activities on the weekend of September 29-30. Read it and see the snapshots on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Friday shouldn’t have been so chaotic. I was going to drive to Midland, in northern Michigan, to be on a panel discussion at Northwood University. Northwood is a jewel of a little school, most known for a curriculum that tunes students to be players in the retail end of the car biz. Every fall for the past fifty years, the students at Northwood put on a weekend that begins with the VIP panel and ends with a car show on the campus mall. I looked forward to this weekend all year, but suddenly discovered that the fourth Santa Fe Concorso would be honoring Denise McCluggage, and I needed to be there.

There was one answer: drive two hours north, be on the 10:30 a.m. panel, blow out of there like a freight train at high noon, book it two hours to Detroit Metro, catch a flight to Denver, jump on one of those flying cigar tubes to Santa Fe, and get a rental.

Car #1: Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Kia Cadenza Four Seasons Test Car

It made swift and sure transport for the four-hour round trip. I paired my phone, plugged it into the USB port, and quickly sorted out how to toggle between my iPhone playlist and the nav.

I did have one fistfight with the nav, when it spit me off the Interstate and onto forty miles of two-lanes running past cornfield after cornfield in the fertile outback south of Midland. The pitch black night was interrupted every few seconds by a synchronized flashing grid of red lights about 300 feet in the air, stretching for what looked like miles to the left and right of me. What the…

Aha. I’d not seen them at night, but it was the massive wind turbines—133 of them, stretching across 30,000 acres in rural Gratiot County—that had gone up over the past two years. I was looking at the aircraft warning lights atop the 330-foot towers. It was mesmerizing and worth the detour.

This Cadenza rings the cash register at $41,950. That’s a long way from the 2004 Kia Rio my brother owns. Ten years ago, Kia meant cheapo transpo. Now, they are stylish and nosing into the high-roller club. Still, I was dressed like a schlub. I had cleaned my house, paid the bills, and packed for the long trip before jumping in the car to head north. I was wearing jeans, a sweatshirt, a Detroit Tigers World Championship jacket, and flip-flops. This is a typical outfit for driving north to the cabin in the woods. Of course, the minute I arrived at the lovely H hotel in Midland, the head of Toyota, Jim Lentz, and his wife, Barbara, stepped from the back of a chauffeured sedan, dressed to the nines for dinner. The Kia looked elegant, though. (Reminder to self: Always dress for first-class travel in case they need to upgrade someone.) It was extra exciting for me to discover that I’d left the entire outfit (including shoes and jewelry) I’d planned to wear for my VIP morning hanging back home in the closet.

The subject of my remarks could be summed up thus: The automotive industry is awash in testosterone, and women would rather put their eyes out with steel needles than buy a new car or have it serviced. Jim Lentz made sure to attend. I’m sure my outfit from the previous evening suddenly made perfect sense.

Car #2: A Rental Chevrolet Impala

Nothing strikes fear in the heart of a frequent flyer more than finding out that all legs of the multi-leg adventure ahead will be handled by “our alliance partners,” as the tiny prison ships of the sky were called by the man checking me in at United. Then he said: “What the heck is Great Lakes Aviation doing in New Mexico? We’re the Great Lakes state.” For the record, Great Lakes Aviation was fine. And even though there was a two-hour delay in Denver, the Hertz counter was still open when we arrived in Santa Fe for the Concorso. With all of our bags.

The old Impala—although not as inspiring as the new one—makes an exceptional rental car. Hertz, however, ought to clean its car windows. The Impala felt tight for its 15,000-plus miles and had decent acceleration at 7,500 feet above sea level, and the steering wheel had no slop in it. There was a funny moment when our friend from Mercedes-Benz decided to forgo her sexy SLS cabrio press car and ride with us in the Impala to the tony grounds of the Club at Las Campanas for the Concorso, so she could share her VIP parking pass with us. The journalist riding with her took one look at us and said, “No.” Just like that. “No.” And talked his way in, which is probably something we couldn’t have done without that red VIP pass.

Car #3: A 2014 Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT Roadster

The day before the Concorso, we found the First Lady of Racing, the honoree of the weekend, and my personal role model and heroine, Denise McCluggage, waiting at the start of the ninety-mile Mountain Tour for participants in Sunday’s show. Sir Stirling and Lady Susie Moss were there to lead the tour in the Roadster, but she had a thought in the night.
“You know, it’s been twenty-five years since you and Stirling did the Pirelli Classic Marathon in the MGB. Wouldn’t it be fun if you drove him this time?”
Hilarious. I could call him a stupid cow this time, and he could yell at me to stop tanning, put my shirt back on, and get back in the car. Hahaha.
He wasn’t laughing.

Until I write that particular story, let me just say that it was 38 degrees when we left, and we left the top down. I cannot praise Airscarf enough. With the heated seats on full burn, the side windows up, and the wind blocker behind us, the appropriately named Airscarf blew a constant stream of warm air around our necks. It was so warm in our open roadster that we actually dialed back on butt and neck warming.

The car show was a little gem of fabulosity, a “boutique” show as Lady Moss calls it. She and Stirling have been at all four. Other racing celebs included Norman Dewis, 93, who developed and tested every C-type, D-type, and XK-SS while at Jaguar, and Alma Hill, the woman who married America’s only Formula 1 world champion, Phil. Her son Derek was a judge, as was Al Unser, Sr.
Dale Chihuly, the extraordinary glass artist, brought his Austin Healey and did an art installation in the midst of the grounds.
More on that to come. Stay tuned.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Spark 2LT
promoTeaserSmall: It's small, cheap, not bad-looking...did I mention small? But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: It's small, cheap, not bad-looking...did I mention small? But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Chevrolet Spark 2LT: I think this minicar has many good qualities that belie its size. Still, it's tiny all right! What does the Peanut Gallery think? Read our reviews on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $15,895 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.2-liter four-cylinder, 84 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual
Fuel economy: 32 mpg city/38 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Chevrolet MyLink
Option I can’t live without: There were no options on board!
You might also be considering: Fiat 500, Honda Fit, Smart Fortwo, Scion iQ, Toyota Yaris

See more specs on the Chevrolet Spark lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

How does a serious small-car buyer choose a size and type of car these days? It’s not hard to make a—you should excuse the expression—short list. The problem is in deciding on the many tradeoffs. There’s no shortage of cars in the subcompact segment and even the sub-subcompact niche. You’ve got your Mini Coopers, which are charming and sporty. But they can be as expensive as a much larger car, putting them more in the category of a second or third car to own for fun. If you’re going small at least partly to be frugal and not just to be fashionable, it might be out of your price range. You’ve got your Smart Fortwo, which is undeniably cheap and fuel-efficient but comically tiny; the Scion iQ and Fiat 500 are a little more reasonable—but only a little. Going up a bit in size, you’ll find the Honda Fit and the Toyota Yaris, which have more of a standard silhouette, along with decent-size engines and horsepower—but lower fuel economy to match.

And then there’s the Chevrolet Spark. This is a car that straddles the tiny space between these other tiny cars. You get your cheap price and your fuel economy; you enjoy a certain amount of sporty style. Yet you don’t feel like you’ve been folded up inside a suitcase. As my eighteen-year-old son Henry exclaimed the first time he climbed in, “It’s actually like a real car inside!”

How much like a real car? To find out, Henry and I embarked on a 200-mile round trip visit to that arbiter of all purchase wisdom, my dad. (You’ve met him before on a Buick LaCrosse car-testing expedition.) Yes, we careened up I-94 through pothole-rich Detroit in a Spark. It was an adventure! I did try to psych myself out a bit by murmuring to myself, “This is a normal-size car. This is a normal-size car. This is just as big as the other cars around me.” It was okay; Henry had his earphones in.

Seriously, though, the Spark was capable of meeting and even exceeding the 70-mph speed limit, providing as smooth a ride and as strong a performance as you have any right to expect from a 2,237-pound car on a 93.5-inch wheelbase with an 84-horsepower engine under the cute little hood. The five-speed manual transmission was smooth and enjoyable to use once we exited onto the surface roads of our destination. (Consumer Reports said the manual is to be preferred over the jerky automatic in this car, but I didn't try the automatic-transmission version, so I couldn't judge.)

And when we hauled ourselves up onto the solid ground of my dad’s driveway, what do you suppose his reaction was? Something along the lines of, “What is THAT!?!” and “You expect me to fit in here?” The candy-colored Spark did look faintly ridiculous in the suburban driveway, but I had already grown to like it.

I just laughed, knowing that I would indeed get my dad into the passenger’s seat of the Spark, and he’d end up having the same reaction Henry had.  Sure enough, the next morning we headed out to the Four Star, our favorite breakfast joint, and I enjoyed the feeling of parking the Spark next to a mammoth-looking Honda Accord and having plenty of room inside the white lines. My colleagues thought the front seating area was narrow and cramped. That didn't bother me, and it was no problem for my eighty-five-year-old father to get in or to get comfortable inside. Plus, he was impressed by the fuel economy numbers and the low price.

But Frank Brown is not the target demographic: This South Korea-sourced Chevrolet is the first minicar the GM division brought to North America, and it’s marketed for “young city dwellers.” Accordingly, it has a lot of electronics for such a small car. The standard MyLink infotainment system has a seven-inch screen, Bluetooth streaming audio,  SiriusXM satellite radio, and embedded Pandora and Stitcher apps. Henry figured it all out instantly and had nothing but praise for the display and the ease of use.

The Spark also spares you from some of the penalty details you’d have a right to expect from an entry-level car: there are power windows on all trim levels,  it has a flip-and-fold rear seat that opens up 31.2 cubic feet of storage space in back, and GM’s StabiliTrak system with traction control and brake assist is standard. There’s even a rear spoiler.  And when I took three members of the Jean Knows Cars team on an outing, it seated us all in pleasant comfort. (In the photo at top, you can see how well Annie White fit in the back seat, even though she’s way taller than I am.)

Henry complimented the Spark’s looks compared with, say, the Smart or the Scion, and he’s got a point. Although it comes in fruity shades including Jalapeno, Lemonade, and Techno Pink, the Spark has enough edges on it to keep from looking too much like a rolling jellybean. That almost makes up for the Oreo-cookie-size fifteen-inch wheels.
Why all the candy metaphors? I guess because driving the Spark was enough fun to knock a few decades off my mental age—at least while I was behind the wheel.

The Verdict:

A minicar like the Spark is not an impulse purchase, despite the tempting price point. You need to do some soul-searching first. Are you really prepared to drive something this small? Yes, four people do fit pretty nicely. There’s a decent amount of storage space. It’s not that this is not a functional and even a nice car. I’m talking about how it will feel, day in and day out, to be in a car that’s notably smaller than the other traffic around you. If that feels okay to you, and especially if you have already worked that out and are actively city-car shopping, don’t pick one based on trendy ads or word of mouth alone. The Chevy Spark may not be the hippest nameplate out there, but don’t make your final choice until you’ve had a spin in this one.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: On my first drive in the Spark, I kept mistakenly starting out in third gear. Then I realized that because first and second gears are so far left the armrest was getting in my way. Once I quit using the armrest, the gear pattern was much easier. However, driving a car this tiny with a manual can be a problem for the front seat passenger. I kept having to remind my daughter to leave me room to shift. Its sensibility reminds me of the Chevette: great price, reasonably cute, fun to drive. I will be interested to see how this little spark plug does in NHTSA's crash tests.

Annie: The Spark has a lot going for it—unique styling, good fuel economy, good infotainment—but its main characteristic will always be its diminutive size. The car is so narrow that the steering wheel obscures the driver's view of the center console, and two adults sitting in the front row will be bumping elbows. I wouldn't buy a Spark because I'm more likely to take four people on a road trip than I am to try to squeeze into a subcompact parallel parking space, but for city dwellers who can't get by with Zipcar, the Spark could be just the econobox they're looking for.

title: The Rearview Camera Fight
promoTeaserSmall: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that.
promoTeaser: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that.
metaKeywords: Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act
Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety
metaDescription: The Rearview Camera Fight: Should backup cameras be required? Safety groups, parents, and automakers are quarreling over that. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The story of Cameron Gulbransen’s preventable tragedy is one that should touch every parent. The two-year-old woke up past his bedtime on a Saturday night, clutched his blankie, and wandered outside. Dr. Greg Gulbransen, a pediatrician, was backing his BMW X5 out of the driveway when he accidentally backed over his son and killed him.

That happened more than twelve years ago, and it's horrible to say, but little has changed, at least in the law. This terrible tragedy has gone on to happen to a lot of other people. Backing up a large vehicle is just not foolproof, especially if someone as small as a toddler is directly behind it where he or she can't be seen by mirrors.

But, you say, what about rearview cameras? Aha. Yes, Gulbransen has become a staunch advocate since his son's death, both for rearview cameras and for federal standards to mandate better rear visibility for vehicles. He had some success when, in 2008, the Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act was signed into law, mandating better rear visibility through rearview cameras on cars, among other things.
If you didn't realize that such a law was in place, that's because implementation has been repeatedly delayed, and the rule is not now scheduled to go into effect until 2015.

Gulbransen, along with safety advocates and another parent, Susan Auriemma, who backed over her three-year-old daughter in her driveway in 2005, sued the U.S. Department of Transportation in late September.

The lawsuit asks the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to direct the DOT to issue a mandatory rear visibility rule by the end of the year. The advocacy group Public Citizen is representing the plaintiffs in the suit. They are Gulbransen, Auriemma, the Consumers Union of the United States, Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety, and Kids And Cars, Inc., represented in the action by Public Citizen.

“Our federal government, whose job it is to make sure we have safe vehicles to drive, needs to recognize this all too real problem and begin to inform the public about these dangers, and the automobile manufacturers need to install technology that has proven to be effective and would help warn drivers that something is behind their vehicle before backing up,” said Gulbransen.

You won't be surprised to hear that the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers opposes the law. Twelve automakers, including BMW, Chrysler, and Ford, are members of this group. The AAM sent out a Tweet saying the group believes the "decision to buy such cameras should be consumers’.” Industry experts say the addition of such cameras would add to the sticker price of vehicles.

Federal safety regulators insist they are not standing still, despite the many delays in implementing the law. The federal government last week said it will add rearview video systems to its  "recommended" features list in the New Car Assessment Program.
Safety advocates aren't buying that.

“It is time to stop delaying and start solving a dangerous safety problem with a technology that is available and absolutely essential to saving lives,” said Jackie Gillian, president of the Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will identify on www.safercar.gov vehicle models that have rearview video systems. It said it is making the move while it “researches implementation of a rear visibility rule.”

While the two sides duke it out in the courtroom, industry experts say that standard rearview camera systems are starting to become commonplace on vehicles. Such systems are available on seven in ten new vehicles, according to some industry estimates.
We'll be watching the progress of this lawsuit, fully aware that this not the only piece of momentous legislation being held up even though it has been signed into law.

Related Stories

title: Another Alarming Teen Driver Study
promoTeaserSmall: More to worry about! Teen accidents are much more likely when friends are in the car, a study shows.
promoTeaser: More to worry about! Teen accidents are much more likely when friends are in the car, a study shows.
metaTitle: Another Alarming Teen Driver Study - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Another Alarming Teen Driver Study: More to worry about! Teen accidents are much more likely when friends are in the car, a study shows.  Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Thinking about teenagers out on the road can scare a parent on the best day. But there might be a good reason for feeling alarmed: researchers at the Texas A&M Transportation Institute are out with a new study about teen drivers that has some less-than-encouraging statistics.

New research shows that novice teenage drivers, those ages fifteen to seventeen, are about eight times more likely than young adult drivers, those ages eighteen to twenty-four, to have a fatal crash if teenage passengers are in the car.
Driver distraction, especially the explosion in text messaging by young drivers, may be behind the dismal statistic.

Institute researchers say they looked at ten years of national data on fatal crashes in which teen passengers were present at the time of the crash. Researchers then compared patterns for novice drivers with those of young adult drivers to arrive at a “relative risk index.” Basically, the research shows that the younger the driver, the greater the risk. And, unfortunately, the problem is growing.
For novice drivers carrying two or more passengers in 2011, the teen passenger/fatal crash connection was 7.7 times more likely, up from 5.9 a decade earlier – an increase of 30 percent.

“Researchers did not explore reasons behind the upward trend,” the institute said. “However, the study points out that the ten-year period of analysis essentially mirrors the time when text messaging grew from an occasional activity to a practice that now largely defines youth culture.”

Young teen drivers also must overcome other safety hurdles. They include an overall lack of driving experience, along with slow brain development.
“Judgment and decision-making activities are centered in the prefrontal cortex of the brain, the region of the brain that is the last to develop and isn’t fully developed until about age twenty-five,” the institute noted. “Consequently, teen drivers lack full adult capabilities of understanding and avoiding the negative consequences of risky driving behavior.”

A recent YouTube video by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration advises parents to “find a way–any way” to lay down the law when it comes to safe driving. The video shows parents hiring an attorney to develop a driving “contract” for their son that includes such restrictions as “no cell phone use.”

But what power do parents really have to keep their kids safe? First of all, focus on the very real problem. American teenagers are more likely to die in a car crash than by any other means, according to U.S. Centers for Disease Control statistics.

Check out the CDC Teen Drivers Fact Sheet, which says that comprehensive graduated driver licensing, or GDL, programs are associated with reductions of 38 and 40 percent in fatal and injury crashes, respectively, among sixteen-year-old drivers. This is good news, but let's think about why that's the case. It's because a full license is delayed while teenagers get their initial driving experience under low-risk conditions.
“When parents know their state’s GDL laws, they can help enforce the laws and, in effect, help keep their teen drivers safe,” the CDC says.

As parents, let's go beyond just handing over the car keys. Let's pay attention to what our teenagers are allowed to do (and not allowed to do) under graduated licensing laws and reinforce that with talk, rules, and even contracts (here are some examples, from Toyota, the National Safety Council, and CDC).

But beyond that, we can think about why graduated licensing helps cut risks to inexperienced drivers. It is, in effect, a way for teens to get valuable experience behind the wheel while limiting such potentially dangerous behaviors such as late-night driving and ferrying a car full of other teenagers. Let them spend some of that time with you instead. During this probationary period, we should not stop setting a good example behind the wheel, spending time in the car with our teens while they drive, and finding opportunities to continue teaching safe driving techniques while they get their first few hundred miles in.

So, parents, let's put our own cell phones away, stop driving distracted, and set a good example. Let's mentor our kids during their early driving years, and let's also focus on being the drivers we want our kids to be.

title: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Has Your Back
promoTeaserSmall: All sizes of people should find the new sedan's seating comfy, thanks to extensive testing.
promoTeaser: All sizes of people should find the new sedan's seating comfy, thanks to extensive testing.
metaTitle: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Has Your Back - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Impala Has Your Back: General Motors engineers studied all sizes of rear ends to make the big Chevy's seats just right. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: I’m probably not the only person who has arrived at a rest area after a long stint behind the wheel to feel my back snap, crackle, or pop on that walk to the bathroom. If an uncomfortable seat has ever been part of your driving experience, you'll appreciate that the human factors engineers at General Motors had your spine in mind when they designed the seats for the new 2014 Chevrolet Impala.  By marrying state-of the-art technology with low-tech methods, GM aimed to design a seat that comfortably accommodates everyone from Kristin Chenoweth to Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson and every BMI in between.

Call it the Goldilocks approach.  GM asked volunteer testers to spend hundreds of hours, over thousands of miles, in prototype vehicles evaluating seat comfort and providing feedback. The testers spanned the range of human configuration, from petite women at five feet tall and 110 pounds to men reaching upward of six feet or more and weighing in at 223 pounds.  After sixty minutes in the driver’s seat, each was asked to go beyond the fairy-tale-like measurements of too hard, too soft, and just right and numerically rate the comfort level of all the seat’s components: cushion, back rest, lumbar support, head rest, and side bolsters.  Of course, one person’s ten is another person’s “get me to a chiropractor," so that’s where biomechanics come in.

You're Sitting on 4,600 Data Points Right Now

Engineers gave testers’ brains a rest in order to enlist another part of the anatomy, their behinds. By sitting people of various builds in prototype seats blanketed with state-of-the-art digital pressure-mapping technology, engineers were able to create a map of more than 4,600 data points along the seat surface. That massive collection of data was then used to illustrate the driver’s experience either at rest or in the act of operating the vehicle.

A Little Help from Oscar

Arriving at the most comfortable seat design by combining hard data with testers’ personal feedback is what Jill Green, GM seat comfort lab manager, describes as “both an art and a science.” That includes another GM technology, employed in the early days of the Impala’s cabin design, known as Oscar. This metal and plastic mannequin-like tool weighs up to 170 pounds. It has a head, legs, a torso, and the ability to be reconfigured, which allows engineers determine interior dimensions to suit a wide array of human shapes and sizes.

After discovering all the effort that went into the Chevy’s seats, I couldn’t resist stopping by a local dealer to sit my own unique derrière in an Impala.  My first impression was a comfy, supportive feel, which became heavenly repose once I found the power eight-way seat adjuster and the four-way lumbar controls. These customizing controls come standard on every 2014 Impala, from the $27,670 LS base model up to the top-end $37,625 2LTZ.  Now that’s a feature I can get behind.

title: The Weekly Windup!
promoTeaserSmall: Flying cars, Chrysler homages, Forza Motorsport 5, a Honda feud...all part of your complete weekend.
promoTeaser: Flying cars, Chrysler homages, Forza Motorsport 5, a Honda feud...all part of your complete weekend.
metaDescription: The Weekly Windup! News about Honda, Chrysler, Forza Motorsport 5, flying cars, Chevrolet Malibu, and the Detroit Tigers

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Here are a few things we ran across on the way to finding what we were looking for. Go ahead, click on them and let these random items sidetrack you like they sidetracked us. It's fun.
1. Chrysler gives a shout out to one of our Detroit Tigers. Do you think that means the Boston fans will shy away from Pentastar products?
2. Only one more year until we can live the Jetsons life.

3. How the Xbox game Forza Motorsport 5 made the driving experience so close to the real thing.
And the math behind it.
4. You know how some people will go to great lengths to make a point? Well, this urban cyclist wants everyone to see the perils of riding in the bike lane.
5. Chrysler has launched a new design contest for Michigan high school students. It is nice to see an automaker invest in the designers of tomorrow.
6. Are you driving less than you used to? Popular Science’s infographic illustrates a startling trend.
7. Honda is feuding on Twitter with the snack food industry.
8. The New York Daily News did a really nice job of showcasing the Chevrolet Malibu’s 50th birthday.
9. Bottom line, I just like these car photos from the past.
10. And to close out this weekend's list, here's a story about a zombie car. In China. Yes, you heard me right.

title: Ford Mustang's Colorful History
promoTeaserSmall: From lurid to lascivious to gorgeous: an appreciation of the pony-car's hues through the years.
promoTeaser: From lurid to lascivious to gorgeous: an appreciation of the pony-car's hues through the years.
metaKeywords: historical paint color choices for cars
metaDescription: Ford Mustang's Colorful History: From the lurid to the lascivious to the gorgeous, here's a brief history of the pony-car's hues. Read about it (and admire the cars) on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: The Ford Mustang is an American icon. Since 1964, kids have pinned up posters of the muscle car on their bedroom walls and saved paper route money in hopes of getting their very own pony. Perhaps as important to those dreamers as the car’s sporty lineage was the color they would choose for their perfect Mustang. When I was growing up, red was the obvious paint choice for young drivers lusting after a ‘Stang. But that has not always been the case. Ford released data this week that exposed the Mustang’s color history, and it’s more varied than you might expect.

The data, provided by Marti Auto Works, shows that the all-time most popular color for a Mustang is, yes, red, with 21 percent of all Mustangs sold wearing that attention-grabbing hue. Perhaps more surprising, at least to those of us who don’t remember the 1970s, is that brown is the seventh most popular Mustang color of all time, thanks to a period of intense popularity in that decade. It’s impossible to buy a new brown Mustang today; they haven’t been built since 1989. Green was also popular in the Mustang’s early years, holding a slot as one of the three most popular Mustang colors for much of the late 1960s and early 1970s.

The most popular shade for a new Mustang today is black, gracing 28 percent of 2013 Mustangs. That’s also the color I would choose for my own hypothetical Mustang, thanks mostly to a black 2014 Mustang GT I drove that elicited multiple comparisons to the Batmobile. White, the most popular color for new cars overall, makes up just ten percent of today’s Mustang sales.

Ford maintains that color and personality are crucially important to Mustang buyers. Mustang marketing director Melanie Banker said that Mustang owners want their car’s color to reflect “what they want their Mustang to say to the world about them.” Sadly, “my favorite color is pink” is no longer a sentiment that a Mustang owner can project to the world—which was not the case in 1967, when Ford offered two shades of pink for the muscle car: Dusk Rose and Playboy Pink.

What color would you choose for your Mustang? Eye-gouging Gotta Have It Green? Yellow, the eighth-all-time most popular Mustang tint? Or would you seek out a 2004 SVT Cobra, available in color-shifting Mystichrome? Let us know in the comments below.

images.caption: His and hers pink Mustangs, anybody?
"Vibrant hues." Okay, if that's what you want to call this two-tone Mustang.
Back in the Jimmy Carter era, you might have had harvest gold appliances inside, and a brown Mustang in the garage.

title: A Brief Tour of My Hat Collection
promoTitle: A Brief Tour of My Hat Collection
promoTeaserSmall: A video visit to my personal closet, emphasizing the work of the great local milliner Mr. Song.
promoTeaser: A video visit to my personal closet, emphasizing the work of the great local milliner Mr. Song.
metaTitle: A Brief Tour of My Hat Collection - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Brief Tour of My Hat Collection: A video visit to my personal collection of fine millinery, emphasizing the work of the great Detroit-based milliner Mr. Song. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears.
