pageElements.text: Detroit has earned the distinction of being the most dangerous city in the United States for the past five years in a row, according to Forbes magazine. In fact, it has been referred to as Murder City. However, there are hundreds of thousands of law-abiding citizens who call the Motor City home, and a growing number of them are rising up to the challenge of reinvigorating their hometown. Since Detroit is my closest urban city, I share their mission. So, when I heard about a nighttime bike ride through Detroit, my husband, Tom, and I loaded up a 2014 Ford Explorer, ignored the statistics, and put our faith in mankind instead.

How the Slow Roll Got Started

In 2010, these two guys, Mike MacKool and Jason Hall, were spending most days riding their bikes and playing Call of Duty. One night, after a heavy battle, they realized that their lives revolved around two things: bikes and murder. A few glasses of wine later, the two decided to put their passions together and created a bike club, fittingly named Bikes & Murder. They are quick to point out that it is a different kind of murder, as in “I murdered that sandwich” or “I murdered that job interview.” I am a fan of urban slang, so I was picking up what they were layin’ down.
MacKool (seriously: that is his real name) explained the progression from a bike club to community organizers.

“Bikes & Murder is our roots in cycling," he told me. It's "a bike club we started with a group of guys that we rode and gamed with. It was a small club that ignited our passion for cycling in Detroit and laid the groundwork for everything that came after. The natural progression from bike club to bike advocates brought us to create Detroit Bike City, a bike show/expo/swap meet at Cobo Center. Because we wanted to grow as an organization, we have done everything as Detroit Bike City, our #1, and kept Bikes & Murder as simply a club and apparel company. It is important to us to note that we are more focused on Detroit Bike City than B&M.”

This Is How They Roll

Detroit Bike City hosts a ten-to-twelve-mile bike ride every Monday night in downtown Detroit from March until October, and it's dubbed the Slow Roll. The event rolls deep: more than 1,700 riders have participated in some of their recent rides. It is indeed a slow roll, and since Detroit is quite flat, any bike will do, and pretty much anyone can keep up with the group.

The information on their website is pretty slim, so basically all we knew was to meet at Saint Andrew's Hall at 6:30 p.m. This time, rollers were encouraged to dress up for Halloween, since it was Oct 28. Saint Andrew's Hall is now exclusively a music venue, but it was once home to the Saint Andrew’s Society of Detroit with the mission to provide assistance to fellow Scots and to encourage the love of Scotland through its history, customs, music, literature, and national games. Who knew that the Scottish population is so large in Detroit that they have been organized since 1849? Underneath Saint Andrew's Hall is The Shelter, which also hosts live music. It is credited with being one of Eminem’s first venues. And looks it.

Tom was more worried about lights on our bikes than whether he should dress up as a superhero or a gangster. I ran around town buying enough gadgets and gizmos galore to make us visible to our Canadian neighbors on the other side of the river in Windsor. And I taped a jaunty little hat on top of my helmet so that I was at least partially in character.

Rolling in the Explorer

The Explorer came sans hitch, so we needed to put our vintage mountain bikes in the back. We were straight up impressed with the power seats in the far back that folded into the floor. You can actually fold just one side or both! We needed all the space, so we went for both down.

The middle seats fold forward, and their headrests tuck, so we didn’t need to remove them—sweet. It took a few attempts, but amazingly the bikes fit,  and we only needed to remove the front tire of one bike.

We managed to be rolling toward Detroit on time, which if you knew the two of us is a miracle. I programmed the address into the navigation, connected my phone via Bluetooth, and used the voice commands to select our radio station. This whip was perfect for the mission. Obviously, if I actually owned this ride I would have a bike hitch installed so I could bring a bigger posse. But, truth be told, I was a little nervous to bring my teenage daughter to an event where we would be slow rolling through a town that has packs of stray dogs, murders on many nights, and a reputation for poor response time from first responders.

Yes, I was a little nervous, but mostly excited to be outside my comfort zone. I knew I wasn’t climbing Mount Everest or base jumping off a tall building, but it was still something of a leap of faith.

We paid a man $10 to park the Explorer, even though the sign clearly said $5—that is the way things go in the D. No questions asked. Somehow it feels like he owes you so he will keep an eye on your ride. But mostly, I believe he needed that extra $5 more than we did. We pulled our bikes out and bedazzled them with lights. Our neighbor's Ford Focus had carried three guys and three bikes without a hitch, literally.
It is indeed a slow roll, and since Detroit is quite flat, any bike will do, and pretty much anyone can keep up with the group.

800 Bikes, 600 Costumes

The group assembling in front of Saint Andrew's was a great mix of humanity. It was not a million man march but still a more than healthy crowd for a Monday night when the temperature was hovering in the high thirties. When I asked MacKool afterward, he said 800 riders were in attendance. Many of the bikes were decorated, and I would say that 75 percent of the riders were in costume. The group was a combination of Detroiters and suburbanites, but symbolically, for this night, we were all Detroiters.

The organizers shouted out the rules over a megaphone.
1. Stay right: Cars need to get around the pack.
2. Communicate: Shout out signals, stops, obstructions, etc.
3. Stick together: The tighter the group, the better it can move through the city.
4. Stay alert: Obviously.
5. No littering: They asked us to help police one another.
6. Encourage positivity.
7. Respect: The neighbors, the cars, each other.
8. Be prepared: Spares, helmets, lights.
9. Have fun: duh.
10. Make friends: Meet your fellow riders.
11. Corking: There is a team of marshals positioned at intersections to inform drivers that the group is about to ride through.
12. Wear a helmet: Duh again.
13. Music: Riders who have music need to make sure people can still communicate.
14. Roll slow: This is not a race.

The Roll

I have never ridden a bike in a large group, and certainly never at night. At first it was difficult to ride slowly with bikes all around, but I got into the rhythm pretty quickly. I did feel like I needed to be uber-alert to any pothole in the road, so I wasn’t able to look around as much as I would have liked.

The route took us past four cemeteries, but it was difficult to tell because it was so dark out. Even though it was only eight at night, and we were in central Detroit, there was no one outside—in fact we saw fewer than a dozen residents on our two-hour ride. The roads they chose were actually in good shape, but as we rolled by the neighborhoods it was very post-apocalyptic, with porches falling off houses, boarded-up windows, and lots of empty lots. We did see some homes that were cared for, but it was so dark that the whole ride was surreal.

Elmwood and Mount Elliott Cemeteries

Elmwood Cemetery was the first fully integrated cemetery in the Midwest, and it is the final resting place to many of Detroit’s dignitaries of the 1800s as well as the controversial Detroit mayor (from 1974 to 1994) Coleman Young. As we pedaled by, the darkness loomed ominously, and I wondered if there were any illicit activities taking place in there. I felt oddly safe in the pack, even though I could hear dogs barking in the night.

Next we passed the Mount Elliott Cemetery, also home to Detroit’s movers and shakers of the past whose names are now those of major Detroit streets, including Beaubien, Campau, and Moross. But just as important, it is the home of the Fireman’s Fund monument. It resides within a special section reserved for those who have served their communities as firefighters. But the darkness held all of these monuments as its hostage. We vowed to come during the day, and see exactly what we had missed.

Directly across the street is the Capuchin Monastery and its soup kitchen, which appeared like an oasis in the deserted city.

The Heidelberg Project and My Introduction to Corking

We pedaled within a half block of the Heidelberg Project, folk artist Tyree Guyton’s now famous project that uses everyday, discarded objects to create a two-block area full of color, symbolism, and intrigue. We only knew that we were near because we saw Guyton’s signature polka dots on the street surface. As we rode through the darkness, marshals and the crowd itself patrolled the group, shouting “keep right,” “keep moving,“ “tighten the gap,” etc.

But my very favorite part was the corking. As the group would approach an intersection, volunteers would protect the group from perpendicular traffic. They did so in a gracious manner intended not to infuriate the delayed motorists. Honestly, the working together for the good of the group was so off the chain that it made my eyes well up. Adding to the ambiance, several corkers were dressed as Santa Claus for some reason.

The Slow Rollers I Liked Best

I never stopped smiling as the various decorated bikes and riders would pass us or we would pass them: a recumbent bike that looked like a racing car, Marie Antoinette, a butterfly, various angels, witches, ghouls, Gumby, and Beaker from The Muppet Show. My very favorite rider was a man who I don’t believe was in costume. He sat very upright on a Panama Jack beach cruiser from Huffy that was retrofitted with big high handlebars that had speakers integrated into them. A local Detroit rap station was escorting him along, and every inch of the bike was lit up with LED lights. To me it felt like he was dressed up as Snoop Dogg, and I loved him.

Adding to the festive feeling was the aroma of marijuana that would envelop the group from time to time. I was vigilantly watching for potholes and couldn’t imagine being high as we moved along—but then again, I am an uptight almost-fifty-year-old white girl from the small town of Roscommon.

Trinity Cemetery and Beth Olem Cemetery

As we neared Hamtramck on Detroit's north side, we stopped to let the group condense again. We could see the Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly plant off in the distance. This 362-acre site was once home to 4,200 residents, 1,400 homes, several churches, and 140 businesses. General Motors purchased some of the property and fought to obtain the balance of it through eminent domain. It was a highly controversial effort, but eventually the Michigan Supreme Court ruled in GM’s favor. Currently there are 1,600 workers at the plant, which builds the Chevrolet Volt, Malibu, and Impala, and it has produced more than three million vehicles. Still located on the grounds of the plant is Beth Olem Cemetery, a small Jewish cemetery that managed to remain in place. Interestingly, visitation is limited to the Sundays before Rosh Hashanah and Passover. It would be interesting to know if anyone comes.

Rolling toward the Renaissance Center

We pedaled on through the night, chatting with our neighbors and just listening to the crowd in general. One woman talked about how the Slow Roll had become her addiction, and how on her first slow roll she was so out of shape she thought she may need to quit part way through. She was sad that this was the final ride of the year. Even though it was near freezing as we moved along, I hardly thought about the cold. My mind wandered to the people who were hunkered down in their homes, and I hope it made them happy to see us rolling past. We were ready to be done when we spied the Renaissance Center guiding us to the starting point and our spanking new Explorer.

The party continued into the night inside Saint Andrew’s Hall. We chose to skip those festivities; instead, we ate at Nikki’s Greek Restaurant, a mere half a block away. The streets were desolate except for our fellow Slow Rollers and a few unlucky homeless people huddled around sewer vents for warmth. The main section of Greektown was one block away, but we felt better moving quickly between well-lit, populated areas.

Done Exploring

After dinner, we were done with the Slow Roll and wanted to Fast Roll back to Ann Arbor. After all, it was a Monday night, and Tom’s 4:30 a.m. wakeup call comes early. The Explorer delivered a smooth ride over the potholed highways that lead out of Detroit. The 3.5-liter V6 Ti-VCT (twin independent variable camshaft timing) engine was flawless as we followed the complicated highway changes that the nav was barking out. I mentioned to Tom that I barely remember how difficult it used to be to maneuver around Detroit while looking at a map. Now I would never venture to Motown without some type of a nav system.

The Explorer weighs in at 4,534 pounds, which is about the size of a small elephant, but it actually feels stable as it rolls on its twenty-inch wheels. The V-6 didn’t exhibit much lag as we barnstormed for Ann Arbor. It would be interesting to feel what a 5,000-pound trailer would do to the driving experience, that being its maximum tow capacity.

Obviously, we did not test the four-wheel-drive capability, but considering how many of this SUV's owners will haul various trailers and head to vacation destinations, I think it is a wise addition to any Explorer purchase. The cabin itself is upscale, and the blue lights that glow from the instrument panel and the cup holders make for a first-class cabin atmosphere.

Detroit Bike City has other events throughout the year to keep the spirit alive, but the Slow Roll hibernates until spring. The bike expo in Cobo center will take place the last weekend in March. That should give you plenty of time to choose your bike for the 2014 Slow Roll season. While you're waiting, here's a map of our route.

2014 Ford Explorer LTD 4WD

Price: $45,560 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 290 horsepower, 255 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Fold-flat second- and third-row seats
Option I can’t live without: Power folding third-row seat
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Traverse, Honda Pilot, Jeep Grand Cherokee, Nissan Pathfinder

title: Seen at SEMA: Racy Volkswagens
promoTeaserSmall: Some wild and wonderful VWs from the Specialty Equipment Market Association show this week.
promoTeaser: Some wild and wonderful VWs from the Specialty Equipment Market Association show this week.
metaTitle: Seen at SEMA: Racy Volkswagens - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Seen at SEMA: Racy Volkswagens: Some wild and wonderful VWs from the Specialty Equipment Market Association show this week. Read about them at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Every fall, the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) descends on the Las Vegas Convention Center for what is, by all accounts, a completely over-the-top car show. Carmakers, tuners, and aftermarket equipment manufacturers all show up with their most outlandish creations, stuff we mere mortals could never dream up. We’ll be bringing you news of SEMA’s hottest concepts and products all week, starting today with Volkswagen and the three hot-rodded concepts it brought to Vegas.

Jetta and Golf Upgrades

This year, Volkswagen brought two tarted-up Jettas and a racy Golf to showcase the Jetta’s upgraded engines and the Golf’s seventh-generation redesign. The next Golf goes on sale next year as a 2015 model. The 2014 Jetta is available with an all-new 1.8-liter, 170-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder engine. This new engine gets 36 mpg on the highway. That's 5 mpg better than the Jetta’s outgoing standard engine, a 2.5-liter normally aspirated five-cylinder powerplant.

Helios Special Edition Jetta GLI Tribute

To showcase this new engine, Volkswagen and FMS Automotive teamed up to create a tribute to the 1989 Helios Special Edition Jetta GLI, thus the name. The 2014 reincarnation features the same blue exterior paint as the classic it’s based on and wears custom side moldings, a rear spoiler, and custom side mirrors. The interior features Recaro seats sporting the Helios color scheme of blue, black, and gray; brushed aluminum accents; and a navigation system and rearview camera. But they didn’t stop with surface upgrades. The Helios Special Edition Jetta GLI also got a sport-tuned exhaust as well as a set of brake calipers from the Golf R, a performance version of the Golf hatchback.

Racer's Dream in Black and White

VW’s second SEMA show car is also a Jetta. This one, also created in concert with FMS Automotive, uses the Jetta GLI’s recently tweaked 2.0-liter turbo engine, which, in its production version, makes 210 horsepower. In this concept, dubbed “Racer’s Dream in Black and White,” the same engine has been tuned to make an astounding 426 horsepower.

To accommodate this extra power, the car also has stronger brakes, a special cold air intake system, a coil-over suspension, and anti-roll bars, among other modifications. To make the car’s looks match its track-ready insides, it has been outfitted with Recaro seats and interior trim and a full body kit. As the name suggests, the car has been painted white with a black roof.

A Modified 2015 Golf

Not content with these two pretty extreme concepts, Volkswagen and H&R, a suspension tuning firm, worked together to modify the 2015 Volkswagen Golf. The Golf gets a coil-over suspension and front and rear sway bars for a sportier ride. It also has a body kit, rear spoiler, and dual exhaust kit from VW Accessories.
The public may never get the chance to drive these one-off creations, but I'm happy just to know they exist. A little excess is good for the soul.
Keep checking in with us all week as we bring you updates on the crazy concepts and products from SEMA!

title: 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA250
promoTeaserSmall: This entry-level Mercedes is diabolically good, but don't expect to get it on the cheap.
promoTeaser: This entry-level Mercedes is diabolically good, but don't expect to get it on the cheap.
metaDescription: 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA250: This entry-level Mercedes is diabolically good, but don't expect to get it on the cheap. See my short, sweet video review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $30,825 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $43,245 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 26 mpg city/38 mpg highway
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 208 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic with shift paddles
Safety features: Collision Prevention Assist (anticipates a crash and initiates braking), Attention Assist (checks steering and detects drowsiness, issuing an alarm), eight airbags, rearview camera, stability control, traction control; Driver Assistance package ($2,500) includes blind spot assist, Distronic Plus brake assist, lane keeping assist; rear-seat side airbags are optional
Tech features: Eco Start-Stop, Bluetooth, mbrace2 telematics, bi-xenon headlights
Chief competitors: Acura ILX, Audi A3, BMW 1 Series, Volkswagen CC
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/PQOOPmeOrgw?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• This all-new entry-level car for Mercedes-Benz slots below the C-Class. In comparison, it is $5,900 cheaper than base 2014 C-Class, which starts at $36,725, including destination.
• The German automakers, most notably Mercedes-Benz and Audi, are duking it out for the souls and wallets of the young by rolling out these downsized yet upscale cars.
• The true battle is between the CLA250 and the 2015 A3. The two are priced on top of each other. But the standard equipment in the A3 includes a panoramic sunroof, Bluetooth, LED daytime running lights, leather seats and bi-xenon headlights. Several of those are extras in the CLA250.

• The base Audi A3 will get a 170-horsepower 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine, but Audi has not released horsepower numbers on the head-to-head competitor with the 2.0-liter engine.
• The CLA250 is just slightly bigger than a Honda Civic. The CLA250’s wheelbase is 106.3 inches; length is 182.3 inches. The Honda Civic’s wheelbase is 105.1 inches; length is 179.4 inches.
• Downsides: This Mercedes comes standard with a no-brand audio system with a single-disc CD; the base engine is peppy, yet noisy; the rear seat is cramped.
• Yes, it is oxymoronic that Mercedes calls the CLA a “four-door coupe.”
• The CLA lineup includes this base car, along with the CLA250 4Matic (this one is not priced and due out in spring) and CLA45 AMG, which is the cheapest AMG model in the lineup (starts at $48,375, including shipping).
• The as-tested price includes seven options or options packages, including special $720 Mountain Grey exterior paint ($720, a panoramic sunroof ($1,480), and bi-xenon headlights ($850).
• The Premium package ($2,300) includes heated front seats, Harman/Kardon audio system, garage door opener, compass, and dual-zone automatic climate control.
• The Multimedia package ($2,370) includes navigation system, rearview camera, seven-inch high-resolution LCD screen, six-disc DVD changer, and SiriusXM traffic and weathe.r
• The Sport package ($2,200) includes eighteen-inch AMG wheels with high-performance tires, brakes with perforated front discs, and AMG cladding.
• The Driver Assistance package ($2,500) includes Blind Spot Assist, Distronic Plus, and Lane Keeping Assist.
• That sexy witch hat I’m wearing in the video is not about Halloween. It’s about the sorcery required to get into the CLA250 at its budget-minded base price. The test car, which gets most of the available goodies, is $12,420 more expensive than the base price.

images.caption: Yes, the CLA250 is still a Mercedes-Benz, even at an entry-level price.

Big screen on the CLA250 is part of the Mercedes-Benz Multimedia package ($2,370) includes navigation system, rearview camera, seven-inch high-resolution LCD screen, six-disc DVD changer, and SiriusXM traffic and weather.
A little sorcery is needed to get the Mercedes-Benz CLA250 anywhere close to its base price of just under $30,000.
Traditional Mercedes-Benz amenities are here on the entry-level CLA250.
Special Mountain Grey exterior paint is a $720 option on the 2014 Mercedes_Benz CLA250.

title: 2015 Porsche Macan: L.A. Show
promoTeaserSmall: This debut had all the hallmarks of the birth of a star.
promoTeaser: This debut had all the hallmarks of the birth of a star.
metaTitle: 2015 Porsche Macan: L.A. Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2015 Porsche Macan: L.A. Auto Show. This debut had all the hallmarks of the birth of a star. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a car geek dating back to my childhood, when I took notice of the various sizes, shapes, and designs of cars. I named all of our family cars and cried when they reached the end of their useful life. I’ve been mentally composing automotive reviews for years, but it wasn’t until some years ago, when I read one of Jean Jennings's columns while waiting for an appointment, that I realized that it was possible. And here I am… grateful and enjoying every second. My next goal in life is to learn to drive a manual.

pageElements.text: The 2015 Porsche Macan, the automaker's first entry into the small-SUV market, made its world premiere at the Los Angeles Auto Show, and I have to say I think I saw a star being born.

Featuring elegant, uninterrupted lines, this little beauty caught my eye with its uncluttered appearance and elegant stance. The Macan will be equipped with all-wheel drive, air suspension, and Porsche's PDK seven-speed double-clutch gearbox, plus available ceramic brakes and much more. Porsche combines its SUV capabilities with a level of performance that should draw younger first-time buyers into the Porsche fold.

Porsche will sell two versions. The entry-level Macan S starts at $51,095, including destination. That one will be powered by a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that makes 350 horsepower. The Macan Turbo will be priced starting at $73,495, including destination, with a 400-horsepower 3.-6-liter twin-turbo V-6. It will go on sale in the spring.
For Los Angeles star power, this one definitely outflanks the Kardashians. —Elaine Nadalin, Correspondent

pageElements.text: The Los Angeles Auto Show marked the North American debut for the third-generation Mini. The cuddly pop culture favorite was ushered in by a DJ spinning Daft Punk's “Get Lucky” to enthusiastic applause.

New this year is a 1.5-liter three-cylinder engine making 134 horsepower, one of two turbo engines; the S version has a 189-horsepower four-cylinder. A new six-speed manual transmission is standard, with a six-speed automatic optional. Also new is the ability to choose among Mid, Sport, or Green driving modes.

The front-wheel-drive cutie gets some minor tweaks to its looks, most of which make it a lot less mini in size: a longer wheelbase (it’s now 4.5 inches longer overall), more interior space, and a slightly different grille.

I'm guilty of associating the Mini with spoiled high school students. But this latest release is easy to love. With the Mini’s rabidly loyal following, there's no reason this latest release will be any different.

title: Booster Seats: All You Need to Know
promoTitle: Booster Seats: All You Need to Know
promoTeaserSmall: Wondering which booster seat to choose? And when? We'll point you to the best source of information.
promoTeaser: Wondering which booster seat to choose? And when? We'll point you to the best source of information.
metaTitle: Booster Seats: All You Need to Know - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Booster Seats: All You Need to Know: Wondering which booster seat to choose? And when? We'll point you to the best source of information. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: All parents want to know that their children are as safe as possible when riding in the car, and that means buying a good car seat. But with so many choices, it can be hard to know which one to buy. To help guide parents who are shopping for booster seats, which are recommended for children aged roughly four to eight, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) has released a report detailing the results of this year’s booster seat fit test.

Booster seats help safely position seatbelts on children who have outgrown their forward-facing child seats. Seatbelts should sit flat across a child’s upper thigh and snugly over their shoulder. They shouldn’t sit over the child’s abdomen or slide up onto their neck or down off their shoulder. To test whether booster seats provide proper fit, the IIHS tests them with a child-sized dummy in seats from cars, minivans, and SUVs.

The Ratings

The best booster seats provide safe seatbelt fit in almost any vehicle. Those seats earn a Best Bet rating from the IIHS. Seats that provide an acceptable fit in most vehicles earn a Good Bet rating. Seats that may work in some vehicles earn a Check Fit rating, encouraging parents to try the seat with their own child in their own car before buying. Seats that can’t stand up to the Check Fit standards are rated as Not Recommended. This year, the IIHS tested thirty-one current booster seat models. Of those, nineteen earned a Best Bet rating, one was named a Good Bet, and eleven more were rated at Check Fit.

Just two seats were rated as Not Recommended by the agency; both were three-in-one seats from Dorel. These convertible seats work well as rear- or forward-facing restraints but don’t quite pass muster as booster seats.
For a full list (with pictures) of the rated booster seats, visit the IIHS website.

images.caption: Two IIHS Best Bets: Recaro Vivo (left) and Britax Parkway SG.
IIHS Best Bets: Evenflo Chase (left) and Graco Nautilus Elite.
More IIHS Best Bets: the backless Harmony Youth Booster and Evenflo Amp, and the full-length Cosco Pronto.

pageElements.text:
Don't Rush into a Booster Seat...

IIHS also cautions parents not to prematurely switch children from a forward-facing restraint with its own integrated harness to a booster seat. They suggest leaving children in forward-facing restraints until they reach the height or weight limit for the seat. When you do decide to switch to a booster seat, check that the seat fits not just your child, but also your vehicle (and any other vehicle your kid frequently rides in) before purchasing it. Also be sure to keep an eye on the IIHS’s ratings. Three seats that had passed previous tests with flying colors slipped to a Check Fit rating this year after they were substantially redesigned; don’t assume that a seat is safe just because it earned a good rating a few years ago.

...And Then, Don't Rush Out of One

Once you find the right booster seat for your child, fight to keep him or her in it. As little kids turn into big kids, they may start rebelling against the oppression and fundamental un-coolness of a car seat. But until they’re tall enough to wear a seatbelt safely without aid, stand firm. IIHS says kids aged four to eight are 45 percent less likely to be injured in a crash if they’re in a booster seat compared to wearing a seatbelt alone. Enough said.

title: 2013 Toyota Avalon Limited
promoTeaserSmall: I think its new look is more like its glamorous Lexus cousins. But what does the Peanut Gallery say?
promoTeaser: I think its new look is more like its glamorous Lexus cousins. But what does the Peanut Gallery say?
metaDescription: 2013 Toyota Avalon Limited: The older sister of the glamorous Lexus is showing off its all-new look and feel. Like it? I do. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $42,449 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated seats front and back
Option I can’t live without: Precollision braking system (part of Technology package, $1,750)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Impala, Chrysler 300, Lincoln MKZ, Lexus ES, Nissan Maxima

See more specs on the Avalon in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

There may be no better evidence that Toyota is trying to move away from its stodgy image than the 2013 Avalon. Long considered the old-man car in the lineup, the Toyota flagship has changed a lot with its complete overhaul for 2013 and now looks every bit as upscale as the Lexus ES, its slightly pricier cousin. You would be forgiven if you walked up to this car, with its strikingly swoopy sides and low profile, and didn’t realize this was a Toyota. It’s downright sleek and modern, absolutely without a doubt the first Avalon that will turn heads.

It’s also turned into an all-American product. There’s that big grille that reminds me of the current Ford Fusion's, and there’s the fact that it was designed and developed at Calty Design Research in California and the Toyota Technical Center right here in Ann Arbor, and it's built in Kentucky.

The redesign does not extend to the engine: it has Toyota’s tried-and-true 3.5-liter V-6 with a six-speed automatic transmission, yielding 268 horsepower. There is also a hybrid Avalon with the merit of not costing a huge premium over the standard model, starting just over $35,000 and offering 40 mpg.

Consumer Reports, usually ready to approve of a Toyota, gave this completely redesigned Avalon a score of 85 out of 100 points and its top rating for predicted reliability. However, the publication criticized the ride feel as “stiffened too much.”

Now, maybe I am driving too many sporty cars—if there’s such a thing as too many—but this was far from the stiffest car I’ve driven in the past week, let alone unacceptably stiff. Toyota did want to add a little dash of sportiness to this new model, and in that sense it succeeded. The automaker described it as "reinventing Avalon's roadgoing character." In my view, that's a good thing. I wouldn't be surprised if those changes lose Toyota a few customers who liked a more traditionally soft ride, though.
You won't forget you're inside a Toyota because it's no-nonsense, but there's enough understated comfort to reward your decision to go a bit upmarket.

Over smooth roads or at moderate speeds, the car still has the buttery feel of a Lexus, and that’s no surprise, since they’re under the Toyota umbrella, too. What it doesn’t have is the high-cholesterol price of a Lexus: this extremely well-appointed full-size sedan cost $42,449 with everything on it. Compare that with the cost of a similarly equipped Lexus ES, its platform mate, which tops out at $46,420. Toyota hasn't raised the price of the Avalon for 2014, either.  Now, once you get into the $40,000-and-up shopping category, those few grand may not matter compared with the opportunity to drive a Lexus-badged car. But having the Lexus badge is not a selling point for everybody, including Toyota-brand loyalists and those looking for space and comfort more than status.

But setting aside all talk of driving excitement, check out the interior of the Avalon. I certainly did. The black, brown, and tan combination, and the smooth textures and curving lines, all definitely worked for me. The stitching on the leather seats was particularly nice. You won't forget you're inside a Toyota because it's no-nonsense, but there's enough understated comfort to reward your decision to go a bit upmarket. I love the dual-screen setup that lets you look at an analog clock, temperatures, and HVAC settings below while maintaining a separate screen of audio or navigation information above.

The Limited model, top of the Avalon line, comes with such higher-end features as a power tilting/sliding moonroof, HID headlights, rain-sensing wipers, and paddle shifters for the automatic transmission. Safety features included on the Limited include a blind spot monitor and rear cross-traffic alert. The Technology package ($1,750) adds automatic high-beam headlights, dynamic radar cruise control, and a precollision braking system. That latter item is one of my favorite technological advances. I'm looking forward to the day when nobody smashes into the back of anybody else ever again.
For 2014, Toyota makes the rearview camera a standard feature on all levels of Avalon, but otherwise, the made-over model has no substantive changes, including to the price.

The Verdict:

I was glad that modernizing the Avalon didn’t take away some of the old-school comforts that the car was known for before. The tri-tone interior, the classy analog clock and leather surfaces, and the general feeling of prosperous ease are all there, but there’s value added in the form of a more interesting ride. You don’t feel detached from the road in an old-person way. I’m guessing some people will miss that cushioned feeling, but it’s likely that even more people will appreciate the driving experience of the revised Avalon.

You might ask, why buy a $40,000 Toyota when you can move into a Lexus? Well, there are many people who would be more attracted to the flagship Toyota than the lower-end Lexus. Maybe they’re coming up from a Camry or over from another large car, and what they want is more luxury at less of a price increase. Those people are out there, and they deserve to be given as appealing a choice as this Avalon. If you’re one of them, or even if you don't think you are, try this car with an open mind.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Avalon is a sleeping giant: a premium large sedan for the buyer who wants luxury, but doesn't need to show off. The passenger space seems huge, as does the trunk. You could actually take this on a road trip with four adults and be comfortable. But the very best part is the price. The base model starts at $31,800.

Annie White: I was surprised by how much I liked driving this car. It is spacious and comfortable, and the V-6 engine felt capable and powerful. On the other hand, I fell far short of the 21-mpg city rating during my drives around town, and I wasn't a fan of the infotainment system's touch surfaces or the tri-tone interior treatment. Not quite right for me, but I can imagine this car making many other drivers very happy.

title: A Cadillac Living Room Make-Over
subTitle: Cadillac Elmiraj Concept interior designer Gael Buzyn imagines a Cadillac-style living room design.
promoTeaserSmall: Cadillac Elmiraj Concept interior designer Gael Buzyn imagines how I could redo my NYC living room.
promoTeaser: Cadillac Elmiraj Concept interior designer Gael Buzyn imagines how I could redo my NYC living room.
metaTitle: A Cadillac Living Room Make-Over - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Cadillac Living Room Make-Over: Cadillac Elmiraj Concept interior designer Gael Buzyn imagines a Cadillac-style living room design. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pages.metaDescription: Cadillac Elmiraj Concept interior designer Gael Buzyn imagines a Cadillac-style living room design.
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: In my ongoing project to embrace the qualities of car design and apply them to the decor of my New York City home, this time my living room, I sat down with Gael Buzyn, the interior design manager for two recent Cadillac concepts, the Elmiraj luxury coupe and the Ciel convertible.

He explained that both of these concepts paid tribute to his passion for mid-century modern and sophisticated craftsmanship. He calls the 1950s through the 1960s the most splendid era of the century, and he imbued both the Elmiraj and the Ciel with this sensibility. “They are truly American progressive but with obvious roots,” Buzyn explained.

Buzyn took his cues from the homes in Palm Springs, the setting for the recent reveal of Cadillac ELR. We took a tour of famous mid-century modern houses with Michael Stern, co-author of the coffee-table book Julius Shulman: Palm Springs. He pointed out, "Everybody is in Palm Springs to have a good time; the houses are livable and ripe for entertaining." Stern explained that, when these homes were built, there was a zoning ordinance for one-story houses so that no one could see into your back yard.

In brief, the landmark homes he was showing us (designed by famous architects for luminaries including Frank Sinatra and Bob Hope) were built with open floor plans, lots of windows, and simple, clean lines that made use of the desert light and the stunning scenery.

Palm Springs was a super setting for the introduction of the Cadillac ELR, an electric plug-in coupe that can travel 300 miles powered by the combination of battery-electric and gasoline power. Besides the ELR’s efficiency of travel, the vehicle’s pure and seamless design speaks to mid-century modern.

Buzyn's Ideas for My Living Room

I showed the designer Pinterest pictures of my living room (wince, wince) as well as architecture, design, and fashions that inspire me. Buzyn shared pictures of his awesome home in the Los Angeles area and pictures of his recently finished mid-century home in Palm Springs.

His L.A. home looked like a magazine shoot. There were molded concrete walls around the fireplace, mid-century chairs from a Danish designer (Credenza, circa 1951), rosewood floors, a Bang & Olufsen turntable stereo (for its clean, flawless and simple technology), and vintage Kandinsky gallery posters on the walls.
I remarked on a neat pile of kids’ toys in the living room and asked him how he kept that under control. He answered, “We only have vintage Fisher-Price toys and… yes, they like them.”
OK, I thought, and now it’s down to my cluttered, narrow New York City space. I took a deep breath and set out on the following Q & A.
Holly: What can we do about all of these bikes? They’re an eyesore!
Gael: Bikes are magical objects! They can be wall art! [He led me online to see images of space-saving bike racks including this one.] Check it out. They are all fabulous!
Holly: Yes, I know that one wall of my apartment is devoted to a flat-screen TV with all of the accompanying cords and other stuff. It drives me crazy. I just look at it and feel messy.
Gael: You could get a retractable-type arrangement where the TV could fit neatly into a credenza. Another sleek option would be a flat screen TV/fireplace like this one.

The designer also noted that he uses his own living room for watching movies. One wall serves as a screen, and the other wall has a small mounted projector. Great idea if you have an extra media room!
Holly: What about my dining area? I have this picnic table with benches to seat lots of people, but it’s uncomfortable.
Gael: The table is too heavy and dark. I would suggest something that is more visually light, like these, to give you a feeling of space.
Holly: My office, once a coat closet, is so claustrophobic and disorganized that I can’t work in it. Any brilliant ideas?
Gael: This area could have the functionality of a credenza. A big cube could open up, the doors would be bookshelves, and inside you would have built-ins. It would fold up like a huge office cabinet.
[He picked this credenza for hiding my TV/stereo and also thought it would be good as a design for my office space.]
Holly: Any suggestions for my living room? I have two leather couches, a couple of Fifties-type chairs, and wood floors [which Buzyn liked!].
Gael: I suggest that you keep one of the couches and replace the other with open chairs.
He supplied me with a list of sites to explore for rugs, and I picked this one from West Elm, a handcrafted Indian vintage piece in ink blue.
The advice? Priceless. The cost of refurbishing my living room? My Buzyn-inspired renovation could possibly come in at less than the $76,000 tag of the 2014 Cadillac ELR.
Buzyn later informed me that it would cost that much if I decided to go with originals and/or authentic reproductions. He suggested that with knock-off furniture I could divide that price in half.

title: Our New Year Playlist
promoTeaserSmall: First resolution: Listen to good music, at the New Year and all year long. Like this playlist.
promoTeaser: First resolution: Listen to good music, at the New Year and all year long. Like this playlist.
metaKeywords: music to listen to in the car
music playlists for New Year's Eve
metaDescription: Our New Year Playlist: Songs to ring in 2014 and enliven your winter driving experience. You're welcome! Read and listen to our list on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

pageElements.text:
As 2014 appears on the horizon, it's time for some resolutions. Top of our list is to listen to great music, not just what falls immediately to hand when dialing the radio (even the SiriusXM radio). Why not start with these resolution-friendly tunes?

Check out the ten songs one at a time on the following pages. Or view the entire playlist here.

Happy motoring in the New Year!

title: 2014 Honda Accord Coupe
promoTeaserSmall: Annie and Molly's video review of that rare bird (in 2014), the coupe.
promoTeaser: Annie and Molly's video review of that rare bird (in 2014), the coupe.
metaDescription: Honda Accord Coupe: Molly and Annie's review of one of the few true coupes on the market. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
2014 Honda Accord Coupe EX-L V6 Navi

Vital Stats

Base price: $31,415 (includes destination)
This car's price: $33,190 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Safety features: Six airbags, vehicle stability assist with traction control, forward collision warning, and lane departure warning (all standard)
Tech features: Touchscreen audio, SiriusXM satellite radio, push-button start, MP3 and USB connectivity, heated front seats
Chief competitors: This is one of the few cars that stands alone in its segment.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/-jk8KnLSBjs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The 2014 Accord Coupe is a carryover model.
• The car shown in the video is the top-of-the-line Accord Coupe model, and it has no options. The base price for the 2014 Accord LX-S coupe with six-speed manual transmission is $24,415 (including destination).
• This EX-L with navigation costs $1,775 more than the EX-L without navigation.
• The model tested has a six-speed manual transmission. There's no price penalty for upgrading to a six-speed automatic.
• The same version with the six-speed automatic transmission gets better fuel economy at 21 mpg city/32 mpg highway. • You can get the Accord Coupe in V-6 and four-cylinder versions. The four-cylinder version delivers 185 hp.

• Honda has always been known for its attitude that “safety should be standard, not optional.” The Accord Coupe earned five out of five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration for frontal, side, and rollover safety.
• The 2013 Accord Coupe was named a 2013 Top Safety Pick + by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. It earned the top Good rating in all IIHS tests, except for an Acceptable rating in the small overlap front crash test. These are still effective ratings, since the Accord was fully redesigned in 2013 and the changes for 2014 model year are minimal.

• Car shoppers don’t have much choice in the mid-size coupe segment, especially since the Nissan Altima Coupe has been discontinued for the 2014 model year. Nissan said the Altima Coupe was a “very low-volume product” and that the discontinuation means that more four-cylinder engines will be available for the 2014 Nissan Altima sedan.

• Why does the Accord Coupe survive? The answer is probably reliability and practicality. • Why do people buy coupes? Style and performance. Just a few years ago there were many mid-size coupes. Among them were the Camry-based Toyota Solara, the Pontiac Grand Am and Oldsmobile Alero coupes, the Ford Probe, and the Mercury Cougar.

• The Accord Coupe has a practical side in that it seats five.
• For 2014, the Honda Accord sedan–not coupe–comes in hybrid and plug-in hybrid versions.
• The 2014 Accord sedan is cheaper than the coupe; the 2014 Accord LX sedan starts at $22,745 (including destination).

title: Annie Goes to Brooklyn
subTitle: Take everything you own, put it in a car, and drive away to New York City to live? I just did.
promoTeaserSmall: Take everything you own, put it in a car, and drive away to New York City to live? I just did.
promoTeaser: Take everything you own, put it in a car, and drive away to New York City to live? I just did.
metaDescription: Annie Goes to Brooklyn: Take everything you own, put it in a car, and drive away to New York City to live? I just did. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Moving from Ann Arbor, Michigan, to New York City may seem daunting, but it’s just like any other move. Take everything you own, put it in a car, and drive away. When I made my move three days after Christmas that’s exactly what I did, except that I took considerably less than half of my stuff, because the rumors about tiny New York apartments aren’t just rumors.

The journey started at 9:00 a.m. on the last Saturday of 2013. My dad had kindly volunteered to drive me cross-country in his 2009 Volkswagen CC. Conceived as a four-door coupe version of the Volkswagen Passat, the CC has a low, sloping roofline and doesn’t feel spacious inside. But it’s actually a few inches longer and wider than the Passat, and it’s by far the largest vehicle driven by a member of the White family, so it was our best option.

By folding the rear seats down, we were able to fit my skis, three suitcases, two boxes of books, and a few bags of other belongings behind the front row. My winter boots and several just-washed dresses, nearly forgotten, were thrown on top at the last minute. My father, like so many fathers before him, groaned with each new bag that materialized in the front hall. But when everything was packed in, we still had a small tunnel clear to look out the rear window, and I call that a success.

Traffic was flowing freely on I-80 and the weather was glorious for late December, hovering right around 50 degrees all day. We stopped for lunch at Plyler’s Buffet in Brookville, Pennsylvania. Years ago, my parents identified Plyler’s as the halfway point on trips to my grandmother’s house in upstate New York, and we keep going back because they have scrumptious pies. I hadn’t been there in nearly a decade, but the graham cracker pie was just as good as I remembered it.

After lunch, it was my turn to drive. I’d driven the CC dozens of times before, so I wasn’t surprised by its eager acceleration and smooth ride, but I still enjoyed it. This particular CC uses Volkswagen’s trusty 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine making 200 horsepower. Sure, the 3.6-liter V-6 would have given this large car a little more pep, but it’s by no means necessary, and the smaller engine means smaller gas bills. We filled up in Brookville and didn’t stop again until we made it to Brooklyn.
Our car was surrounded by big SUVs and heavily modded Civic Si's. Each time a lane narrowed, drivers would jockey for position in a potentially dangerous game of chicken.

We’d left Michigan early and, despite a long lunch, should have landed at my new digs by 8:00 p.m. Sadly, that was not to be. Saturday night traffic into the city via the Holland Tunnel slowed us to a crawl for nearly two hours and gave me my first unpleasant taste of New York City's driving culture. Our car was surrounded by big SUVs and heavily modded Civic Si's from New Jersey, and each time a lane narrowed, drivers would jockey for position, playing a potentially dangerous game of chicken. I happily let some of them in but stood my ground against a few who were blatantly disregarding the laws of polite driving. One woman nearly crashed into us before waving with a falsely sweet smile, as if to say, “Suckahs.” “Yeah, I’ve got a finger for her too,” said my dad from the passenger's seat.

Then, suddenly, we were there. It was nearly 10:00 p.m, almost thirteen hours after we’d left home. Two of those hours had been spent driving the last ten miles from New Jersey through lower Manhattan and into Brooklyn. My dad was determined to put a few hours of driving between himself and New York City hotel rates before stopping for the night, so we quickly unloaded my things and said our goodbyes, and then he was off and I was alone in a brand-new city.
Going from having a small fleet of new cars at my disposal to taking a forty-five-minute ride in a dirty subway car anytime I want to go somewhere is a major change.

I’ve had plenty of moments like that in the past five years, but it’s always an adjustment. Going from having a small fleet of brand-new cars at my disposal to taking a forty-five-minute ride in a dirty subway car anytime I want to go somewhere is a major change. In my first week in New York, I’ve seen people vomit on the train, watched a man clean his dentures with his sweatshirt, and been warned that if I stand too close to the edge of the platform someone will push me in just for fun. It’s nothing like driving in a comfortable car alone, but it is part of life in the big city, so I’m trying to embrace it. The next time I see someone holding their own teeth, though, I might lose it.

contributors.displayName: Jean Jennings, President and Editor in Chief
contributors.bio:
Jean Jennings has been writing about cars and the car business for more than thirty years. She learned about cars at the kitchen table from her father Robert, the late editor of Automotive News. At the age of eighteen, she bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, Jennings went to Chrysler’s test track where she worked as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, she was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine when she was laid off her Chrysler job, and in 1985 she left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr., as its first executive editor. She became Editor-in-Chief in 2000 and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

Jennings has won awards for her feature writing, for her car reviews, and for her monthly Automobile Magazine column “Vile Gossip.” She was the recipient of the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. Jennings has the unique experience, sensibility, and personality to connect with women and to give them voice in the male-dominated automotive space. She was the subject of a Susan Orlean profile in the New Yorker, has appeared on numerous television news shows, has been on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000.

She is currently a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News.

Jennings lives in the Michigan countryside with her husband, Tim, and the entire food chain.

I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

pageElements.text: Ralph Gilles has been an amazing constant at the head of Chrysler design. For a time, he was in charge of Dodge, and he's currently in charge of SRT. It's funny that a designer is actually in charge of a brand as well as design, but certainly his passion for performance serves the company well.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/ohb9YQwSs3o" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Chrysler 200 was formerly the Sebring. They renamed it the 200, despite the fact that changes to it were modest, because the Sebring was such an awful car. When Fiat swooped in and saved Chrysler's bacon, they discovered that the company was more bankrupt in terms of product and engineering than they had suspected. There was so much work to be done that, for the first couple of years, all that could be done was cleaning up interiors and dealing with the most egregious problems in the lineup.

But, while Fiat and Chrysler and the United States government were hammering out a deal, the engineers and designers never stopped working. Ralph and his team did a wonderful job keeping Chrysler's great history from crumbling into dust. I particularly appreciated that because I'm part of Chrysler's great history, having worked at the Chrysler proving ground for five years in the mid-1970s.

This Chrysler 200 is nothing like the car it replaces, which is a great thing. The only thing that car had going for it was the fact that Eminem stood in front of it while he made an emotional speech about Detroit in an extra-long ad during Super Bowl XLV in 2011. $2 billion was spent to make this car great: $1 billion on manufacturing and $1 billion on product. It's competing in the fiercest class of all, dominated by the Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, and Ford Fusion—all sales juggernauts—and let's not forget the Nissan Altima and the Mazda 6. Chrysler is bringing everything they have to the party. Ralph Gilles was the only man to give us the walkaround.
