title: 5 Ways to Parent Your Teen Driver
promoTitle: 5 Ways to Parent Your Teen Driver
promoTeaserSmall: When your teenager gets a driver's license, you've got work to do. Here are five must-do items.
promoTeaser: When your teenager gets a driver's license, you've got work to do. Here are five must-do items.
metaTitle: 5 Ways to Parent Your Teen Driver - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 5 Ways to Parent Your Teen Driver: When your teenager gets a driver's license, you've got work to do. Here are five must-do items. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Watching a child make the transition from backseat passenger to brand-new driver can be scary for parents. Putting your teenager in charge of a multi-thousand-pound vehicle may not be the easiest thing you’ve ever done, but it is almost inevitable. And the good news is that even when you’re not in the car with them, you can have a big impact on their driving habits, according to a study released this month by Travelers, the insurance provider. Keep reading for some surprising findings from the study, and tips on how to talk to your kids about safe driving.

1. Be a Good Role Model

Travelers found that teens who reported that their parents were good driving role models were half as likely to have been in an accident as teens whose parents weren’t setting a good example. That’s good news, but it’s also a big responsibility. So when your kids are in the car, make an extra effort to drive safely and courteously–and hands off the cell phone.

2. Start a Conversation. Soon.

In their survey of 2,000 teens and parents, Travelers found that two-thirds of sixteen-year-olds wanted to have a conversation about driving safety with their parents, and half of those kids were waiting for their parents to initiate the conversation. By the time young drivers are eighteen, however, that window of opportunity is nearly closed. Just 29 percent of surveyed eighteen-year-olds were interested in a safe-driving talk with their parents. Don’t shy away from the talk; start a dialogue with your kids before they lose interest.
Be sure that your kids know not only how dangerous it is to drink or text behind the wheel, but feel empowered to refuse rides from peers who aren’t driving safely.

3. Don’t Be Naïve

Travelers found a surprising disconnect in the driving behaviors that parents and teens are concerned about. While the majority of teens–66 percent–were concerned about driving under the influence, just 14 percent of parents thought of it as a major concern. Mobile phone use while driving concerned 56 percent of teenagers but just 35 percent of parents, despite heavy media coverage of the dangers of distracted driving. You may not be worried about these behaviors because you think your teen knows better than to engage in them, but you should include impaired and distracted driving in your safe-driving talk anyway. Be sure that your kids know not only how dangerous it is to drink or text behind the wheel, but that they feel empowered to refuse rides from peers who aren’t driving safely.

4. Make a Driving Contract

Acting as a good driving role model and having a frank, open conversation with your teens about safe driving will go a long way, but they can’t be your last steps. To cement the agreements you and your new driver have made, think about drawing up a driving contract with your teen. Talk about forbidden behaviors, curfews, the number of passengers they’re allowed to carry, and anything else that’s important to you.

5. Have Consequences and Stick to Them

You should also agree on consequences for broken rules, so the contract has some teeth. That way they can’t say you’re being unfair when you take away the keys after a missed curfew. Consider agreeing to abide by some guidelines of your own, so your teen knows you’re not just imposing arbitrary restrictions.
Do you have young drivers in the house? What are your strategies for keeping them safe? Let us know in the comments below.
Images at top: Lisa F. Young/iStock/Thinkstock Inset: Alin Dragulin/FogStock/Thinkstock

title: Millennials Do Want to Drive
subTitle: Don't believe the hype about under-25s. Study shows we like cars as much as the rest of you.
promoTeaserSmall: Don't believe the hype about under-25s. Study shows we like cars as much as the rest of you.
promoTeaser: Don't believe the hype about under-25s. Study shows we like cars as much as the rest of you.
metaTitle: Millennials Do Want to Drive - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Millennials Do Want to Drive, a new study says. Encouraging! Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Young people like cars, after all!

There’s been a lot of chatter lately about how young people don’t like cars anymore. Many an article has been written bemoaning the fact that millenials would rather beat their high score on Fruit Ninja than learn to drive stick, and are more likely to spend spare cash on a tablet than a vehicle. As a young person who loves cars, I’ve long been suspicious of this dim view of millenials. And thanks to a study from J.D. Power, now I have some backup.

The firm recently released its report on automotive marketing and media, conducted since 1987, and it was full of good news about the attitudes of young people towards cars. According to the report, drivers age twenty-five and younger have represented a steadily increasing percentage of new car buyers since 2009, and now account for more than six percent of new car purchases.
For many young drivers, their car isn’t just a convenient way to get around but an extension of their personality and an important component of their public image.

Young buyers are also passionate about the cars they purchase. The report showed that for many young drivers, their car isn’t just a convenient way to get around town. It’s viewed as an extension of their personality and an important component of their public image. According to the report, 33 percent of young car buyers “completely agree” that they want their car to stand out from the crowd, compared to just 20 percent of drivers across all age groups. Twenty-seven percent of young drivers answered “completely agree” when asked if they would want to personalize their new cars with options and additional equipment, compared to 20 percent of drivers in all age groups.

It’s not just interest in theoretical cars, either: 29 percent of young car owners say they wash and wax their cars themselves, which is five percent above the national average, and they are willing to pay the price; younger buyers finance cars for an average of sixty-eight months, three months longer than the average.

Those numbers suggest a very different story from the “young people don’t care about cars” narrative we’ve been hearing. And it doesn’t stop with the car’s appearance. Young people are also much more likely to report enjoying driving on challenging roadways, and 41 percent of young car buyers prefer responsive, powerful cars. This is a satisfying rebuttal to the naysayers who are convinced that young people wouldn’t know a good car if it ran them over.

Older buyers still out-purchase the under-twenty-fives, but if J.D. Power’s study is to be believed (and why not?) we youngsters are not as hopeless as carmakers had feared. We are at least as excited about our cars and the role cars play in our lives as older drivers are. And that’s encouraging news.
Header: Wavebreakmedia Ltd/Thinkstock Inset: Samuel Borges/istock/Thinkstock

title: Winter Maintenance: 4 Musts
promoTeaserSmall: In any season, but especially during the cold months, keep these four items in working order.
promoTeaser: In any season, but especially during the cold months, keep these four items in working order.
metaDescription: Winter Maintenance: 4 Musts. Four things you need to watch on your car so it gets you to spring. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Back in the fall you equipped yourself for winter with that long down coat, texting gloves, and an infinity scarf, but how about your car? To make sure all the winter car prep bases are covered we asked Michael Calkins, the manager of technical services at AAA’s national office, to run down the four most important maintenance considerations for safe winter driving.

1. Tires

Maintaining proper traction is a challenge in winter conditions, so if you live where there is heavy snow, consider purchasing snow tires for the season. If you're counting on all-season tires to get you through, they won't be as useful if you have let the tread wear down. “If any tire has less than 3/32 inch of tread,” cautions Calkins, “it should be replaced.” Also, tire pressure drops along with temperatures, so make sure yours are properly inflated. Appropriate PSI for your tires can be found on the driver’s door frame, or check your owner's manual.

2. Battery

Batteries become less efficient with colder temperatures so if your charge wasn’t optimal in the first place you may have trouble starting the car once the winter chill begins in earnest. Calkins recommends having your car’s starting system and battery charge tested to make sure you won’t get caught out in the cold.

3. Brakes

On icy roads, we put an almost unreasonable amount of faith in our brakes. Give yours a fighting chance by having them checked. Calkins reminds us, “Brakes that tend to grab or pull on dry roads are likely to lock on ice or snow-covered pavement, resulting in a loss of stopping power and/or steering control.” So, if you had questions about your brakes in the summer, don’t bet on them getting you safely through the winter months.

4. Wipers

Visibility is hard enough when slush covers the lane paint and also splatters the windshield, so worn out wipers will just make the whole mess worse. If your wipers are streaking and missing sections of the glass they should be replaced. In a long snow season Calkins says to consider winter wipers like the new "beam" type designed to discourage ice and snow buildup. Remember to use an antifreeze washer fluid and keep some extra handy. Speaking of visibility, don’t forget to clear off your car’s head- and taillights so you can see, and be seen, during winter’s dreary days and dark nights.
Once you’ve gotten the car in good working order, throw a well-stocked Winter Emergency Kit in the back, and a shovel, since at some point in all our lives there’s a snowbank with our name on it.
Images: wipers from artist-unlimited/iStock/Thinkstock; batteryfrom Winai Tepsuttinun/iStock/Thinkstock; brakesfrom koufax73/iStock/ThinkStock

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: We were just talking about the Kia Soul at Jean Knows Cars, and days after our review of the 2014 model, the automaker has rolled out a new version. At the Chicago Auto Show this morning, I saw the worldwide debut of the 2015 Kia Soul EV, an all-electric version.

The Soul EV has lithium-ion polymer battery power, teamed with a 109-horsepower electric motor. That may compare unfavorably with 164 horsepower for the "regular" Soul with its conventional internal-combustion gasoline engine.

But people don't buy most electric vehicles for power. The question you're asking is, what about range? So check this out: the EV offers 114 mpg-e in town and 90 mpg-e on the highway. The estimated range on a charge is a truly impressive 80 to 100 miles. Drivers can also dial in the car's regenerative braking system to recapture up to 12 percent of energy during coasting and braking, which will help optimize that range. I  liked Kia's choice of where to plug it in: right behind the front grille. It will charge in four to five hours using a 240-volt charging station or in 24 hours with standard 120-volt household current. Or you can get it to 80 percent in a half-hour if you use a special 50-kW charger.

The under-floor battery positioning, Kia says, offers "more energy in less space." Legroom in the back seat is cut only 3.1 inches from the reasonably capacious regular Soul, and rear cargo space is down 5.1 cubic feet to 19.1 cubic feet. Indeed, Kia has not budged from its characterization of the Soul as a five-passenger vehicle unlike, for example, the Chevrolet Volt, which seats four because of its battery.

images.caption: Grille looks different because that's where you plug this Kia Soul in.
A promised range of up to 100 miles sounds good. The Kia Soul EV will charge fully in under five hours with a 240-volt charger.
Two-tone color schemes will differentiate the Kia Soul EV from the regular Soul.
2015 Kia Soul EV making its debut at the Chicago Auto Show, February 6, 2014. Photo by Susan Campbell.
Molly Jean and one of the iconic hamsters at the Chicago Auto Show, posing with the 2015 Kia Soul EV. Photo by Susan Campbell.

pageElements.text: As soon as I saw it on the show floor in Chicago, I was a fan of that two-tone paint scheme. Gorgeous! All the Kia EVs will be two-tone: Caribbean Blue with a Clear White roof, Pearl White with an Electronic Blue roof, or Bright Silver with a Clear White roof. That's a way to differentiate it from the gasoline-powered Soul.

Kia marketing chief Michael Sprague said the Soul EV will be competitive against the whole gamut of electric vehicles, from the Fiat 500E to the Ford C-Max to the Nissan Leaf. He didn't name an estimated price for the car, but that will be clear soon. The Soul EV goes on sale in California and Oregon by the fourth quarter of this year. After that, it will roll out in New York, New Jersey, and Maryland.
Top photo and photo of Molly Jean with hamster: Susan Campbell

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The first crazy thing that happened on our trip to the Westminster Kennel Club's 138th annual dog show was yesterday. We came down in the Mercedes-Benz Sprinter to get the lay of the land and were able to find parking on the roof, which is like a miracle. We only had to walk a few steps to an escalator, go straight down, and we were in and walking around.

This morning, entrants could bring their dogs in starting at 5:30 a.m., and people line up to come in at that hour. Well, we thought we'd leave for the show at 8:00 a.m. instead, but we found out the roof parking had been filled by 6:30 a.m. My husband, Tim, dropped us off. We brought everything in while Tim made friends with the parking guys on the roof. So, the minute a space opened, they called his cell phone, and he went up and parked on the roof.

Our handler, Kelly Leonard, knows about half the people here at Westminster. A lot of her friends have come. I've never met them, but they know who Bob is, which is cute. There is fierce competition here. The #1 Chesapeake in the country from last year is here and being handled by a woman who has won Best in Show two different times, not with Chesapeake Bay retrievers like Bob, but she's very well known among the judges. I knew all the top dogs would be here, and they are really spectacular-looking.
Bob and I are just happy to be here. He has let a lot of kids pet him, and he loves being with people, although we're keeping him close in his cage until showtime.

We walked around a little and looked in at Ring 8 just in time to see our friend Mark Bettis, one of the top handlers in the country, watch his Flat-Coated retriever from ringside. His dog won among twenty-eight entries. Everyone around him was crying and hugging him. He's a real tough guy, but he was in tears, too. Mark is a great friend who has shown Bob once or twice for fun.
The top five breeds entered at Westminster this year are Labrador retriever (76 entries), Golden retriever (58), French bulldog (52), Rhodesian ridgeback (46), and Australian shepherd (44).
What kind of chance did Bob have as one of twenty Chesapeake Bay retrievers entered at Westminster?

In his favor, he finished eighth in the country last year despite not competing in many dog shows. We're not sure what his ranking is this year. However, we do know that he is at his peak age and condition, and he won his first four shows of the year, all four of which had an unusually large number of Chesapeakes in the ring, and a third place in the Sporting group.

Against him? We’re not breeders, we’re not professional handlers, and we don’t advertise regularly in dog magazines that judges read. We’re going because we love dogs and it’s great fun to see the top dogs in the country in every single breed in one place for two days. And because we’ve been watching it on TV virtually all of our lives. It’s just cool to be here.

So how did Bob do? He did make the cut among Chesapeakes, but in the end he did not place. But did we have fun? I did! My husband, Tim, did! Handler Kelly did (and thank you so much, Kelly, for handling him so beautifully in the ring). And Bob? His bait was sliced-up steak from last night's dinner. He was in ecstasy.

Now we're back in the Sprinter and on our way out of New York City, headed for I-80, then across Pennsylvania headed for home. Bob is sound asleep in the back. We'll have video of our adventure here soon.

title: Dodge La Femme: Rhapsody in Pink

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Few people appreciate or even remember the La Femme, the auto industry’s first attempt to market directly to women. Based on the 1955 Dodge Custom Royal Lancer, it was paradoxical then, and nearly sixty years later,  the few remaining traces aren’t easy to read.

Maybe the result would have been better if this two-door hardtop model hadn’t expressed the worst styling cliches of the 1950s. To begin with, the Royal had too much ornamentation. Its chrome face was an atrocity. The hood scoop was fake, and the diving beltline failed to distract from the body’s ungainly proportions. Stupid little fins were tacked on atop the rear fenders.
Discern for yourself whether the special La Femme trim level aimed at women was a cynical ploy to move some sheetmetal out of showrooms or a genuine effort to create a new market niche.
“Won’t the gals love this?” we can imagine Dodge president W.C. Newberg saying.

“Won’t the gals love this?” we can imagine Dodge president W.C. Newberg saying to vice-president R.C. Somerville and sales manager L.F. Desmond before unveiling the La Femme option. This was in the spring of 1955—the middle of the model year. "Yes, Boss," we can imagine Somerville and Desmond answering.
The La Femme was cloaked in a pink-and-white paint job, but the name Heather Rose was used. To ensure irresistibility, a unique rosebud pattern was chosen for the jacquard-weave upholstery.

Personal accessories—all in pink—were included: a four-button raincoat, rain hat, and umbrella. Additionally, a large and awkwardly shaped purse, very tall and narrow as if for storing nightsticks, contained a compact, a cigarette case, and a lighter.
These extras stowed away in pouches that clung to the backs of the first-row seats.
If the Dodge La Femme website is to be believed, the accessories were widely coveted:  “Unfortunately, many…disappeared before they even reached the dealer showroom."

If the Dodge La Femme website is to be believed, the accessories were widely coveted. “Unfortunately, it seems that many…disappeared before they even reached the dealer showroom,” the site says. (We presume Pinkerton detectives couldn’t track down the pilfered goods.)
One ad supported the La Femme with the slogan, “Now for the first time anywhere, a car glamorously, personally yours.” It promised “every sophisticated touch your heart could desire!”
Another played on the Royal name, saying, “By appointment to Her Majesty...the American Woman.”

We can’t pin down exactly how many examples of the La Femme were sold. Did women demand them and—rare at the time—independently transact the purchases? Did men buy the cars as gifts? A combination of both?

Some 30,500 Custom Royal Lancers were produced in 1955. No figures are broken out for Her Majesty’s favorite trim level, but we imagine dozens of women lining up in Coral Gables alone. After all, the pink handbag in combination with Dodge’s Red Ram V-8 engine represented the new automotive black.
Only twelve surviving examples are listed in the La Femme website's registry, though.
The worst thing Dodge did after the '55 La Femme? When repeating it one more time, in 1956, they deleted the purse.
That’s what we call a pink slip.

title: Winter Olympics' Gold Medal Cars
subTitle: At Sochi, Volkswagen’s Russian car brands are transporting everything from medals to mascots.
promoTeaserSmall: At Sochi, Volkswagen’s Russian car brands are transporting everything from medals to mascots.
promoTeaser: At Sochi, Volkswagen’s Russian car brands are transporting everything from medals to mascots.
metaTitle: Winter Olympics' Gold Medal Cars - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Winter Olympics Gold Medal Cars: At Sochi, Volkswagen’s Russian car brands are transporting everything from medals to mascots. See the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: After watching this video of the guy in the Sochi polar bear suit struggling to fit his formidable fur head into the passenger's seat of an Olympic vehicle until he gives up and lies down in the back seat, I had to wonder: Was there no larger auto at the Olympic organizers’ disposal to accommodate the top-heavy mascot? Turns out that Volkswagen Group Rus, a collection of VW’s brands in Russia, is supplying the fleet of about 3,000 support vehicles from VW, Audi, and Skoda for the Olympic and Paralympic Games, and they actually do come in all shapes and sizes.

Skaters, skiers, bobsledders, and pipe riders, plus their gear and coaches, have access to transport en masse via VW commercial vehicles with names unfamiliar on the U.S market like the Multivan, Transporter, Caravelle, and Crafter. (Any of these vehicles would have better suited the oversize Sochi mascot.)

Of course, not every job calls for massive interior volume. Sedans make up about 25 percent of the Sochi fleet, putting Audi’s four-wheel mastery to work on Russia's roads with A4, A6, and A8 models. The Olympic committee can also call on the less stylish Skoda Octavia and Superb when needed, as well as VW’s Polo, Passat, and Phaeton to get them around the Olympic Village and beyond.

Snow and ice are easily handled by the VW Touareg and the Audi Q5 and Q7 but when conditions go from worrisome to beyond manageable, organizers can call on a tricked-out version of the VW Amarok. It’s a mid-size truck that boasts an efficient diesel engine and is seemingly available everywhere but the U.S. The specially modified Sochi Polar Expedition Amarok with monster wheels recently off-roaded its way into the Guinness World Records book on a pre-Olympic publicity traverse across Russia.

Given such a wide variety of Olympic vehicles, surely the Sochi bear shouldn’t have had to suffer such global viral indignity in a Skoda Yeti.  Or maybe I’m looking at it all wrong.  Perhaps, like any resourceful Olympian, the polar bear simply found a way to get the job done in difficult conditions.

pageElements.text: The idea of entering an automotive parts superstore is so daunting for some of us that even if we need something as simple as windshield washer fluid, we will pay a premium to have the dealer to do it rather than buy it ourselves. I checked in with Advance Auto Parts store's Brian Bartholomew to find out what the five most common purchases were.

1. Fluids

Even if you are not planning to become a shade-tree mechanic, you should know what products your car uses. Check the owner's manual for the specs, and then check out the savings if you buy them ahead of time from a superstore (instead of in an emergency at the 7-11). Particularly with older engines, check your oil regularly, and if it is running low, having a quart available to top off your supply will be most welcome. Plus most stores have used oil recycling programs, making it a no-brainer to dispose of that spent oil responsibly. While you are there, pick up a gallon of windshield washer fluid, which is generally cheaper here.

2. Batteries

Did you know you can not only buy a battery at the auto parts store, but have one installed? I didn't. A common culprit when your car struggles to start, the battery’s charge is easily checked by your auto parts store. Brian notes batteries are a large part of his store's business: “In winter, we might sell thirty-five to forty batteries in a day.” Which is why many retailers like Advance Auto Parts offer free diagnostic, installation, and charging services. They'll recycle the old one, too. While you are waiting for the new powerplant to be hooked up, browse the jumper cables just in case.

3. Car Wax and Detailing Supplies

There is a dizzying array of products to shine, clean, and recondition your car inside and out, so it makes sense to check with the experts at your superstore before buying. Chances are they’ve used the products themselves and have had lots of helpful feedback from auto-obsessed regulars. Like so many other leisure pursuits, doing a really good job of washing your car yourself is satisfying

4. Windshield Wipers

Replace your blades at least once or twice a year, recommends Brian. Those who live in wintry climates will know that the change of seasons usually requires a fresh set of wiper blades anyway. Here's where online shopping can be helpful. Advance Auto Parts' website, for example, lets you select your exact year, make, and model of car and will show you the blades that are an exact fit so you can go to the store armed with that information. Or, at the superstore, there's usually a printed guide to blades, or ask the clerk to look up the proper style for your car; he or she can also advise you on the tradeoffs between price and quality. It takes just a few minutes to remove the old ones and click the new ones on.

image.altText: rugged ridge all terrain floor mats

pageElements.text:
5. Floor Mats

All manner of unspeakable detritus gets ground into the carpet of your car’s floor on a daily basis, wearing and tearing until once proud fibers are rubbed bare. A good set of all-weather floor mats is one of the most satisfying aftermarket items to put into your car, and even high-end mats aren't that pricey; at Advance Auto Parts, for example, you can get a pair of heavy-duty WeatherTech all-weather floor mats for under $100. Auto stores carry a variety of aftermarket mats made to fit most vehicles, but if you need or want something in particular the store can order it for you. Consider a seat protector while you are at it, especially if you have light-colored upholstery.

Remember these big chains have purchasing power for lower prices and are staffed by the kinds of people who live and breathe autos. Brian says he’s noticed women are increasingly present and seem more comfortable shopping the store. And I think we can all agree that that's exactly how it should be.

pageElements.text: The venerable Accord has been one of Honda’s most dependable models, and for 2014 the tradition continues.  Chalk up the attraction to the variety of trim and engine choices that the Accord offers in a reliable, roomy package. Choose your powerplant from the sensible four-cylinder to a more powerful V-6 to those ultra-green plug-in or two-motor hybrids. The manual V-6 coupe has drawn compliments for driving fun, but for conservative types a six-speed automatic or continuously variable transmission are available.  nteriors have been freshened up to give the center stack a more integrated look over previous models, but with a buffet of buttons, screen displays, and controls, the items on the dash can seem almost too plentiful. Still, many drivers will appreciate all the available technology in the form of a media touchscreen and a navigation system, as well as driver assist options. Select Econ mode, which comes standard on the Accord, to save fuel.  Opt for the new Honda Lane Watch to monitor those cars that sneak up alongside you, or avoid punting the rear end of the car in front of you, with the forward collision warning system. To add to its practical appeal, the Accord is a Top Safety Pick by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Trying to be all things to all people means the Accord does lack flair in the style department, but that shouldn’t bother those seeking a solid, capable commuter or family sedan that won’t let them down.

Competitors:

Ford Fusion
Nissan Altima
Toyota Camry

Cool Tech:

i-MMD Hybrid continuously cycles between two motors, gas and electric, to maximize fuel economy.
Honda Lane Watch can be set to come on automatically when you hit your turn signal.
Grade Logic Control system adjusts transmission to adapt to road conditions.

Looks:

Center stack is less bulky and has improved material quality.
New exhaust tips add some flare to the rear end view.

New for 2014

Additional non-plug-in hybrid model is added for 2014.

title: Toyota RAV4 to Mackinac Island
subTitle: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves.
promoTeaserSmall: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves.
promoTeaser: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves.
metaDescription: Toyota RAV4 to Mackinac: You've heard the Great Lakes are frozen over? We drove the small SUV up north to see for ourselves. Read our story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Like most people in Michigan, I was suffering from cabin fever when I climbed into a Toyota RAV4 at the start of a frigid February weekend. My husband, Tom, and I considered hitting I-75 and driving south until our tires reached sand, but we decided instead to go the “polar” opposite direction—Mackinac Island.

This car-free island just a few miles off the eastern shore of Michigan’s Upper Peninsula in Lake Huron is infested with tourists in the summer, but when the snow starts to blow, it becomes a ghost town. A ferry continues to run until the icy waters become too treacherous, but after that the only way to get there is to make a quick trip in an airplane to or from Saint Ignace, the town on the Upper Peninsula side of the Mackinac Bridge.

That is, until, at some point early in the New Year, an ice bridge forms linking Mackinac Island to the real world. Then, for a short period of time it is possible to walk, bicycle, or snowmobile between Saint Ignace and the island. We had to see that (and try it) for ourselves.

The ice bridge is sanctioned by no official organization, and no one will deem it safe for passage, whether officially or even in conversation. The islanders explained to us how unnamed individuals test the depth of the ice, and once they feel it is safe, they plant discarded Christmas trees along two paths. The northern route is the shortest distance; it lands on the island at the opposite end of the main street.

The second route is called the Beeline. It is longer, but it delivers you much closer to the main street. However, it is also considered more dangerous. Both begin in the harbor behind the Mackinac Grille restaurant in Saint Ignace, which boasts a large parking lot that is free for all—but pack a shovel, because you could easily get plowed under. On the weekend when we went, there were plenty of snowmobilers, and we also saw a group of fat-tire bikers and even a few walkers. Be aware when you plan a trip that the ice bridge is fickle. It can last for two months or only a few days.
Be aware, if you plan a trip to Mackinac in winter, that the ice bridge is fickle. It can last for two months or only a few days.

Since we do not own a snowmobile or a fat-tire bike and weren’t ready for a five-mile hike, we opted to take the air option to get to Mackinac Island. But first, we needed to get to Saint Ignace. Since we would be flying over in a small plane, we thought it made sense to pack light. However, once we packed snowshoes and enough winter gear to keep us warm in the single-digit temperatures, we were more in the heavy range. The RAV4 has plenty of room for two, but if you threw in a dog and a couple of kids, it would be helpful that the XLE comes standard with roof rails. Optional crossbars are available, and they'd be needed.

Mackinac Island is a straight shot up I-75 from Ann Arbor, but we opted to take the scenic route and spend a night in the upscale tourist town of Glen Arbor. In the morning our route hugged the Lake Michigan coastline, revealing a winter wonderland that the Sochi Olympics organizers would envy. We were a little disappointed that there was not a remote start, but spring is only twenty-three days away, so I will forgive Toyota. Since there are no heated seats even available on the XLE, I was glad it had cozy cloth seats. The seats, however, seemed to attract lint and crumbs, and a power driver’s seat is not available in this trim, either.

To remedy my complaints, if you bump up to the Limited package, your behind will thank you. Standard features are leather seating, an eight-way power driver's seat with lumbar support, and best of all, those front seats are heated. My bum says Limited all the way. Plus, it also is the only trim level with which you can get a blind-spot monitor, lane departure signal, and auto high beams.

The RAV4 has a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine that makes 176 horsepower. Ours was equipped with all-wheel drive (AWD). Actually, it operates in front-wheel-drive mode until the dynamic torque control senses slipping in the front tires and then automatically switches to AWD, or the driver can elect to push a button to lock it into AWD. The roads were mostly snow covered, but the RAV4 was stable and performed as if were traveling on clear pavement. But once we were far north enough to be sharing the roads with snowmobiles,  we locked in the AWD. The transition was undetectable, and we surefooted our way until we returned to a road that had seen the blade of a snowplow to unlock the AWD.
If I owned this car, I am sure I would quickly get addicted to the apps. I love the idea of pressing a button and seeing a weather radar right on the on-board monitor.

For the remainder of our drive, the sun was shining, and we were able to enjoy the scenery rather than white-knuckle our way North. The sport-ute proved to drive more like a car, and the ride was both smooth and sturdy. Our RAV4 was equipped with the optional Entune premium audio with navigation and app suite, a $1,030 option. The navigation system proved a little tricky until I found the control to change the view from direction-based to a mode that kept north always at the top. I had easily linked my phone, but I did not bother to download the Entune app on my phone to use Pandora, traffic, and weather right on the vehicle monitor. If I owned this car, I am sure I would quickly get addicted to the apps. I love the idea of pressing a button and seeing a weather radar right on the on-board monitor.

As we drove over the Mackinac Bridge that links the Upper and Lower Peninsulas of Michigan, all that we could see was a giant sheet of ice. There was a long mark where an icebreaker had broken a path that clearly showed the shipping route, but it had since frozen over. On the day we crossed over the bridge, the Great Lakes were 88 percent frozen, and Lake Huron was estimated at 97 percent. I grew up with snowmobiles, and I was conflicted as to which method of transportation was safer. I have a faint memory from my childhood of being on snowmobiles crossing a lake when the top layer suddenly was less than solid. But flying in a small plane ranks high on my list of fears as well.

Once we reached the tiny Mackinac County Airport in Saint Ignace, we hopped on a six-seater plane from Great Lakes Air (round trip $50) and made the five-minute flight to the island. The view was phenomenal. We could easily see the ice bridge with snowmobilers hightailing it to the island. I stumbled over a quick Hail Mary, and we were on the ground.
The 500 year-round residents rely on the freedom that the snowmobiles deliver. In fact, most of the kids drive themselves to school by snowmobile once they turn twelve.

A horse-drawn carriage taxi met us at the airport, and we clip-clopped our way from the center of the snow-globe island to the Pontiac Lodge. At first it seemed wrong to see all the snowmobiles zipping around on the normally gas-free island—other than the horses' odoriferous contributions, of course. But I quickly realized that the approximately 500 year-round residents of Mackinac Island rely on the freedom that the snowmobiles deliver. In fact, most of the school kids drive themselves to school via snowmobile once they are twelve. Just the idea of that makes me envious of the islanders. A bike is one thing, but imagine the freedom of a snowmobile.

This is not a vacation spot for shoppers or indoor enthusiasts. There are only two restaurant/bars, a grocery store, and just  a handful of accommodations that are open during the winter. But the true beauty lies outside. It is a paradise for snowmobilers, cross-country skiers, and snowshoers. Fat-tire bikers told us that the snowmobile paths were great for them, but they shared that much more than four inches of snow does make pedaling difficult.

Cawthorne’s Village Inn held a chili cookoff the day we arrived, and the locals and visiting snowmobilers filled the place way past capacity. We had our sights set on the lantern-lit cross-country or snowshoe event that was scheduled for 6:00 to 8:00 p.m. So we took a trip to Doud's grocery store and cobbled together a snack.

The one horse-drawn carriage available is actually less than available: we called several times, and each request was rebuked. So we headed out to the start of the hike on foot, carrying our snowshoes. I haven’t been to the island in at least twenty years, and I had forgotten how steep the climb is to the Michigan Governor's Summer Residence. Seriously, I wished we had a Sherpa, and I was the load they were carrying. Or how ‘bout a mule?? I don’t think we were trespassing as we walked through the drifts and looked out over the straits of Mackinaw from the governor’s porch. I felt like, since I pay taxes, it was a legit visit.

From here we skirted around Fort Michilimackinac. Built by the British during the American Revolutionary War and surprisingly part of the War of 1812 as well, the fort is now part of the Mackinac Island State Park. I am sure few visitors know that the park is actually over seventy percent of the island. A map of ski trails highlights the miles of trails that are available.
We struggled to capture the evening, but our photos in no way matched the beauty or the complete silence that we experienced as we laughed our way through the inky night.

By the time we reached the beginning of the two-mile lit loop it was quite dark, but a big fat full moon beamed down and made the path clear. That is, until we reached the dense woods. We popped on our snowshoes and headed out into the night. On our hike we only saw a half-dozen skiers, and most of them were in the first half hour. It was seriously dark between the lanterns, and we were happy to have headlamps to lead the way.

When we reached the famous rock formation that overlooks Lake Huron known as Arch Rock, we had the night to ourselves. We struggled to capture the evening with our amateur camera, but our shots in no way matched the absolute beauty, coupled with the complete silence, that we experienced as we laughed our way through the inky night. The loop seemed more like five miles than two, and at the end was a campfire with hot chocolate provided by the state park. We mingled with locals who shared stories of living on the island. It was fascinating to imagine living on less than four square miles—relying on bikes and foot power to move about for most of the year. I can imagine this simpler life, but I would look forward to the snow when I could get on my snowmobile and hit the ice bridge to the mainland.

Also, I would seriously miss the freedom that a car represents.

The next day we hiked around the village and had a leisurely lunch at the Mustang Lounge. We walked to the ice bridge, where one of the fat tire bikers was kind enough to let us take a spin on his $2,500 bike. Tom was enamored with the bike but not the price. We were bundled like toddlers sent out to play in the snow in their snowsuits, and we felt like kids on a playground. We poked around the deserted Grand Hotel and ended up at Cawthorne’s for a quick meal with an individual TV at our table to enjoy the Winter Olympics. As the sun was setting, we walked back out on the ice bridge just in time to catch the sun setting behind the Mackinac Bridge.

The forecast for the next day was for rain, sleet, and windy conditions, and we needed to get back to reality, so we arranged for a taxi to catch the first flight of the day. I secretly decided that if the conditions were horrid, I would stay on the island until spring. But luckily the storm was still several hours away when we stepped aboard the Lilliputian plane. Since I am able to share this tale, obviously we landed safely. As idyllic as the island experience was, it was nice to be back to the mainland. Once we were in the RAV4 we headed south on the real Beeline, I-75.

I highly recommend a winter trip to Mackinac Island, and the snowier and colder the better. Remember, it must be very cold for a long period of time before the magical ice bridge is ready for travel. I would seriously consider renting a snowmobile in Saint Ignace and having full run of the island, and next time I will stay at one of the B&Bs. Other than that, I wouldn’t change a thing.

2013 Toyota RAV4 XLE AWD

Price: $26,535 base price (including destination); $28,552 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 176 horsepower, 172 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/29 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Dynamic Torque Control All-Wheel Drive
Option I can’t live without: Entune App Suite (part of Display Audio with Navigation and Entune package, $1,030)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, stability and traction control, brake assist and Smart Stop technology, roof rails, Bluetooth connectivity
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Hyundai Santa Fe

title: 2014 Cadillac CTS AWD 2.0T Luxury
subTitle: Is this the sedan you are looking for?
promoTeaserSmall: Is this the sedan you are looking for?
promoTeaser: Is this the sedan you are looking for?
metaDescription: 2014 Cadillac CTS AWD 2.0T Luxury: Does this car belong in your driveway? Read our review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $53,925 (base price of this model), $56,875 as tested (prices include destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 272 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Driver Awareness package, including side blind zone alert
Option I can’t live without: Navigation system ($905)
Notable standard features on this model: Brembo performance brakes, Cadillac User Experience (CUE) with 8.0-inch touchscreen display, Bluetooth connectivity, heated steering wheel, remote start
Notable options on this model: Eighteen-inch painted fifteen-spoke wheels ($1,550), navigation system with surround sound ($905), Majestic Plum Metallic paint ($495)
You might also be considering: BMW 5 Series, Lexus GS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

It’s all new. It is Motor Trend's Car of the Year for 2014. And it’s absolutely, undeniably a Cadillac to look at. Its only problem may be that last part. We tried out the 2014 Cadillac CTS in its top Luxury trim but with its 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, rather than the 3.6-liter V-6 or the even sportier twin-turbo Vsport version. Call it the everyday CTS, the one that a younger or less wealthy buyer might go for when seeking luxury more than performance.

Because luxury is a state of mind, and you can get into that state of mind quite easily when stepping into the car. I visualized myself pushing my mink coat aside to strap in. But the floatiness and even flabbiness of old Cadillacs is no more. This feels like a completely modern sedan.
On the other hand, it's not for someone who is that much less wealthy. Witness the as-tested price of $56,875.
Cadillac went straight at the mid-size luxury cars from BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Audi, and, as the New York Times commented, "the German lessons are paying off."

Cadillac went straight at the mid-size luxury cars from BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, and Lexus with this sedan and, as the New York Times commented in a January story on the CTS, “The German lessons are paying off.” The use of aluminum cut weight (and made the CTS come in about 200 pounds lighter than the BMW 528i, for example). Technology abounds, including standard Brembo front brakes, a sport suspension, a rearview camera, forward collision alert, lane departure warning, and side blind zone and rear cross-traffic alerts. It also has General Motors' annoying but useful Safety Alert Seat, which vibrates when you are in danger of leaving your lane or getting into a crash.

The elephant in the passenger compartment might be the Cadillac Cue telematics system. I didn't personally have any trouble with it, but I have heard and read enough complaints that I'd advise any prospective buyer to play with it a lot before closing a sale, to make sure it works for you. "Cue" stands for Cadillac User Experience. It has an eight-inch touchscreen information display and, on the one we drove, navigation (we had the optional navigation system/uplevel surround sound package, priced at $905). Cadillac uses terms such as "intuitive" and "smartphone- and tablet-influenced controls" to describe the system, but really, it's complex. Of course, to an owner who spent some time with it, there might be a whole different report card than for someone like me who just got in for a short time. But all the choices on the screen can be distracting, and I only worked on it while securely parked.

Since it is winter, I appreciated that the model we drove had all-wheel drive. The seats were supportive without being squashy; the ride was the same. The CTS was sure-footed, comfortable, and so assertive to drive that every stereotype about a Cadillac's living-room-sofa ride feel went straight out of my head.

Having said that, it could have been even better. The midrange CTS we got to drive did not have some of the features you could get by going for the Vsport version. The rear-wheel-drive Vsport has a twin-turbo V-6 that makes 420 horsepower, mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. It also has Magnetic Ride Control and an electronic limited-slip differential to make this sporty sedan even sportier, and automatic park assist to make parallel parking a twenty-first-century experience. For those looking for the maximum performance out of this new Cadillac, the Vsport seems like the one to go for, and its price ($59,995, including destination) is not so much higher than the four-cylinder version to put it out of contention.

The Verdict:

So, should you buy this car? It’s like what your mother told you about true love, or the critics told you about art: you’ll know it when you see it. If the look and feel of a Cadillac CTS does it for you, there’s no point in worrying about whether a BMW or Mercedes will impress more people in the parking lot. You can buy this somewhat flashier, very American car and know you've made the right choice. It's just as good as it looks, or, depending on your taste, even better. The 2.0-liter Luxury model with AWD, shown here, will be just right for most people, if they're looking for a Cadillac as a modern luxury sedan more than as a sports car. But try the Vsport before you decide, since the prices are so close between it and the four-cylinder CTS.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The CTS is the brash American in the mid-size luxury segment, but it should not be overlooked. In fact I think it stands out from its peers for its unique grille and aggressive stance. The interior is lush and sophisticated, and the materials can stand up to the German and Japanese contenders. With the plethora of engines and trim levels that are available, there is an option for most any driver. That being said, it still does not have the refined powertrains that the Mercedes E-Class and Audi A6 deliver.
