title: 2015 Ford Mustang GT Coupe
subTitle: Moray Callum, Ford's new global design chief, explains the thinking behind the all-new fastback.
promoTeaserSmall: Moray Callum, Ford's new global design chief, explains the thinking behind the all-new fastback.
promoTeaser: Moray Callum, Ford's new global design chief, explains the thinking behind the all-new fastback.
metaDescription: 2015 Ford Mustang GT Coupe: Moray Callum, Ford's new global design chief, explains the thinking behind the all-new 2015 Mustang. See the designer walkaround on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I met Ford's newest vice-president of design, Moray Callum, in the late 1980s when he worked as a design consultant to Ghia, a design studio in Turin, Italy, owned by Ford. His very illustrious career there included working on the sweet 1989 Ghia Via concept and the exquisite Aston Martin Lagonda Vignale.

He took a real job at Ford in 1995, and his career there included a stint running Mazda global design when it was still part of the bulging Ford portfolio of car companies. His tenure in Japan influenced the 2005 Miata, the Mazda 3, the 2006 Mazda 5, and the 2007 CX-7 and CX-9, a whole row of extremely successful designs.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/E9krJQiZil0?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It was a big shocker when Ford's worldwide design boss, J Mays, "retired" last fall, and Moray was given the top spot. He remains his affable self, with a Scottish brogue so thick, you'll have to pay extra attention as he walks us around the new Mustang.
Oh, and yes, Jaguar's equally talented design chief, Ian Callum, is Moray's brother. When they get to talking to each other, no one understands them.

title: Best and Worst from Geneva
subTitle: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
promoTeaserSmall: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
promoTeaser: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
metaTitle: Best and Worst from Geneva - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Best and Worst from Geneva: Hits, misses, and a revelation about how the 1% think, from Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Vanity would have me believe you’re reading this because you’re a devoted fan of my writing. In that case, you may want to know that I also edit the magazine’s Ignition section, read lots of Kurt Vonnegut, and would eat sushi at every meal if it were socially acceptable. Reality tells me you just want to know how I landed this amazing job. Fine. Based on my experience, here’s some advice.

1) Major in journalism. Most of us here aren’t racecar drivers -- we’re writers and reporters. It probably helps if you’ve attended journalism school, as I did at the University of Maryland, or worked for some periodical. That said, deputy editor Joe DeMatio now claims he was more intrigued by my second degree in Jewish studies, even though he’s never once asked me to write about the exploits of Simon bar Kochba.
2) Know how to operate a manual transmission. Seems obvious, but I actually did not upon being hired. I taught myself during my first month on the job by visiting six Ann Arbor dealerships to test drive stick-shift economy cars. My sincere apologies to whoever ended up buying that Ford Focus.
3) Learn everything you can about cars. I grew up pouring over car magazines and memorizing zero-to-sixty times as if they were catechism. People have been asking me for car-buying advice since before I could drive.
4) Realize you actually know nothing about cars. A brief conversation with design editor Robert Cumberford, editor-in-chief Jean Jennings, or any other of the veterans here leaves you humbled and astounded by their wealth of automotive knowledge. It’s truly one of the best parts of working here.
5) Be persistent. I wrote to Automobile’s editors. And called. And wrote them some more.
6) Be lucky. I really have no idea why then deputy editor Joe DeMatio answered my unsolicited voicemail. I hadn’t even pronounced his name correctly (it’s De-MAY-shee-oh, not De-MAH-tee-oh). But he did, and here I am, driving cars and writing about them for my devoted fans.

pageElements.text:
Hit: Mazda 2

The Hazumi concept, which will be the Mazda 2 just as soon as it grows real door handles and mirrors, is yet another handsome execution of the Kodo design language. Like the 3 and 6, it looks more like a rear-wheel-drive European car than a front-wheel-drive Japanese car. That’ll be a huge advantage for the new 2 here in Europe, where the B-segment is more significant than any other.

For the U.S. market, the most significant change in the 2 will be its point of assembly. The car will be built at Mazda's new factory in Mexico, which has recently started churning out North American Mazda 3s. That should insulate the brand from sharp currency changes.

Miss: BMW 2-Series Active Tourer

Unlike many of my colleagues, I’m not prejudiced against front-wheel-drive cars, even from sporty brands. I recognize that BMW needs the profits and sales volumes that only front-wheel-drive cars can earn so that it can subsidize ambitious investments like Project i and playthings like the M3.

That said, I am having a lot of trouble warming up to this front-wheel-drive car. The cab-forward proportions and tall roofline scream “dumpy utility vehicle.” Perhaps BMW designers should spend some time studying the Mazda Hazumi concept, which looks more like a BMW than this vehicle. The name adds insult to injury, muddying the already confusing split between the brand’s odd-numbered sedans and even numbered coupes/four-door coupes.

Hit: Infiniti Q50 Eau Rouge

Infiniti got a lot of attention by stuffing the GT-R’s 3.8-liter twin-turbo V-6 between the front fenders of the Q50. Now comes the inevitable question: will it reach production? Infiniti CEO Johan de Nysschen indicates that the will is certainly there.
“Look, if we were run as a dictatorship, we’d be building it now,” he says.

It’s finding a way that could be very difficult. The biggest challenge may be finding a transmission that can handle 443 pound-feet of torque (the GT-R’s rear-mounted transaxle would be a tough fit in the Q50). Infiniti's de Nysschen adds that he doesn’t want to “run out…and buy an expensive transmission,” such as the seven-speed automatic that partner Mercedes-Benz employs in the V-12-powered S65 AMG. Then the engine would need to be extensively retuned to work with a different transmission.
“That's why it has not been done before: It's not easy," he says.
Still, there’s a compelling case for Infiniti, which has struggled for two decades to establish itself as a first-class luxury brand, to go ahead with the ambitious project.

Hit: Obscenely Expensive Tchotchkes

What separates the Geneva Motor Show from most others is the presence of real, live rich people. Every brand makes sure to offer this clientele something absurdly expensive to take home, even if they decide not to put down a deposit on a Gumpert Explosion. Can I interest you in a 10,000 Euro scale model of a Bugatti Atlantic? Or, perhaps, Porsche swim trunks for 131 Swiss francs ($148)?

Revelation: Luxury Is Excess (Or Is It the Other Way Around?)

Silly as all these extravagances seem to us regular folks, they provide important insight into what real luxury is. No one needs a luxury car, certainly not when your average Kia or Volkswagen comes loaded with premium features. The key to getting people to spend more on a car is not some special paint color or a branded infotainment system but rather, the sense that the car is a pure reward.

title: How Much Do Rearview Cameras Help?
subTitle: Are they effective in preventing accidents? Insurance Institute for Highway Safety checked it out.
promoTitle: How Much Do Rearview Cameras Help?
promoTeaserSmall: Are they effective in preventing accidents? Insurance Institute for Highway Safety checked it out.
promoTeaser: Are they effective in preventing accidents? Insurance Institute for Highway Safety checked it out.
metaTitle: How Much Do Rearview Cameras Help? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A recent IIHS study on the effectiveness of backup cameras illustrates that the technology does help reduce the risk of rear pedestrian collision. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Rearview cameras are widely regarded as one of the more essential safety features and technologies on new vehicles. Research suggests that rearview cameras do decrease the risk of backup collisions, and the National Highway Traffic Safety Transportation (NHTSA) added the technology to its list of recommended features in its safety ratings last September. Yet when the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) tested whether rearview cameras help drivers avoid "backover" crashes into pedestrians, the results were less than conclusive.

According to the new list, backover accidents kill 292 people and injure 18,000 every year, even though backup cameras and parking sensors have become available on mainstream cars. Unsurprisingly, the elderly and young children are the most frequent victims of the accidents, which usually take place in parking lots or driveways. Large SUVs and pickups tend to have the worst blind spots and, as a result, are more likely to be involved in this type of incident.

The IIHS study involved 111 volunteers, who unknowingly participated in the rearview camera exercise. The volunteers thought they were testing the infotainment systems, but when asked to back out of a spot to return to the lot entrance, a child-sized foam crash dummy was placed behind the vehicle. It may sound cruel for an unwitting volunteer to discover he or she just killed a foam child, but it’s all in the name of science.

While stationary, the dummy was struck 56 percent of the time when drivers relied on the rear camera alone. The combination of a rearview camera and parking sensors was, oddly enough, slightly less effective, because the sensors often activate too late to let drivers brake in time before a collision. With just parking sensors, only one in sixteen drivers avoided hitting the dummy. Every single driver without the aid of technology ran into the dummy. In cases where the dummy was in motion, drivers were four times less likely to hit it than when it was stationary.
Shown here: 2014 Toyota Corolla

images.caption: Chrysler's rearview camera.
Rearview camera view in a 2013 Honda Accord.
2013 Mercedes-Benz C-Class shows this view from the rearview camera.
Volkswagen rearview camera placement.
2012 Ford Explorer with rearview camera screen.
Rearview camera in a 2013 Nissan Altima.
Rearview camera's screen in a 2013 Nissan Altima.
2014 Toyota Corolla LE Eco's screen.

pageElements.text: “Having an available rearview video system on a vehicle model should not justify design choices that restrict direct visibility around the vehicle," the Institute said.

The IIHS says backup cameras reduce blind zones by an average of about 90 percent, but even when the technology is used in accordance with rearview mirrors, side mirrors, and rear glances, it isn’t perfect. Blind zones near the bumpers remain problematic, and the cameras are not reliably effective in varied lighting conditions like shade.
Shown here: 2013 Nissan Altima

The IIHS study shows that rearview cameras are definitely effective in reducing the risk of backup pedestrian collisions but that there is still progress to be made. Even more important, it shows that designers still have a responsibility to provide good visibility because the technology is still imperfect. “Having an available rearview video system on a vehicle model should not justify design choices that restrict direct visibility around the vehicle," the Institute said in a statement last July.

Related story:

Should Rearview Cameras Be the Law? October 14, 2013

title: Was that a Google Autonomous Car?
subTitle: Building an autonomous car is a big problem to solve, even for a company that loves big problems.
promoTitle: Was that a Google Autonomous Car?
promoTeaserSmall: Building an autonomous car is a big problem to solve, even for a company that loves big problems.
promoTeaser: Building an autonomous car is a big problem to solve, even for a company that loves big problems.
metaTitle: Was that a Google Autonomous Car?- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Was that a Google Autonomous Car? Building an autonomous car is a big problem to solve, even for a company that loves big problems. Read a progress report on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: For Google, the quest for a driverless car started ten years ago—in 2004—in the Mojave Desert with the DARPA Grand Challenge. The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) offered a cash prize for anyone who could create an autonomous vehicle. That first year, things did not go well. Not a single car that entered the race meant to test the mettle of those early efforts made it through the challenge.

But Google—always up for a project that involves solving big problems—kept at it. And on the ten-year anniversary of what was then little more than a fun science project for the data company, I thought it would be fun to find out how that crazy science project is going. So, even though the Google car people aren’t talking to press, I annoyed everyone I could with questions about the Google car during a recent visit to the Google campus in Mountain View.

Building an autonomous car is a big problem to solve, even for a company that loves big problems. But it’s certainly a worthy one: 1.2 million people are killed in car accidents annually, and 93 percent of accidents are caused by human error. But teaching a car to recognize every possible thing—person, bicycle, tree, raccoon, whatever—it might encounter on the road and what to do in all possible scenarios required some serious science. The car needs a detailed up-to-the-minute map of every road, sensors (laser, radar, GPS) that tell can tell it accurately where it is and what’s near it, high-resolution cameras and algorithms that enable it to understand and react to objects and creatures, an enormous amount of data, and a processor capable of analyzing all of that information quickly enough to make split-second decisions. Much of that technology barely existed in 2004. But a lot has changed, very quickly, since then, as anyone who has ever used Google Maps on a smartphone will tell you. Google has most of the data it needs now and the processing power to analyze it.
In 2012, Google co-founder Sergey Brin said autonomous cars could be safe for operation in five years.

So two years ago, at Google's headquarters, California Governor Jerry Brown signed SB 1298, which established guidelines to allow autonomous vehicles to be tested and operated in California. At the signing ceremony, Google co-founder Sergey Brin said autonomous cars could be safe for operation in five years. Google hasn’t said anything since, neither publicly nor when I was pelting them with questions this week, to contradict that prediction or change that timeframe.

In fact, there are about two dozen self-driving cars on the streets of San Francisco every day. Most are probably on their way to or from the Googleplex in Mountain View. And Google cars have logged more than 500,000 miles in self-driving mode. The company started buying Toyotas and Priuses a few years ago and retrofitting them with sensors and Google’s autonomous driving software.

These days, the Google autonomous cars you see on the road is more likely to be a Lexus RX450h, though, with a Google employee behind the wheel who has been trained on the car and is helping it gain more driving experience, which in the case of the car means recognizing real-world objects and deciding how to react. At any time, the driver can take over control of the car.
The Google cars have never had a single accident while in autonomous driving mode. The few fender benders the cars have been in occurred when humans were in control.

But since so much of the heavy lifting in data collection has been done and sensors and processors have come a long way, the cars are now pretty good at driving. And everything one car learns can be passed on to all the others with a simple software upload. So that means it’s possible for a brand-new car to have the collective experience of fifty years of driving. And even these Lexus prototypes are safer than most human drivers who tend to be easily distracted, drunk, or young, and, even when experienced and sober, don’t have unwavering focus, a map of every street, and a 360-degree view of their surroundings uploaded to their brains. The Google cars have never had a single accident while in autonomous driving mode. The few fender benders the cars have been in occurred when humans were in control.

But just because smart, self-driving, capable cars are on the street doesn’t mean you will be able to buy one anytime soon. “At Google[x], we try hundreds of projects and then move forward with a few that we think are viable and going to have a huge impact on the world,” Katelin Jabbari, a Google spokesperson I cornered,  admitted. “The self-driving car project is certainly one of those. The team has made a lot of progress, and we continue to refine the technology."

Google[x] refers to ideas that are (mostly) in the pure research stage at Google. These are huge problems that, if solved, change the lives of lots of people for which Google is seeking radical solutions. Moonshots, they like to call them. Google Glass is another of these. In the spirit of academia, these projects do not have an expected outcome, a business development plan, or any of the business-side attributes of a product in development...yet.

So the autonomous car is a viable Google[x]project. But it’s still a science project. Nonetheless, this is clearly a science project that’s come a long way in ten years—and one that holds enormous promise for saving lives, giving people back the time they spend commuting, and reducing parking problems (a self-driving car can go do something else rather than sit in a parking space.) Will the Google self-driving car change the world as thoroughly as Google search did? That remains to be seen. But it is certainly a big problem that is well on its way to being solved. And the company is busy thinking about ways to make it a reality.

title: Openbay Service App
subTitle: Need to find a mechanic? Want to compare estimates from several shops? There’s an app for that.
promoTeaserSmall: Need to find a mechanic? Want to compare estimates from several shops? There’s an app for that.
promoTeaser: Need to find a mechanic? Want to compare estimates from several shops? There’s an app for that.
metaDescription: Openbay Service App Need to find a mechanic? Want to compare estimates from several shops? There’s an app for that. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Have you ever wished there was a way to compare, book, and pay for auto mechanic services online or from your phone? Software entrepreneur Rob Infantino had that very wish when he was presented with an outrageous estimate at his local dealer. He walked out and then had to face the arduous task of making individual calls to a variety of shops in search of high-quality service at a more reasonable price. “There’s got to be a better way,” thought Infantino, and he set out to create Openbay, an online marketplace for auto repair.

Launched last October, Openbay has quickly grown from a local Boston enterprise with 400 auto service providers to a national database of 220,000 providers and counting. The free service, which you can find at Openbay.com, has a clean, uncluttered look and is delightfully devoid of any advertising because it charges a ten percent fee to the service provider/garage, which is built into the final invoice for each repair.
Openbay is very simple to use. It has a dashboard to access all your account activities and even offers the ability to sign into your account via Facebook.
Rating and reviewing the service you receive is encouraged, in order to strengthen the local community of users and providers.

The first step is to establish your account, during which time you list your vehicles, enter billing information, and complete a few other profile details. When you need a repair, select Request Service for a particular car and state preferences: for instance, you not only enter that you need a wheel alignment but also use a dropdown menu to say how soon you want the repair. Additionally, you can select what kind of amenities you desire from a list that includes loaner car, early dropoff, shuttle service, wait on site, even Wi-Fi. If you don’t exactly know what is wrong with your car, you can submit a Custom Service Request or select General Diagnosis and provide a detailed description in the Notes box.

Once you submit your request. Openbay will contact providers on your behalf. You’ll receive a list of nearby mechanics, who will respond to you with offers. You can compare their prices, locations, and amenities as well as user ratings and reviews before booking your service appointment. When the repair is complete, you pay via Openbay, which will then keep a record of services received.  Provider offers are valid for six months, but Openbay will check in with you at thirty days to request a decision. You can withdraw or modify a request at any time.

What if you take your car in and the mechanic says you need additional repairs? Infantino recommends asking the mechanic to demonstrate to you exactly why the additional repair is needed. That service provider will have to resubmit the new price to you via Openbay, and you will then have the option to accept it or not. You can also submit a request for the newly proposed repair via Openbay for comparison to decide if you are comfortable with the price you are being quoted for those additional repairs.

Rating and reviewing the service you receive is encouraged, in order to strengthen the local community of users and providers. Infantino also points out that Openbay provides a maintenance schedule based on the make, model, and mileage of your vehicle. There are also financial incentives: for every dollar you spend on the site, you earn Openbay Rewards that can be applied to your next repair cost.

“We’ve had repeat customers who’ve brought all the cars in their household, and sometimes they’re getting free services.” said Infantino, “It’s cool for the consumers.”

Openbay began in Boston and started its spread via major metro markets, including Atlanta. At present the company has providers in forty-four states, but there may be times when services are not yet available in your area. Infantino stresses to keep trying: the network is adding new providers every day.  It is also being built systematically as the company works to create a density of service providers over the coming year.
So, next time you hear a mysterious clunk, whine, or rattle coming from your car,  consider signing on to Openbay.com. They may just help you find the right mechanic for the job.

title: The Weekly Windup!
subTitle: The Weekly Windup! Spring is for puppies, ponies, sunny days...and cars that read your mind.
promoTeaserSmall: The Weekly Windup! Spring is for puppies, ponies, sunny days...and cars that read your mind.
promoTeaser: The Weekly Windup! Spring is for puppies, ponies, sunny days...and cars that read your mind.
metaDescription: The Weekly Windup! Spring is for puppies, ponies, sunny days...and cars that read your mind. Read the list on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Happy spring to everyone.
1. This video sums up how done we are with winter.
2. Onward to sunny days. A Tesla fan made this video for $1,500.
3. I wonder if all Scottish dogs are this impatient.

4. This video of the thirty-five-acre Packard plant on Detroit's east side is beautiful. For the sixty years since the plant has been closed, it has been abused by illegal dumpers, graffiti artists, vandals, and scrappers. The Detroit Free Press has an in-depth story of why it needs to go.
5. This pony’s birthday is so big that it takes place in two separate locations.
6. Nanny-state warning: your future car may read your mind.
7. Behind the scenes at Hot Wheels Design studio.
8. Airbags are terrifying and reassuring at the same time.
Image at top: Whitetag/iStock/Thinkstock

pageElements.text: I know the awkward feeling of arriving at an event wearing the same dress as another attendee and, to make matters worse, she indeed is wearing it better. No need to fear the awkward entrance in a 2014 Mini. You can choose from a whole new selection of Mini branded accessories for the outside and inside of your car starting in mid-April.

If you were thinking there were already plenty of aftermarket choices for the Mini Cooper, you weren't wrong, but fashion must continue to move forward. There are four new design lines for both exterior and interior details: Vivid Green. Speedwell Blue, John Cooper Works Pro, and Essential Black. These will complement the previously available roof and side graphics, interior and exterior mirror caps, floor mats, side-indicator surrounds, and a plethora of other unique choices.

Also new for 2014 are coordinated key caps that feature an integrated Near Field Communication chip for data exchange between the key and your smartphone. Once it's synced,  you can control stereo volume and launch apps via the key.

To clarify, the four design lines are not really packages (although Mini calls them Character Packages), but rather a motif that is applied to various accessories that you can then buy à la carte. Speedwell Blue is by far my favorite: it has a fabulous light blue plaid that screams retro British.
Nickelodeon fans may gravitate toward Vivid Green, since it sports a slime green dot pattern on a black background.
The John Cooper Works Pro design will attract the racing enthusiast with its black, red, and gray motif.
And for those who are celebrating black as the new black, I recommend Essential Black.
There are also two new finishes: Gold Jack, which adds a gold tone to the classic Union Jack, and Big Bang, which looks like cartoon bubbles rather than anything celestial.

Don’t forget the wheels as an opportunity to show your flair. You can choose eighteen-inch forged aluminum rims in cross-spoke design, or seventeen-inch light alloy wheels in a multi-spoke design, available in Bright Silver metallic or Liquid Black.
But why stop at silver or black? You can bedazzle your light alloy wheel hubcaps in Chili Red, Bright Orange, Apple Green, or Bright Yellow.

The current fashion trend of mixing clashing patterns, when applied to a brand-new 2014 Mini Cooper, is certain to garner attention. I myself would go all the way with Speedwell Blue and call it a day.

title: Chevrolet Malibu Wins Safety Honors
subTitle: Add another popularly priced car to the short list from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
promoTeaserSmall: Add another popularly priced car to the short list from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
promoTeaser: Add another popularly priced car to the short list from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
metaDescription: Chevrolet Malibu Wins Safety Honors: Add another popularly priced car to the short list from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

pageElements.text: The 2014 Chevrolet Malibu is the latest model on the short list of vehicles to earn the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s Top Safety Pick + award. It’s the only Chevrolet product to make the highly selective list; the Spark minicar is a Top Safety Pick (without the +).

The Malibu received the top Good rating in all of the IIHS’s crash tests, including the most challenging (and newest), the small overlap front crash test. The 2013 model had garnered a less desirable Marginal rating in the front overlap test.
Other vehicles that ascended to the Plus list in the past week were the Nissan Rogue small SUV and the Audi A3.

We reviewed the 2014 Malibu last fall, after its overhaul only one year into a new model. Re-engineered for more rear-seat room and for better fuel economy thanks to stop-start technology, the 2014 Malibu also has a quartet of active safety options: forward collision alert, lane departure warning, side blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert with a rearview camera. In addition to the IIHS honors, the 2014 Malibu also got the top five stars in crash testing by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration earlier this year.

The IIHS ratings are based on both crashworthiness ("how well a vehicle protects its occupants in a crash," as the agency explains) and crash avoidance/mitigation, or the presence of technology to avoid a crash or lessen the severity of one.  Ratings assigned after its five crash tests are Good, Acceptable, Marginal, or Poor. These tests evaluate moderate overlap front, small overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraint performance. To win the coveted Top Safety Pick Plus designation, a vehicle must rank Acceptable or Good in the newer small overlap front crash test and Good in all other areas.
Shopping for a new car? Notice that on many of these models, only certain trim levels get the Plus.

Crash prevention technology is designated as Basic, Advanced, or Superior after track testing; only vehicles that have front crash prevention, no matter what level its rating, can be Top Safety Pick Plus winners.

Those that don't are still eligible to be named Top Safety Pick, provided they meet the crash test standards. Since front crash prevention is relatively new on the market, we can expect more and more new models to become Plus-worthy in the coming few years.

The full list of Top Safety Pick Plus winners is here. Shopping for a new car? Notice that on many of these models, only certain trim levels get the Plus. For example, the 2014 Toyota Highlander, Acura MDX, and Ford Fusion, among others, the award only applies to models with the optional front crash protection technology on board.

title: The Weekly Windup!
subTitle: A magnificent seven items we found out there and brought in here. Start your weekend right!
promoTeaserSmall: A magnificent seven items we found out there and brought in here. Start your weekend right!
promoTeaser: A magnificent seven items we found out there and brought in here. Start your weekend right!
metaDescription: The Weekly Windup - A magnificent seven items we found out there and brought in here. Start your weekend right! They're on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We had to pick carefully among the news items this week, it being April Fool's Week and all, but these seven are guaranteed to be authentic. Have a great weekend!

1. Looking for a career change? Aston Martin has an apprenticeship available. What do you mean, you're too busy? Consider that George W. Bush is a portrait painter now, and Daniel Day-Lewis once took several years off acting to become a shoemaker, so...

2. Love Guinness world records? (You were cheering for the Rosie the Riveter group last weekend, we know.) How about the record just won for fastest lawn mower? (No, not the kid you hired who ran straight over your tulip bed. This one was way better.)
3. Hate botched custom cars? You'll love to hate this one.
4. One step forward, one step back: We get rearview cameras (starting in 2018 on all cars). But now, our friends at Motor Trend alert us to a move to get rid of side-view mirrors.

5. Interested in all-black paint schemes? This one just won a prize (and its owner is this person). This one ought to.

And then there's this thing.

6. Speaking of black cars: It just opened today in the U.S., but people have spent $100 million already seeing Captain America: The Winter Soldier, surely in part because of the Chevrolet Corvette Stingray that co-stars, driven by the Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson). Will your dollars add to the take this weekend?
7. Two interesting trucks got attention in New York City yesterday: Jimmy Fallon's new choice, and the ASPCA's.
Photo at top: Fuse/Thinkstock
